webTitle: McIlroy's men catch cold from Gudjonsson

fields.headline: McIlroy's men catch cold from Gudjonsson
fields.standfirst: Gudjonsson 88
fields.trailText: A goal two minutes from time by Thordur Gudjonsson denied Northern Ireland a point at the Laugardalsvollur stadium last night.
fields.body:
A goal two minutes from time by Thordur Gudjonsson denied Northern Ireland a point here at the Laugardalsvollur stadium last night.

It was a goal made in England when a scoreless draw seemed certain. Iceland were awarded a late free-kick, Eidur Gudjohnsen of Chelsea floated the ball into the box and it was headed over the advancing keeper Roy Carroll by Watford's Heidar Helguson for the Las Palmas striker to nod into the net.

Northern Ireland, operating a 4-5-1 system, should have taken the lead after 24 minutes when Jim Magilton, of Ipswich, played a free-kick into the penalty area but Gerry Taggart, the Leicester centre-back, missed from five yards.

Three minutes later Gudjohnsen almost got the breakthrough. His powerful shot from 12 yards looked a certain goal but Carroll, the Wigan goalkeeper, magnificently turned the ball round the post.

Northern Ireland's inaccurate short passing put them under unnecessary pressure as opponents repeatedly intercepted to create dangerous build-ups. Magilton, dominant in midfield, sprinted through just before half-time but his drive went narrowly over.

Northern Ireland's defence was hesitant and frequently they found themselves in trouble of their own making. Taggart, who had struggled from a knee injury, was taken off by Sammy McIlroy at half-time and replaced by Wimbledon's Mark Williams, and this at least added some stability.

Twice Gudjohnsen was only inches off target and Neil Lennon's misplaced free-kick put the Irish back division into further self-inflicted trouble. This time only a brave save by Carroll on the edge of the box prevented Iceland from scoring. But, just when it seemed they would hold out, Gudjonsson struck.

Iceland (4-4-2): B Kristinsson; Helgason, Hreidarsson, Sverrisson, Vidarsson; Gudjonsson, Gunnarsson, R Kristinsson (Gretarsson, h-t), Helguson; Gudjohnsen, Dadason (Sigurdsson, 63min).

Northern Ireland (4-5-1): Carroll; Lomas, Taggart (Williams, h-t), Murdock, Hughes; Johnson, Magilton, Lennon, Horlock, Elliott (Gray, 84); Healy.

Referee: M Merk (Germany).

webTitle: Obituary: Brian Walsh

fields.headline: Brian Walsh
fields.standfirst:
Leeds QC who tackled high-profile cases - and the divisions within Yorkshire cricket
Cricket Unlimited
fields.trailText: Judge Brian Walsh QC, more than most, should have written his own obituary, as an exceptionally witty counsel who could also ambush court opponents with biting polemic.
fields.body:
Judge Brian Walsh QC, more than most, should have written his own obituary, as an exceptionally witty counsel who could also ambush court opponents with biting polemic. He would have mocked himself elegantly for a penchant for dramatic, high-profile cases, and especially for attempting the impossible: sorting out the corrosive divisions inside Yorkshire county cricket club.

Walsh, who has died of cancer aged 65, was the best-known figure on England's north-eastern circuit, and was appointed to the ancient ceremonial title of Recorder of Leeds four years ago. He was almost as well-known in northern cricketing circles after serving as chairman of Yorkshire CCC from 1986 to 1991, a period when arguments raged around Geoffrey Boycott and other strong-minded figures in the club.

His prominent briefs included defending Jon Venables, one of the two boys convicted of killing three-year-old James Bulger in 1993. He was also involved in the trial of miners after the "Battle of Orgreave" in the 1984-85 coalfield strike and in the Cleveland inquiry into claims of widespread child abuse.

Walsh earned a name for defending judicial and barristers' independence, attacking proposed changes in 1989 as threatening a state monopoly licensing system. He was also a regular scourge of inefficiency and legal delay, publicly berating police three times in a week in 1997 for deficiencies in bail arrangements.

Walsh came from a Leeds legal family, as the son of a local solicitor, and showed obvious promise at school. After a brief spell at college in Srinagar, India, because of his father's work, he became head boy of Leeds grammar school and in 1959 president of Cambridge university union.

National service as a pilot officer in RAF fighter command gave him another perspective, and his steady climb up the legal ladder was accompanied by campaigning, civic work.

As a Liberal, he polled respectably in the South Leeds byelection caused by the death in 1963 of the then Labour leader Hugh Gaitskell; he was also a strong supporter of the city's Jewish community, chairing the local campaign for Soviet Jewry during the worst years of communist persecution.

After appointment as a QC in 1977, he spent a decade heading Leeds chambers with another regular counsel in controversial cases, Gilbert Gray QC, before becoming leader of the north-eastern circuit and then, in 1996, a circuit judge. He served the profession nationally as a member of the General Council of the Bar from 1982-86 and 1990-96.

Walsh was in demand as an after-dinner speaker, where he showed the same timing that made his inquisition of evasive witnesses particularly deadly.

He leaves his wife Susan and two daughters, one of whom is a solicitor.

webTitle: Workplace blues leave employers in the red

fields.headline: Workplace blues leave employers in the red
fields.standfirst: A dramatic increase in stress levels has led to spiralling anxiety, burnout and depression across the globe, the UN's labour arm warns
fields.trailText: The workers of the world are, according to a United Nations report, united in just one thing these days: record levels of stress.
fields.body:
The workers of the world are, according to a United Nations report, united in just one thing these days: record levels of stress.

What is more, the report warns, anxiety levels are set to dramatically increase in the coming years as globalisation continues its relentless march, and the economic costs for business will be massive.

In a landmark survey examining stress in the workplace in five countries, the UN's International Labour Organisation (ILO) found that levels of anxiety, burnout and depression are spiralling out of control.

The problem is costing employers billions of pounds in sick leave and lost working time, and often leaves frayed employees grappling with a series of complex mental disorders for years afterwards.

The study focused on the problems of stress and mental illness at work in the UK, the United States, Germany, Finland and Poland.

It found that despair at work is a growing problem in all five countries, with as many as one in 10 workers affected.

Depression in the workplace is the second most disabling illness for workers after heart disease, the report warns, and is set to grow dramatically as new technologies multiply.

Downsizing, layoffs, mergers, short-term contracts and higher productivity demands have all exacted their toll in the last 10 years, leaving many workers frazzled and on the verge of a nervous breakdown.

"Workers worldwide confront, as never before, an array of new organisational structures and processes which can affect their mental health," the report says.

In the UK as many as three in 10 employees experience mental health problems and at any given time one in 20 Britons is fighting off "major depression".

"The self-reported occurrence of anxiety and depression [in the UK] ranges from 15 to 30% of the working population," the report says.

The reasons for this are twofold: people find it hard to adapt to new technology and cannot keep up with constantly changing working practices.

In the UK, these higher stress levels are estimated to be responsible for the loss of 80m working days a year. In financial terms, that leaves the country seriously out of pocket - to the tune of £5.3bn annually, according to the Confederation of British Industry.

The NHS is also bearing the brunt of the wave of work-related anxiety. Some 14% of inpatient costs and almost a quarter of its annual bill for drugs and medication are swallowed up by stressed out, sometimes mentally ill, office workers.

"These trends represent a wake-up call for business," the ILO says. "For employers, the costs are felt in terms of low productivity, reduced profits, high rates of staff turnover and increased costs of recruiting and training replacement staff."

In the US the picture is equally bleak. One in 10 workers suffers from clinical depression and the problem is getting worse. Some 200m working days are lost every year because of stress, and the cost of treating anxiety-ridden workers tops £30bn annually. Some 40% of workers complain that their job is very, or extremely, stressful.

Unrealistic deadlines, poor management and inadequate childcare arrangements are to blame, the ILO says.

As much as 4% of the 15-country European Union's gross national product is ploughed into treating the stressed and mentally ill.

But it is in Finland that work-related stress seems to have reached epidemic proportions. More than half of the workforce in this nordic country is blighted with some kind of stress-related symptom, and 7% of Finnish workers are "severely burnt out".

Worn out, increasingly cynical and suffering from insomnia, the average Finnish worker's performance is badly impaired and the country's suicide rates are high.

In Germany, 7% of workers opt for early retirement because they are stressed and depressed, the report says, and Poland's workforce is increasingly prone to anxiety as joblessness soars in the wake of the collapse of communism.

People who have time off because of nervous breakdowns are often stigmatised, and find it hard to pick up where they left off.

The World Federation for Mental Health this week warned that by 2020, stress and mental disorders will overtake road accidents, Aids and violence as the primary cause of lost working time.

Taking its toll

UK: Three in 10 workers have mental health problems and one in 20 suffers from major depression. Stress accounts for 14% of sickness leave and 80m lost working days each year. The annual cost of productivity lost due to stress is £5.3bn

US: One in 10 workers suffers from clinical depression, with 200m lost working days a year and a bill for treatment and lost earnings/working time of £30bn

Finland: More than half of the workforce is blighted with stress-related symptoms, 7% are "severely burnt out" and the country suffers from a high suicide rate

Germany: Almost 7% of early retirements are caused by depression. The number of working days lost annually is 2.3m and the annual cost of productivity loss due to stress-related absenteeism is £1.5bn

Poland: Anxiety caused by soaring joblessness increased by 50% last year, while post-communist economic restructuring saw the country's suicide rate rise from 13.9 to 14.9 per 100,000 population

webTitle: Genetic tests to be used in setting premiums

fields.headline: Genetic tests to be used in setting premiums
fields.standfirst: Jessica McCallin on the government's decision to allow insurance companies to set premium levels based on hereditary disease risks
fields.trailText: Jessica McCallin on the government's decision to allow insurance companies to set premium levels based on hereditary disease risks.
fields.body:
The government is tomorrow expected to confirm the reliability of tests for the hereditary disease Huntingdon's and give insurers the go-ahead to use the results when setting premium levels for sufferers.

This will be the first ruling of the Genetics and Insurance Committee, set up in April 1999, and will pave the way for other genetic tests to be approved.

At present, the insurance industry does not ask people to take genetic tests as a condition for cover, but its code of practice states it may use the results of tests for seven diseases, including Huntingdon's, Alzheimers and breast cancer, providing they were carried out prior to the person applying for insurance.

The GAIC's approval of the test would mark an endorsement of the insurance industry's approach, but is likely to fuel controversy surrounding the issue, with opponents claiming people with a hereditary genetic condition will be penalised through higher premiums. Huntingdon sufferers pay two or three times as much for insurance.

The disease affects an estimated one in 20,000 people. Future rulings on more widespread diseases, such as breast cancer, will have a much wider impact if the GAIC says insurers can use test information.

Most insurers charge higher premiums for genetic pre-dispositions, but some refuse to extend cover if they decide a person is too much of a risk. Alternatively, they may decide to offer cover but only if the insurance policy is modified to fit a person's circumstances. For example, a 30 year old Huntingdon's sufferer may be offered a 10 year life insurance policy if his father didn't start developing signs of the disease until his 40's.

If, against expectations, the GAIC rules the test for Huntingdon's is not reliable enough for insurance purposes, the Association of British Insurers said it will instruct its members to stop using the test and refund excess premiums.

webTitle: Classical review: Rattle

fields.headline: Rattle
fields.standfirst:
BCMG/Rattle ****
Barbican, London
fields.trailText:
BCMG/Rattle ****
Barbican, London
fields.body:
Colin Matthews's Continuum, for mezzo-soprano and 23-instrument ensemble, given its world premiere by Cynthia Clarey with the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group and Simon Rattle, is a fecund vision of musical continuity. The work's structure is striking. Two settings of poems by the Italian Eugenio Montale, and two epigrams by Rainer Maria Rilke, are disrupted and fused by instrumental sections in a continuous, 45-minute span of music.

Both of Montale's poems - Chrysalis, set in Italian, and House by the Sea, set in English - meditate upon images of death and decay. In Chrysalis, Matthews creates a kaleidoscope of skirling rhythmic impetus. Yet the momentum is contained and the setting never arrives anywhere, for all the energetic motion. Mirroring Montale's poetic ambiguity, the result of Matthews's music is an ineluctable build-up of pressure.

It's the instrumental interlude between Chrysalis and the slower, more expressive setting of House by the Sea that finally dissipates this tension. In the latter, Cynthia Clarey's lines have a more conventional contour of tension and release. Yet just as in the first setting, the ending of House by the Sea - along with the second Rilke aphorism - represents a journey without end. Accompanied by a pre-recorded ghost of the work's opening, Continuum concludes with a sonority derived from the first gesture of the piece: Rilke's "everything becomes distant", Clarey 's first words in Continuum, have become a "distant song" by the end. Rattle and the BCMG gave Continuum an apparently definitive performance, balancing the beauty and expressiveness of Matthews's soundworld.

Hans Krasa's 1923 Symphony for Small Orchestra received its UK premiere at the beginning of the programme. Like a distillation of Mahler, combined with the limpid influence of his French contemporaries, this is a unique musical synthesis thatdeserves more exposure. Before Continuum, Pierre-Laurent Aimard joined the BCMG in Ligeti's Piano Concerto, and revealed the range of the composer's imagination: from comic, joyous abandon to gallows humour.

webTitle: Opera review: La Bohème

fields.headline: A fresh-faced Puccini
fields.standfirst:
La Bohème
Glyndebourne *****
fields.trailText:
La Bohème
Glyndebourne *****
fields.body:
Glyndebourne Touring Opera's new season starts with a new production. The next 10 days will see a revival of the Don Giovanni first seen at this summer's festival, and the British premiere of Birtwistle's The Last Supper, in the production that opened in Berlin in April, but David McVicar's staging of La Bohème, conducted by GTO's new music director, Louis Langree, provides the best possible, most invigorating start to the tour.

La Bohème is an opera about young people, and for once it is cast with young singers, whose exuberance makes the tragedy of the last act even more affecting. Through Michael Vale's ingenious sets and Mikki Engelsbel's costumes the action is updated from Paris in the 1830s to present-day London. Rodolfo and his friends live in a squalid flat (just one rung up the social ladder, you sense, from homelessness), but the problems that usually go with updatings - details that don't fit, issues that have to be fudged - are solved triumphantly. In the first act Rodolfo fuses the lights in the flat to produce the darkness that has Mimi trying to light a candle, while the Cafe Momus becomes a glitzy bar, complete with flouncing waiters, silly Christmas hats, street performers and a throng of Christmas shoppers. In the third act the city gates of the original become the shuttered entrance to a tube station, and Marcello is painting a mural for the seedy club next door, while the Bohemians, back together in their flat for the final scene, snort cocaine (except for Rodolfo) just before the dying Mimi appears.

If all this were cosmetic it would mean very little. But McVicar has obtained performances of such telling detail from every member of the cast that the whole drama becomes utterly credible. The way in which Rodolfo (a supremely intelligent performance from Alfred Boe) charts his falling-in-love with Mimi (the touching Simona Todaro) through both his body language and his singing is compelling. This is a man, wimpish and hopeless in many respects, who can't believe what he is experiencing, who realises his whole life is about to be transformed by this encounter. This is in total contrast to the worldly-wise attitude of Marcello (the commanding Luca Grassi) towards his tempestuous affair with the flighty Musetta (Claron MacFadden, visually and vocally spectacular). When at the end of the third act Rudolfo and Mimi agree to stay together at least until the spring, the way in which they leave, he uncertainly a few paces behind, says more about the fragility of their relationship than any of their declarations.

Only one detail is puzzling. When Mimi makes her first timid approach to the door of Rodolfo's flat we see Musetta in the darkness, urging her forward, as if the two women are close friends - unlikely given their very different personalities, one would have thought, unless Mimi's history differs from the version she gives to Rodolfo. That one cares about these few seconds of the production is an indication of how thoughtful the show is and how completely it draws the audience into its world and its characters, and how they are brought so convincingly to life by every member of the cast. The contributions of Nicolas Teste (Colline), Riccardo Novaro (Schaunard) and Eric Roberts (Benoit and Alcindoro) are as significant as those of the principals.

Langree's conducting is vital too. He makes Puccini's so familiar score seem fresh and newly extraordinary; he does not overlook a single detail, and the orchestral playing makes all of them tell. The whole performance, in fact, has no weak links.

Until October 26. Box office: 01273 813813. Then touring to Woking, Norwich, Milton Keynes, Plymouth, Oxford and Stoke-on-Trent.

In the third act the city gates of the original become the shuttered entrance to a tube station, and Marcello is painting a mural for the seedy club next door, while the Bohemians, back together in their flat for the final scene, snort cocaine (except for Rodolfo) just before the dying Mimi appears. If all this were cosmetic it would mean very little. But McVicar has obtained performances of such telling detail from every member of the cast that the whole drama becomes utterly credible. The way in which Rodolfo (a supremely intelligent performance from Alfred Boe) charts his falling-in-love with Mimi (the touching Simona Todaro) through both his body language and his singing is compelling. This is a man, wimpish and hopeless in many respects, who can't believe what he is experiencing, who realises his whole life is about to be transformed by this encounter. This is in total contrast to the worldly-wise attitude of Marcello (the commanding Luca Grassi) towards his tempestuous affair with the flighty Musetta (Claron MacFadden, visually and vocally spectacular). When at the end of the third act Rudolfo and Mimi agree to stay together at least until the spring, the way in which they leave, he uncertainly a few paces behind, says more about the fragility of their relationship than any of their declarations. Only one detail is puzzling. When Mimi makes her first timid approach to the door of Rodolfo's flat we see Musetta in the darkness, urging her forward, as if the two women are close friends - unlikely given their very different personalities, one would have thought, unless Mimi's history differs from the version she gives to Rodolfo. That one cares about these few seconds of the production is an indication of how thoughtful the show is and how completely it draws the audience into its world and its characters, and how they are brought so convincingly to life by every member of the cast. The contributions of Nicolas Teste (Colline), Riccardo Novaro (Schaunard) and Eric Roberts (Benoit and Alcindoro) are as significant as those of the principals. Langree's conducting is vital too. He makes Puccini's so familiar score seem fresh and newly extraordinary; he does not overlook a single detail, and the orchestral playing makes all of them tell. The whole performance, in fact, has no weak links. Until October 26. Box office: 01273 813813. Then touring to Woking, Norwich, Milton Keynes, Plymouth, Oxford and Stoke-on-Trent.

webTitle: Pop review: Britney Spears

fields.headline: Pop's answer to Ann Widdecombe
fields.standfirst:
Britney Spears
Wembley Arena **
fields.trailText:
Britney Spears
Wembley Arena **
fields.body:
Three days after the last football international at the old stadium, the hawkers on Wembley Way struck up a different chant: "Get yer furry headbands and lightsticks!" The touts were more plaintive, willing to offload £25 tickets at face value: the first hint of a craze running its course.

The occasion was the appearance of Britney Spears, the 18-year-old American singer, at the start of her European tour. She is best known to most people older than her for being a virgin.

The most surprising person present was Alastair Campbell, PR supremo of a government anxious to promote virginity. The last connection between the government and this tatty venue was Tony Blair's speech to the Women's Institute. Mr Campbell was there as dutiful father to his six-year-old, Grace. Nonetheless, his presence did make the mind boggle, as did so much else.

Campbell was at the top end of the audience's age range; Grace near the bottom. Most were girls aged about 11 to 16, who spent most of the evening screaming. Perhaps a quarter of those present were male, some of them apparently there in a spirit of postmodern irony, of the sort that makes Rolf Harris popular at Glastonbury.

I don't think many had designs on Ms Spears's virginity. Her performance was energetic and gyratory and focused on her body. It was at once obsessively sexual yet strangely sexless, like an aerobics class or a speech by Ann Widdecombe.

In 1963 the Guardian sent one of its senior writers to the Cavern Club to report on the Beatles. He reported as from a very foreign country. One is terrified of falling into the same trap and missing the zeitgeist of the new century, but this does take some figuring out. What we have here is the 1960s in reverse: young girls screaming in delight not at rebellious young men but at one of their own.

Old pop stars represented the unattainable glamour of sex, drugs and rock'n'roll. Maybe modern kids get so much of all that before they leave primary school that they seek the reverse. More likely, Ms Spears is a role model, an idealised version of themselves. She has everything a teenage girl thinks she wants: fame; money; lovely hair, skin and teeth; plus a super-spangly pink bra top. She is female empowerment personified, strutting purposefully while the men in her act (and maybe her life) just dance attendance. She is 21st-century Cinderella at the ball.

Indeed, the special effects, the sets, the costumes and the audience participation were rather panto-like. The loudest applause of the night was probably for Joe from Essex, who won the chance to meet Britney after he went on stage and walked like a chicken.

Don't get me wrong: the audience loved her too. But there was a curious moment near the end when she broke away from the musical mush that has made her famous, sat on a crimson throne and launched into Satisfaction. Many of the girls sat back, baffled, as well they might. In these circumstances, the psycho-sexual implications were terrifying.

Ms Spears won them back with the finale, her schoolgirl anthem, Hit Me Baby One More Time. Her voice, whenever it was heard over the backing tracks, was raspy, her tunes unmemorable. There is a long tradition of female vocalists producing works of passion from the depths of their experience. Torch songs, we call them. What do you call songs produced from no experience whatever? Lightstick songs, perhaps.

Britney Spears is at Wembley Arena (020-8902 0902), tonight, then tours.

webTitle: Dance review: Merce Cunningham

fields.headline: Merce Cunningham's digital dance
fields.standfirst:
Merce Cunningham
Barbican, London *****
fields.trailText:
Merce Cunningham

Barbican, London *****
fields.body:
As a choreographer, one of Merce Cunningham's most extraordinary projects has been to reinvent the stage. Rather than placing his dancers in regular patterns, with the focus centre stage, he makes his choreography appear like a random visual field. Different dance activities may be happening simultaneously across the stage, while the number of performers grows and shrinks with a rhythm impossible to predict. Watching a Cunningham dance is like watching real life throwing up images and patterns out of apparent chaos.

So it's not surprising that in Biped, Cunningham's first voyage into digital dance (a live performance into which computerised moving images have been projected) we're treated to monumental and magical spatial illusions. As one woman dances alone, bars of coloured light track across a transparent scrim in front of her. The spaces between the bars widen, creating a dizzying sense of the whole stage expanding. Then they contract and disappear and the dancer's body suddenly looks more dense - a concentration of atoms posed in crystalline light.

The height of these vertical bars gives a vaulting grandeur to the stage that is vividly subverted when the digital images are animated into chatty bubbles of light or swirling formations. Frequently the images take human form and spin through the real dancers. At times they are giants, bending over the sweating humans, then they are pygmies skittering between them. Most enchantingly, they blur into feathery movement trails, which seem like ghosts or maybe muscle memories of the dancers inscribed in light.

While the animated images dance, so do the humans. Biped is set to music by Gavin Bryars, in which drones and melodies are densely layered, and the dancers similarly cluster into unison groupings from which individuals randomly detach. The choreography is angular with occasional fierce outbursts of speed, yet there's a peculiar tenderness to it. One recurrent motif is a raised arm that looks like a gesture of appeal; it's a signal that binds the dancers together. They seem like a tribe apart, a futuristic family in a palace of electronic grandeur.

Biped is an awesome project, though purists may find its richness disconcerting when viewed next to Cunningham's 1958 classic Summerspace. This beautiful piece relies simply on the poetics of dance - its infinitely detailed moves not only laying out the resources of the moving body but also making us think of birds flocking, lovers courting or insects droning.

The pleasure of Cunningham's choreography is the way it distils his unique angle on the world. It may just be people moving yet it captures the sensibility of a New Yorker looking at nature, a visual artist with an athlete's genius, a zen poet with a practical bent.

Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Circle

fields.headline: The Circle
fields.standfirst:
The Circle
Salisbury Playhouse ****
fields.trailText:
The Circle
Salisbury Playhouse ****
fields.body:
The boys from London's Bush theatre recently advocated a ban on the classics. In fact, we need to profit from the past, as Joan Littlewood realised when she told the rawly talented Shelagh Delaney to "read Ibsen". And I can think of a few dramatists who might learn how to harmonise plot and character from studying Somerset Maugham's The Circle, immaculately revived by Mark Rosenblatt in a joint production from Oxford Stage Company and Salisbury Playhouse.

The danger is that this kind of play, written in 1919, elicits a stock response. It boasts French windows, a stately drawing room, Georgian furniture: all the things young dramatists have fought against. Study the play closely, however, and you see that Maugham is offering a waspish portrait of upper-class manners.

The hero, Arnold Champion-Cheney, is a priggish MP whose mother abandoned him when he was five to run off with a rising politician. Now the fugitive Lady Kitty returns with her old lover. A comically ridiculous pair, she turns out to be a berouged scatterbrain and he a ratty exile forever cursing his lost opportunities. The question Maugham poses is whether history will repeat itself when Arnold's wife threatens to abscond with an impecunious rubber planter.

Seeing the play soon after Barrie's Dear Brutus prompts some fascinating comparisons. Barrie is always dubbed a sentimentalist, Maugham a cynic. Yet both playwrights argue that character is more important than destiny. At the end of The Circle, Lady Kitty's old lover forcefully says that their young counterparts may succeed where they failed because their personalities are different. It gives a tart comedy a romantic ambivalence; it also suggests that both Maugham and Barrie, shadowed by the first world war, were mounting pleas for individual temperament at a time when fate seemed cruelly implacable.

Classic plays, in short, are revealing social documents. Maugham's is also structured with impeccable logic and far subtler than it at first seems, a point grasped by Rosenblatt's fantastically bright production. Characters are played from their own point of view rather than other people's. Dale Rapley makes the deceived MP not just a stuffed shirt but a man suffering a lifelong emotional wound, as shown by his heartrending cry of, "We've had enough divorces in our family." Jonathan Newth as his cuckolded father also implies that his own cynical irony is a defence against further hurt. And, even if Lois Baxter is a bit too youthfully vivacious as the raddled Lady Kitty, Trevor Baxter is hilarious as her harrumphing, ill-tempered partner. It's an excellent evening that not only makes the case for Maugham, but also proves that, far from banning the classics, we should overcome our prejudices and widen the area of choice.

Until October 21. Box office: 01722 320333. Then touring to Exeter, Warwick, Barnstaple, Bury St Edmunds and Windsor.

webTitle: Wales face a fraught night

fields.headline: Wales face a fraught night
fields.trailText: After police had to fire rubber bullets over the heads of rioting Poland fans in Lodz on Saturday, Mark Hughes can expect the most intimidating game of his brief coaching career at the Legia Warsaw stadium tonight.
fields.body:
Wales face a night of fear here this evening in their World Cup qualifier against the Group Five leaders Poland and their battle-scarred manager Mark Hughes can expect the most intimidating night of his brief coaching career.

The Polish FA is playing down fears of hooliganism at the Legia Warsaw stadium after police had to fire rubber bullets over the heads of rioting fans in Lodz on Saturday to break up fights after Poland's 3-1 victory over Belarus.

Polish insiders claim Saturday's trouble was between two sets of local fans. They do not expect violence tomorrow but Hughes and his team have no doubts that as they try to stop the hosts winning their third straight group match there will be fierce intimidation by the partisan Poles.

Hughes, however, has happy memories of his last visit to the stadium, when he scored one of Manchester United's goals in their 1991 European Cup Winners' Cup semi-final victory over Legia Warsaw.

"Polish grounds are very intimidating," said Hughes. "But I used to enjoy that type of game, the more abuse the better. Hostile environments should inspire you."

The midfielder Robbie Savage recently played through the rockets and flares that disfigured Leicester's Uefa Cup match with Red Star Belgrade. He said: "It's going to be intimidating but I can handle that. I doubt it will be any worse here ."

"We got one point on Saturday and we need that at least out here," said Hughes. "Tactically this is very different to Norway, who had a very set way of playing. The Poles have some nice, bright players who move the ball all over the field."

Nathan Blake, whose fine header gave Wales their point in Cardiff, is a major doubt due to a thigh strain.

Wales (probable)

webTitle: Under-21  round-up

fields.headline: Under-21  round-up
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland convincingly defeated Iceland 5-2 yesterday, bouncing back from a 3-0 home defeat by Denmark last Friday, to continue to show the value of introducing an Under-21 team.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland convincingly defeated Iceland 5-2 yesterday, bouncing back from a 3-0 home defeat by Denmark last Friday, to continue to show the value of introducing an Under-21 team.

The Irish were two goals up after 11 minutes, Sean Friars of Ipswich adding to the Blackburn Rovers player Gary Hamilton's sixth-minute opener. Maurice Harkin, of Second Division Wycombe scored either side of half-time, with West Ham's Grant McCann scoring after 77 minutes to add lustre to an impressive performance, which was slightly spoiled by two late Icelandic goals and the sending off of Wayne Carlisle for deliberate hand ball.

The former national manager Bryan Hamilton was instrumental in setting up the side in 1998 and although no impression was made in the 2000 European Championship, the side has now won two of its first three games in their qualifying group for the 2002 tournament.

By contrast, both Scotland and Wales lost games in which they had taken the lead.

The Welsh, who have not had a victory for 17 games over a three-year period, led their Polish hosts 1-0 at half-time, James Thomas of Blackburn Rovers scoring. However, after conceding a 66th-minute equaliser, they contrived to let in a last-minute goal for their third consecutive defeat in this tournament.

Jimmy Shoulder, the manager of the side was angry that Wales could not sustain their best play for 90 minutes.

"On Friday in Swansea we played some of the best football I have seen from a Wales Under-21 side, for an hour against Norway. We did that again for 20 minutes here, but that's not enough to win a match," said Shoulder. The Welsh are bottom of their group, without a point from three matches.

Scotland, who had won their first match in Latvia, led Croatia after the Manchester United player Alex Notman converted a 36th-minute penalty. However, Mikael Mikic equalised three minutes later, to undo the good work of the Scots. Davica Olic scored to put Croatia ahead, before Mikic scored a second to seal victory.

"I was disappointed for us to lose this game," said Scotland's coach Alex Smith, "but Croatia deserved to win. Unfortunately for us when we did score the first goal we didn't hold that lead long enough."

webTitle: Smith off to blot his copybook

fields.headline: Smith off to blot his copybook
fields.standfirst: Sjolund 15, 76 | Dunn 31, Smith 48
fields.trailText: Leeds United striker Alan Smith reverted to type last night when he was sent off for violent conduct after scoring what might have been the winner in Valkeakoski.
fields.body:
The Leeds United striker Alan Smith has been called a "reformed character" by David O'Leary of late after pledging to repair his reputation as "a thug" on the field, in the words of his own club manager.

Yesterday, however, he reverted to type when after scoring what might have been the winner for the England Under-21 side in their European Championship qualifier in Valkeakoski, a burst of petulence saw him sent off for violent conduct.

Smith's goal was a spectacular strike at the start of the second half but with 15 minutes left he pressed the self-destruct button by lashing out after being fouled by a Finnish defender. It was another moment of indiscipline from a player who only last month was called into the senior squad by Kevin Keegan for the friendly international in France.

England, who had been held to a draw by a late Germany goal on Friday at Derby, paid dearly for Smith's action when, down to 10 men, they allowed Finland to snatch an equaliser when Daniel Sjolund was on target with his second goal of the game within a minute of the dismissal.

England had played the more purposeful football for long periods, particularly in the second half and Smith himself was a major influence until his premature departure. But having taken only two points from their opening two qualifying games they now face an uphill struggle if they are to emulate the achievement of the 1998 and 2000 teams by reaching the European Championship finals in 2002.

There were plenty of plus points with the likes of Michael Carrick and David Dunn impressing in midfield, but England have work to do at the back, although Clarke Carlisle looked steadier than Titus Bramble, who was taken off at the interval by the stand-in coach Sammy Lee.

England made most of the early running. Darius Vassell was only a foot wide with a snapshot from 12 yards and Finland's goalkeeper Otto Fredrikson then did well to tip over a dipping 25-yard effort from David Prutton, who was making his full debut.

But Finland had already shown they were a threat on the counter-attack and after 15 minutes Sjolund put them ahead when he turned inside John Terry before beating Paul Robinson with a deflected shot.

England weathered the setback and after 31 minutes Dunn put them level. Bramble, who had scored England's goal in Friday's draw with Germany, was this time the provider as he threaded the ball into his captain's path.

Smith's goal came via a spectacular overhead kick off the underside of the bar after a right-wing cross from Lee Roche. However all his good work went to waste when Sjolund shot past Robinson from close range after being played through by Tero Karhu.

Finland Under-21: Fredrikson, Heilala, Aho, Pasanen, Timoska, Nordback, Karhu, Vayrynen, Roita, Tainio, Sjolund.

England Under-21: Robinson, Roche, Bramble (Carlisle, h-t), Terry, A Cole, Dunn (Parker, 90min), Carrick, Prutton, Greening, Vassell (Christie, 87), A Smith.

fields.bodyText: The Leeds United striker Alan Smith has been called a "reformed character" by David O'Leary of late after pledging to repair his reputation as "a thug" on the field, in the words of his own club manager. Yesterday, however, he reverted to type when after scoring what might have been the winner for the England Under-21 side in their European Championship qualifier in Valkeakoski, a burst of petulence saw him sent off for violent conduct. Smith's goal was a spectacular strike at the start of the second half but with 15 minutes left he pressed the self-destruct button by lashing out after being fouled by a Finnish defender. It was another moment of indiscipline from a player who only last month was called into the senior squad by Kevin Keegan for the friendly international in France. England, who had been held to a draw by a late Germany goal on Friday at Derby, paid dearly for Smith's action when, down to 10 men, they allowed Finland to snatch an equaliser when Daniel Sjolund was on target with his second goal of the game within a minute of the dismissal. England had played the more purposeful football for long periods, particularly in the second half and Smith himself was a major influence until his premature departure. But having taken only two points from their opening two qualifying games they now face an uphill struggle if they are to emulate the achievement of the 1998 and 2000 teams by reaching the European Championship finals in 2002. There were plenty of plus points with the likes of Michael Carrick and David Dunn impressing in midfield, but England have work to do at the back, although Clarke Carlisle looked steadier than Titus Bramble, who was taken off at the interval by the stand-in coach Sammy Lee. England made most of the early running. Darius Vassell was only a foot wide with a snapshot from 12 yards and Finland's goalkeeper Otto Fredrikson then did well to tip over a dipping 25-yard effort from David Prutton, who was making his full debut. But Finland had already shown they were a threat on the counter-attack and after 15 minutes Sjolund put them ahead when he turned inside John Terry before beating Paul Robinson with a deflected shot. England weathered the setback and after 31 minutes Dunn put them level. Bramble, who had scored England's goal in Friday's draw with Germany, was this time the provider as he threaded the ball into his captain's path. Smith's goal came via a spectacular overhead kick off the underside of the bar after a right-wing cross from Lee Roche. However all his good work went to waste when Sjolund shot past Robinson from close range after being played through by Tero Karhu. webTitle: Finns taking the mickey

fields.headline: Finns taking the mickey
fields.standfirst: England go for broke
fields.trailText: Finland fans firmly believe that the most impressive squad in their history will win tonight and the local press have been riding the mood of optimism by taking random pot-shots at England.
fields.body:
If England think they have been getting a bad press back home it is probably just as well that they do not have any Finnish speakers in the camp, since they have been receiving far worse treatment here.

Iltalehti, the country's second biggest evening newspaper, led the way by pretending to celebrate Tony Adams's 34th birthday yesterday, offering what it considered the most appropriate present; a rocking chair and a few cans of beer. This ignored the facts that the injured Adams will play no part here tonight, having not even travelled with the squad, and that he has been a recovering alcoholic for some years.

The Finns clearly believe that it is good to kick a man while he is down, reflecting the genuine mood of anticipation here that there could not be a better time to beat a deflated England team.

Martti Kuusela, who was Finland's manager when they earned a 1-1 draw against Bobby Robson's England in 1985 (the Finns still insist Mark Hateley's goal for England was offside), says: "We will not lose this game." And most Finland fans believe their team can do much better than that, gaining a victory that would revive their hopes of World Cup qualification while virtually destroying England's.

The optimism is not just a result of England's defeat by Germany at Wembley and the disarray that has followed the resignation of Kevin Keegan, but because they have the most impressive squad in their history.

It is also, for the first time, a fully professional squad, with only three of the 18-man squad playing in their home country. The rest form a diaspora across the European leagues, six of them playing in England, four in Norway and two in Holland.

The most serious threat up front is likely to come from Jonatan Johansson, who has made such an impressive start to his Premiership career with Charlton. He and Liverpool's Sami Hyypia are the leading stars of the Finland team, though Mikael Forssell, 19, who gained Premiership experience with Chelsea last season before being loaned to Crystal Palace, is regarded as Finland's Michael Owen.

Although Jari Litmanen, 29, has become a peripheral figure at Barcelona after moving to Catalonia from Ajax, he is a mobile, inventive player in midfield whom England will underestimate to their cost.

Jarkko Wiss of Stockport County, the reserve goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen of Bolton Wanderers and Derby's Simo Valacari are the others with knowledge of the English game.

Though the Finns are encouraged by the absence of David Beckham and Adams, the manager Antti Muurinen's main concern is the scoring potential of Paul Scholes. Muurinen welcomes back the defender Janne Saarinen after suspension.

 By late last night, Finnish border officials had barred entry to at least eight fans at Helsinki airport, mainly because they had criminal records.

Finland (probable): Niemi; Reini, Hyypia, Tihinen, Saarinen; Nurmela, Valacari, Wiss, Litmanen; Forssell, Johansson.

webTitle: Praise wasted as Brown studies injury options

fields.headline: Praise wasted as Brown studies injury options
fields.trailText: Croatia manager Miroslav Blazevic attempted to turn what had seemed a straightforward fixture for the home team into a stroll in a Balkan park for the Scots when he showered Craig Brown's injury-depleted squad with praise yesterday.
fields.body:
Scotland are not used to having compliments showered upon them as a footballing nation but yesterday Miroslav Blazevic, the manager of Croatia, obliged with a stupefying outpouring of praise.

The Scots face Croatia here tonight in a Group Six qualifying tie which, until Blazevic opened his mouth, had seemed a straightforward fixture for the home team. The thought of Robert Prosinecki, Alen Boksic and Davor Suker (if he plays) knocking at the knees at the prospect of meeting Craig Brown's injury-depleted squad has always seemed absurd. Not, however, according to Blazevic yesterday.

"They [Scotland] have more journalists covering them, more fans following them and they are specialists in qualifying matches," he said. "They are a team with great spirit. They are capable of achieving anything."

With wry humour, the Scots have indeed always felt they were capable of achieving anything, but not as this Croat meant it.

Brown's team are currently sitting pretty with six points from two matches, and victory tonight would only confirm that the Scotland manager, who has outlasted every other European coach except Luxembourg's Paul Philipp, has more Teflon qualities than anyone in the game. Time and again a minor tabloid rumpus with an old girlfriend or some other daft incident is visited upon him; one month later he always comes up smiling, sometimes clutching three points.

Tonight Brown will be without five key players - including Barry Ferguson and Paul Lambert, the bedrock of his midfield - and there is a chance he will offer a starting berth to Manchester City's Paul Dickov. The other option would be to pair Don Hutchison in attack with Kevin Gallacher, from whom the genial Brown took a verbal blast after the Newcastle forward's substitution on the occasion of his 50th cap on Saturday against San Marino.

"I'm not aware of any problem with Kevin; if there is one I don't know about it," Brown said yesterday. "The only thing I know is that you pick your best team and not one based on sentiment. I make a value judgment about a player. If I get it right, I'm right. If I get it wrong, I'm depicted as a tube."

Croatia, having drawn with Belgium last month, are not expected to play Suker from the start, the West Ham attacker not having appeared since playing against Sunderland on September 5.

With no other group match being played, whatever happens tonight the Scots will remain imperiously atop their section.

 Lithuania, bottom of Group Eight, sacked their coach Stasys Stankus on the eve of tonight's home match against Hungary in Kaunus. It followed their 4-0 defeat in Georgia on Saturday.

Croatia (probable, 3-5-2)
Pavlovic; R Kovac, Stimac, Simic; Zivkovic, Biscan, Prosinecki, N Kovac, Jarni; Boksic, Balaban.

Scotland (probable, 3-5-2)

Referee: G Veissiere (France).

webTitle: Ireland wary of minnows

fields.headline: Ireland wary of minnows
fields.trailText: After a promising start to their World Cup qualifying campaign, the Republic of Ireland face a potential banana skin tonight in the form of Estonia.
fields.body:
Having reeled in a couple of big fish, the Republic of Ireland must build upon the promising start to their World Cup qualifiers tonight by preventing one of the minnows from getting through their net.

The feel-good factor generated by holding Holland and Portugal to away draws will disappear quicker than a pint of the murky stuff in Temple Bar should they fail to overcome Estonia at Lansdowne Road.

If the Irish need reminding of the number of potholes still impeding the route to Japan and South Korea, it should be provided by the damage done by Macedonia to their qualifying campaigns for Euro 2000 and France '98. Tonight is a banana skin they dare not slip up on.

"If we mess up here, everything we have achieved so far will mean next to nothing," their manager Mick McCarthy said yesterday. "Our results against Estonia, Cyprus and Andorra will be vital. It's an absolute must that we beat them all home and away because I'm convinced Holland and Portugal will."

Such a scenario would set things up nicely for when the two Euro 2000 semi-finalists visit Dublin next year, but first things first. McCarthy will field the same team for the third successive match, against a physical, aerial side who have won two of their opening three games and were unfortunate to lose against Portugal last month. "They had a lot of chances and the 3-1 scoreline flattered Portugal," said McCarthy. "That should be a warning to us."

Unfortunately for McCarthy his videos of the early Group Two pacesetters went missing along with the rest of his luggage on the way back from Lisbon on Sunday. "They have managed to track it down at last, but it's had to go through Heathrow before I get it back."

A football manager without baggage; how the English FA would love someone like that.

Holland, meanwhile, suffered a double setback when the Rangers pair Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Ronald de Boer were ruled out of tonight's clash with Portugal. De Boer has a knee injury and Van Bronckhorst has been struggling with a painful groin.

The Holland coach Louis van Gaal blamed the injury problems on the number of games the pair have played. The Scottish champions played 15 games in the nine weeks before breaking for the internationals.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2)

webTitle: Finland 0 - 0 England

fields.headline: Finland 0 - 0 England
fields.standfirst: David Lacey's match report
fields.trailText: Finland Niemi, Helin, Saarinen, Hyypia, Tihinen, Nurmela, Wiss, Valakari, Forssell, Litmanen, Johansson. Subs: Jaaskelaninen, Reini, Kottila, Salli, Kuqi, Riihilahti, Kolkka.
fields.body:
Finland Niemi, Helin, Saarinen, Hyypia, Tihinen, Nurmela, Wiss, Valakari, Forssell, Litmanen, Johansson. Subs: Jaaskelaninen, Reini, Kottila, Salli, Kuqi, Riihilahti, Kolkka.

England Seaman, P Neville, Barry, Wise, Southgate, Keown, Parlour, Scholes, A Cole, Sheringham, Heskey. Subs: McManaman, Martyn, Barmby, Ferdinand, J Cole, Brown, Owen.

Referee A Sars (France)

1 min Finland kick off.
3 mins After a couple of minutes during which next to nothing happens, the ball falls to on-loan Palace striker Forssell, who takes a snap shot. Captain Keown leaps in the way to block a frankly poor effort.
5 Another worrying moment for England as Litmanen finds Forssell in more space - to no avail, luckily.
6 A dreadful back-pass puts Sheringham clear, with only keeper Niemi to beat. He races towards the edge of the box and rounds the Finn... but he's brought down on the edge of the area. Is it a penalty? Is it a sending off? Of course it isn't. Niemi is booked, a free-kick is awarded, and it's wasted. Bah, grumble and more bah.
11 Finland win a corner which is cleared by Heskey, of all people. The ball finds Cole who storms forward with murderous intent, but he's easily bustled out of things by Tihinen.
13 Scholes, foraging in the Finnish area, gets his head on the end of a loose ball. It sails towards the top corner but Hyypia blocks. It's a corner. Swiftly followed by a goal-kick.
16 Nurmela chips an interesting ball into the English box, but things quickly turn boring when it becomes clear no Finnish striker available to pick up play. Still, nice to see the other side of the pitch.
19 Heskey-baiters, hold your tounges! The Liverpool bargain bustles down the wing and cuts into the box. Unfortunately, he's edged out of the way, but only at the expense of the corner. Not pretty, but direct and nearly effective.
22 Sheringham nearly gets clear again, and Niemi goes on another sortie outside his penalty area. This one is more successful and the keeper hoofs clear.
24 England win a free-kick just outside the Finnish box. Wise whips it in from the left and finds Heskey, who flicks a header which is scrambled off the line. Keown nearly pops his big boots onto it, as well. No goal, of course, but not bad.
27 Finland are beginning to rock. Saarinen heads back towards his keeper, but only manages to find Cole, who wastes the chance with a shot straight at the man between the sticks. At this rate England must score. Mustn't they?
32 A free-kick for Finland in a dangerous position just outside the English box. Litmanen's effort is rubbish, to be frank, but credit to Southgate for getting his head to it and nutting it far, far away.
34 A lovely little one-two between Parlour, in the game for the first time, and Barry, in the game for, er, the first time. But let's not knock them - they've carved out some space beautifully. Parlour sends an inviting cross towards the feet of Cole who - cue theme music from Some Mothers Do Ave Em - takes a fresh-air shot. Heskey tries to bundle it in, but the chance has gone.
37 Substitution Finnish right-back Helin limps off, Reini comes on.
38 A bit of after-yous between Scholes and Wise on the edge of the box. Great timing, lads. Litmanen nicks off with the ball, thank you very much, and wallops it towards Forssell who is loitering in the centre. He pulls the trigger but leans back to send the ball sailing over the bar. Wheeee!
40 This really could have been quite hellish. Tihinen is set free down the wing by a back-heel from the saucy Litmanen. The full-back fizzes a ball across the face of the English net and Forssell is inches away from lunging in to give Finland a 1-0 lead. Barry tonks the ball into the stand to clear.
44 Seaman to Southgate... hooooooooof!!! Who's in charge of this team, again?
45 Finland win a corner... but there's no time to take it. The ref blows the whistle and it's half-time.

Half-time: Finland 0 - 0 England

46 No changes for either team at half-time. England kick off and immediately find themselves defending a clever deep cross from Forssell. Seaman, who has had his critics lately, comes to claim well.
47 Heskey wins a corner down the left, and then wins a header from the resulting set-piece ball from Wise. But it's going nowhere and the danger is cleared.
49 Nurmela beats Barry down the right and sends a cross into the England box. Southgate's clearance only finds Forssell, who is about to welt the ball into the net when the ref blows up for an infringement - Nurmela had handled, you lucky people.
53 Barry is having a mini-nightmare at present. He's skinned by Nurmela again - but the Villa man breathes again when the Finnish winger slips on the greasy surface.
55 Nurmela nicks past Barry again, and this time it's nearly terminal. He chips a ball across to Litmanen who looks certain to head home - but Parlour brilliantly flicks it away for a corner, which is easily cleared. 56 A touch of the Le Tissiers from Litmanen, who flicks the ball over two players and wallops the ball across the face of goal. Nobody can ram it home, though, and England live on.
58 Moments of respite for England, who aren't exactly pulling up any trees (the definition of that can be found in the back of Charlie Hughes's training manual, Howard). The ball is rolled back to Seaman from the half-way line to jeers and laughter from the Finnish crowd. This is not good stuff at present.
60 England roll the ball back to Seaman. Again.
61 And again.
63 A long clearance from Niemi results in a Finnish corner. Heskey heads the first behind for another corner, which is in turn cleared by the same player, who, for all his faults, has played well in defensive positions.
64 Sheringham finds Wise, who forces a corner, making a nice change. Barry takes it from the right and nearly finds Heskey.
65 Substitution Another injury for Finland to deal with. Saarinen comes off, Salli trots on.
66 Substitution McManaman and Brown replace a dejected Sheringham and Barry.
70 McManaman gets the ball for the first time and takes it up a cul-de-sac. To be fair, though, he wins a throw in. Which may not sound much, but at least England are having some territorial joy at last.
71 Things beginning to look a little better? Must be time for some more bad English play, then. Forssell skips clear from a static England back line and only his clunking first touch saves Howard Wilkinson's men - Seaman flies out to smother.
72 Substitution Kuqi comes on for Forssell.
75 Another long hoof from Niemi causes England problems. Litmanen dashes clear of a static English back line - heard that phrase before? - and only a high bounce allows Seaman to leap and collect ahead of the Barcelona man.
78 Finland win another corner. The English clear it, but it simply goes back to the Finns.
80 Not much happening at the moment. Oh look, the ball's trundling back towards David Seaman.
82 The ball's trundling back towards Seaman again, but this time it's flying at some pace from the boot of Litmanen, who has slipped a pass towards Johannson. However, the Charlton striker hasn't done much and that's not about to change now - the England keeper collects.
83 Parlour lumps in a ball from the right but Cole can only head weakly wide.
84 McManaman and Wise try a bit of trickery down the left, but the ball is only politely passed into the grateful hands of Niemi. England getting desperate - can they pull a result out of the hat? They wouldn't deserve it, but who'd complain?
86 A free kick... is this it? Nope.
88 But this could be! Parlour chests the ball down and bustles through a totally shattered Finnish defence... he's one on one with the keeper... and smashes the ball past Niemi and... onto the crossbar. Like a certain incident at Wembley in 1966, the ball crashes straight down and bounces on the line... but is it a goal? Nope. Wonderful play from the Arsenal man.
90 Cole takes on Hyppia and nearly gets past him down the right. He wins a corner, but it's sadly useless. A little bit of light shoving puts an end to any prolonged pressure by England as well.
90 Finland win a corner, further easing their nerves. Litmanen nearly curls a ball towards the advancing Nurmela at the right-hand post but it flies into touch.
90 That's yer lot. One point from two games isn't that good, is it? Never mind, let's go down the pub.

Full-time: Finland 0 - 0 England

Not pretty, but direct and nearly effective. 22 Sheringham nearly gets clear again, and Niemi goes on another sortie outside his penalty area. This one is more successful and the keeper hoofs clear. 24 England win a free-kick just outside the Finnish box. Wise whips it in from the left and finds Heskey, who flicks a header which is scrambled off the line. Keown nearly pops his big boots onto it, as well. No goal, of course, but not bad. 27 Finland are beginning to rock. Saarinen heads back towards his keeper, but only manages to find Cole, who wastes the chance with a shot straight at the man between the sticks. At this rate England must score. Mustn't they? 32 A free-kick for Finland in a dangerous position just outside the English box. Litmanen's effort is rubbish, to be frank, but credit to Southgate for getting his head to it and nutting it far, far away. 34 A lovely little one-two between Parlour, in the game for the first time, and Barry, in the game for, er, the first time. But let's not knock them - they've carved out some space beautifully. Parlour sends an inviting cross towards the feet of Cole who - cue theme music from Some Mothers Do Ave Em - takes a fresh-air shot. Heskey tries to bundle it in, but the chance has gone. 37 Substitution Finnish right-back Helin limps off, Reini comes on. 38 A bit of after-yous between Scholes and Wise on the edge of the box. Great timing, lads. Litmanen nicks off with the ball, thank you very much, and wallops it towards Forssell who is loitering in the centre. He pulls the trigger but leans back to send the ball sailing over the bar. Wheeee! 40 This really could have been quite hellish. Tihinen is set free down the wing by a back-heel from the saucy Litmanen. The full-back fizzes a ball across the face of the English net and Forssell is inches away from lunging in to give Finland a 1-0 lead. Barry tonks the ball into the stand to clear. 44 Seaman to Southgate... hooooooooof!!! Who's in charge of this team, again? 45 Finland win a corner... but there's no time to take it. The ref blows the whistle and it's half-time. Half-time: Finland 0 - 0 England 46 No changes for either team at half-time. England kick off and immediately find themselves defending a clever deep cross from Forssell. Seaman, who has had his critics lately, comes to claim well. 47 Heskey wins a corner down the left, and then wins a header from the resulting set-piece ball from Wise. But it's going nowhere and the danger is cleared. 49 Nurmela beats Barry down the right and sends a cross into the England box. Southgate's clearance only finds Forssell, who is about to welt the ball into the net when the ref blows up for an infringement - Nurmela had handled, you lucky people. 53 Barry is having a mini-nightmare at present. He's skinned by Nurmela again - but the Villa man breathes again when the Finnish winger slips on the greasy surface. 55 Nurmela nicks past Barry again, and this time it's nearly terminal. He chips a ball across to Litmanen who looks certain to head home - but Parlour brilliantly flicks it away for a corner, which is easily cleared. 56 A touch of the Le Tissiers from Litmanen, who flicks the ball over two players and wallops the ball across the face of goal. Nobody can ram it home, though, and England live on. 58 Moments of respite for England, who aren't exactly pulling up any trees (the definition of that can be found in the back of Charlie Hughes's training manual, Howard). The ball is rolled back to Seaman from the half-way line to jeers and laughter from the Finnish crowd. This is not good stuff at present. 60 England roll the ball back to Seaman. Again. 61 And again. 63 A long clearance from Niemi results in a Finnish corner. Heskey heads the first behind for another corner, which is in turn cleared by the same player, who, for all his faults, has played well in defensive positions. 64 Sheringham finds Wise, who forces a corner, making a nice change. Barry takes it from the right and nearly finds Heskey. 65 Substitution Another injury for Finland to deal with. Saarinen comes off, Salli trots on. 66 Substitution McManaman and Brown replace a dejected Sheringham and Barry. 70 McManaman gets the ball for the first time and takes it up a cul-de-sac. To be fair, though, he wins a throw in. Which may not sound much, but at least England are having some territorial joy at last. 71 Things beginning to look a little better? Must be time for some more bad English play, then. Forssell skips clear from a static England back line and only his clunking first touch saves Howard Wilkinson's men - Seaman flies out to smother. 72 Substitution Kuqi comes on for Forssell. 75 Another long hoof from Niemi causes England problems. Litmanen dashes clear of a static English back line - heard that phrase before? - and only a high bounce allows Seaman to leap and collect ahead of the Barcelona man. 78 Finland win another corner. The English clear it, but it simply goes back to the Finns. 80 Not much happening at the moment. Oh look, the ball's trundling back towards David Seaman. 82 The ball's trundling back towards Seaman again, but this time it's flying at some pace from the boot of Litmanen, who has slipped a pass towards Johannson. However, the Charlton striker hasn't done much and that's not about to change now - the England keeper collects. 83 Parlour lumps in a ball from the right but Cole can only head weakly wide. 84 McManaman and Wise try a bit of trickery down the left, but the ball is only politely passed into the grateful hands of Niemi. England getting desperate - can they pull a result out of the hat? They wouldn't deserve it, but who'd complain? 86 A free kick... is this it? Nope. 88 But this could be! Parlour chests the ball down and bustles through a totally shattered Finnish defence... he's one on one with the keeper... and smashes the ball past Niemi and... onto the crossbar. Like a certain incident at Wembley in 1966, the ball crashes straight down and bounces on the line... but is it a goal? Nope. Wonderful play from the Arsenal man. 90 Cole takes on Hyppia and nearly gets past him down the right. He wins a corner, but it's sadly useless. A little bit of light shoving puts an end to any prolonged pressure by England as well. 90 Finland win a corner, further easing their nerves. Litmanen nearly curls a ball towards the advancing Nurmela at the right-hand post but it flies into touch. 90 That's yer lot. One point from two games isn't that good, is it? Never mind, let's go down the pub. Full-time: Finland 0 - 0 England

webTitle: Healy a marked man

fields.headline: Healy a marked man
fields.trailText: After he scored his fifth goal in six internationals against Denmark last Saturday, David Healy looks the most likely man to put Northern Ireland on something like a run tonight.
fields.body:
David Healy, who will lead the Northern Ireland attack against Iceland in their Group Three qualifier today, looks like the answer to the goal famine that has afflicted them for more than 50 years. But the Manchester United 21-year-old, who scored his fifth goal in six internationals against Denmark on Saturday, will be tightly marked today by Hermann Hreidarsson, the defender signed by Ipswich Town from Wimbledon.

Another intriguing battle will be between Colin Murdock, the Preston centre-back, and Iceland's most expensive player Eidur Gudjohnsen, signed by Chelsea from Bolton Wanderers for £4m. "He is a class act, as he proved with his performance against Liverpool, and it is a challenge for me, another in my learning curve," said Murdock, 25.

Sammy McIlroy, Northern Ireland's manager, retains a 4-5-1 formation, with Damien Johnson, the Blackburn winger who missed the 1-1 draw with Denmark because of a groin strain, in for Jeff Whitley.

Alti Edvaldsson, the Iceland coach, is under strong criti cism after recent results, particularly the inept tactics in the 4-0 defeat by the Czechs in which he moved a defender to outside-left, creating gaps which were severely punished.

The Czechs, who lead the group, travel to Malta hoping to win their 14th world and European championship qualifying game in a row.

Iceland (4-4-2, probable): B Kristinsson; Helgason, Hreidarsson, Sverrisson,Jonsson; Helguson, Kolvidsson, R Kristinsson, Trygguason ; Gudjohnsen, Dadason.

Northern Ireland (4-5-1, probable): Carroll (Wigan); Lomas (West Ham, capt), Taggart (Leicester), Murdock (Preston), Hughes (Newcastle Utd); Johnson (Blackburn), Magilton (Ipswich), Lennon (Leicester), Horlock (Man City), Elliott (Motherwell); Healy (Man United).

Referee: M Merk (Germany).

webTitle: Happy birthday Harpers & Queen

fields.headline: Happy birthday Harpers & Queen
fields.standfirst: Harpers and Queen celebrates its thirtieth birthday next month. So what does the future hold for the high society glossy, asks the Media Medium, Maggie Hyde.
fields.trailText: Harpers and Queen celebrates its thirtieth birthday next month. So what does the future hold for the high society glossy, asks the Media Medium, Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Style bible Harpers & Queen celebrates its 30th birthday with its November issue. Born with the merger of Harper's Bazaar and Queen in 1970, its new editor, Lucy Yeomans, arrives on October 25. So what does astrology show for this high society fashion glossy?

Success for any magazine comes from tuning it into an archetypal core and if we take the cover date of the Harpers & Queen launch (November 1 1970), the dominant theme is Scorpio. Six out of 10 of its planets are in this sign of power and sexuality, with the Moon moving from Scorpio into racy Sagittarius on its day of birth.

The Scorpio planets divide into two distinct groups, bringing out two sides of the sign. One is the Scorpio eagle, shown by intellectual Mercury conjunct imaginative Jupiter, reflected in a literary tradition of eminent writers at Harper's Bazaar, including Simone de Beauvoir, Kingsley Amis, Robert Graves and Virginia Woolf. Here is wit and intelligence, the power to stir and intrigue.

The other side of Scorpio is symbolised by the snake, shown by Moon, Venus and Neptune grouped together. The magazine has been famous for its innovative and glamorous female imagery, with eminent photographers from Munkacsi to Snowdon.

The Scorpio planets key in to Saturn in Taurus, a symbol of old money, rich daddies, high society and ambition. But Saturn's opposition creates a huge unconscious shadow, the dimension of poverty and the meanness of ordinary life which doesn't exist for the Harpers & Queen reader. Who are the women who will buy the £6,750 crocodile skirt, featured in the October issue? Presumably, the cosmocrats featured in the same issue who know that you've got to 'buy Prada in Tokyo, rather than Milan'.

NatMags tells us that the readers are "fashionable, affluent, intelligent, sophisticated and well-educated - or they aspire to be". And perhaps they are. With its Venus changing direction now, we can expect a significant evolution in its presentation of the feminine.

Duncan Edwards at NatMags sees the importance of content in multi-media platforms, and the task of the new editor, arriving on the day that Mercury triggers the Harpers & Queen Jupiter, must surely be to recapture the Scorpio eagle with its substance, depth and transcending power.

STOP PRESS

Found - the woman who will buy the crocodile skirt. Harpers & Queen have informed Media Medium that new editor, Scorpio Lucy Yeomans, was born on November 1 1970 - same year, same day as Harpers & Queen. Auspicious coincidence or what?

Email the Media Medium at: maggie@companyguide.co.uk

webTitle: Win unlimited access to the Raindance film festival

fields.headline: Win unlimited access to the Raindance film festival
fields.trailText: Win a pass giving unlimited access to Britain's largest and most exciting independent film festival
fields.body:
Raindance, Britain's largest and most exciting independent film festival comes to London this Friday, October 13 for two weeks at London's Metro Cinema.

Whether you're a film-maker, a wannabe star or a fan of independent film, there's screenings, events and workshops to please every taste. The festival opens with the London premiere of Chuck and Buck, an offbeat comedy which was the US indie success of the summer. This will be screened alongside The Suicidal Dog, Paul Merton's first short film as writer/director.

Other festival highlights include the London premiere of Christopher Nolan's innovative and compelling psychological thriller Memento. Christopher Nolan will also be at the festival to present a retrospective of his work and answer questions on his acclaimed new film. You can also catch one of the successes from Cannes earlier this year, Things You Can Tell Just By Looking At Her, the directorial debut from Rodrigo Garcia (son of Gabriel Garcia Marquez), starring Calista Flockheart, Glenn Close and Cameron Diaz, the first film to be made in English under the Dogma 95 rules - The King is Alive, Three Below Zero, which stars Wes (American Beauty) Bentley and tells the tale of three diverse New Yorkers who find themselves trapped in a laundry room, and an adaptation of Martin Amis's cult novel Dead Babies, which won't be opening in the UK until February 2001.

As far as events go, we like the sound of Live!Ammunition! on Thursday 19 October - in which aspiring film-makers get just five minutes on stage to pitch their idea to a panel of industry experts. Also worth catching is this year's Alexander Mackendrick Memorial Lecture, which will be presented by British director Stephen Frears. And the illustrious cinematographer Jack Cardiff, who lists African Queen, Red Shoes and Rambo among his many cinematic credits, will be in town, talking about his extraordinary career.

The festival closes on Thursday 26 October with the UK premiere of the British comedy It Was An Accident (pictured). This Walthamstow-set film has been nominated for two British Independent Film Awards, and boasts an exciting young cast which includes Max Beesley and Thandie Newton.

The festival website has full details, and promises to be an event in itself for non London-based film fans, with over 100 live webcasts from the festival, movie clips, and the tantalising promise of the opportunity to catch glimpses of the stars and even meet the talent, producers and directors in exclusive interviews.

We have two festival passes (worth £75 each) to be won, giving the winner access to every screening and special event of the festival, including the opening and closing night.

For the chance of winning one of these passes, email feedback@filmunlimited.co.uk, please put Raindance Festival in the subject line, and include your name and a daytime telephone number (or where we can contact you on Friday morning).

Winners will be contacted by midday on Friday 13 October, and must pick up their passes (ID will be required) from the Metro Cinema on Friday night. The prize does not include the cost of transport; all screenings are at the Metro Cinema, 19 Rupert Street, London W1. Check the festival website for full details.

webTitle: Labour pledges £800m to bridge north-south divide

fields.headline: Labour pledges £800m to bridge north-south divide
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Ministers moved yesterday to shore up support in Labour's heartlands with £800m to improve houses, raise school standards and create jobs in poorer communities .
fields.body:
Ministers moved yesterday to shore up support in Labour's heartlands with £800m to improve houses, raise school standards and create jobs in poorer communities .

Backbench Labour MPs hailed the new fund - launched by Gordon Brown, the chancellor, and John Prescott, the deputy prime minister - as a shift in government policy to address the north-south divide.

A year after the prime minister dismissed divisions between England's regions as a gross over-simplification, senior ministers were at pains to stress that new measures were needed to bridge the gap between the largely prosperous south and the poorer north.

The neighbour renewal fund, which will be coordinated by another special unit in Whitehall, will be allocated to 88 councils - 60 of them in the north and the midlands. The north-east, for instance - political base of Tony Blair and a string of senior ministers - will get 13.25% of the fund although it only has 5.3% of England's population.

This prompted some of the government's strongest backbench critics to claim that Labour's English heartlands were at last getting extra cash to "compensate" for the booming south-east.

Ronnie Campbell, the Labour MP for Blyth Valley and a persistent critic of the prime minister, said: "This is certainly a step in the right direction. It is significant that the north-east is getting a bigger share."

Tony Blair's local authority, Sedgefield, has been allocated £2.3m while neighbouring Hartlepool, where the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is the MP, will get £6.3m.

While London boroughs and towns in the south, such as Brighton and Hove and Hastings, also benefit, Tories claimed that the fund had been deliberately tilted towards Labour areas for political reasons.

Ministers, however, argued that the allocations had been based on a new index of local deprivation, based on low incomes, unemployment and poor health.

They warned that town halls would have to set strict targets to qualify for the cash, which will be spread over three years from next April.

Each year, for instance, they would have to show that the health, education and job prospects of communities were improving before being allocated further cash.

Mr Brown said: "While much previous spending has been directed at dealing with the consequences of economic and social failure, it is time to invest in tackling the causes of failure - poor school results, poor standards of health and low levels of economic activity."

He warned, however, that the fund would be coupled with tough standards for achievement. "Educational performance must be raised. We must increase employment rates and improve health."

The announcement heralds a series of moves by the government to tackle the regional divide, which until recently it sought to play down.

The chancellor has also pledged that the government will pump an extra £500m into eight regional development agencies, boosting their budgets to almost £2bn by 2003-4.

Next month Mr Brown and Mr Prescott will announce a series of tax incentives to revive inner cities, particularly in the north.

Developers will be offered special allowances to encourage the regeneration of derelict land, so-called "brownfield" sites.
