webTitle: A bookish man always destined for the highest office

fields.headline: A bookish man always destined for the highest office
fields.standfirst: Mark Oliver looks at the life and career of Donald Dewar
fields.trailText: Mark Oliver looks at the life and career of Donald Dewar.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar's destiny was to become Scotland's first minister, a glance at his life utterly convinces you of this.

Every step seemed to drive him there, so much so that it became an almost cursory decision for Tony Blair to make him Scottish secretary after Labour's 1997 election victory, setting him on the road to lead Scotland's devolved parliament.

Mr Dewar is a politician from the old school, and this has given his office a special kind of dignity that has endeared him to voters.

He regularly resisted the approaches of New Labour's image-makers who urged him to ditch his 20-year-old overcoat. Only last year did he agree to jettison his trademark horn-rimmed glasses.

He was born in 1937, and educated at Glasgow Academy and Glasgow University. Last year, he admitted he had been an "isolated misfit" in his youth, and said he regretted being an only child. He attributed his infamous public awkwardness to a troubled childhood, which he described as "happy but limiting".

His schooling coincided with the war and he was sent to a small Borders school. He admitted that it was a major cultural change for him when he moved to Mosspark Primary School in Glasgow after the war.

He has said: "It was difficult and rough but Glasgow Academy was very tolerant, although I was not a star pupil by any means." And he added: "At the end of school . . . elderly parents, single sex school, only child . . . I was remarkably socially inexperienced."

After university, it was as a lawyer that he continued to develop the sharpness and verve that would later characterise his political debating.

With professional parents and a middle-class background he explains his affinity with Labour as a "sort of intellectual conviction" which flourished at university. He said there were not many wild times for him at college but that he become very embroiled in the politically active student union.

Mr Dewar has been a Labour Party activist since 1957 and has been fighting for devolution for most of his adult life. His reward, and the culmination of all his work, was overseeing the passing of the Scotland Parliament Act.

Mr Dewar married Alison McNair in 1964, but the marriage ended in 1973 when she left him for the now lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, who was his university friend. The effect the end of the relationship had on him is reflected by the fact that he never remarried and barely speaks to his colleague. He has said: "I was extremely happy for a number of years sometimes things do not work out in the long term and you just accept that."

He first entered parliament as an MP for Aberdeen South in 1966, but lost his seat in 1970. It took eight years for him to return as MP for Glasgow Garscadden. Now he represents Glasgow Anniesland.

His affection for his native city is deep and he hates to leave his mansion in the leafy West End. He rarely holidays but although he claims to turn down cocktail party invitations "by the gross", the bookish politician insists he is not a recluse. He drives a 16-year-old Peugeot and has expressed his unease at climbing inside the government's plush vehicles.

Mr Dewar served as a member of Labour's Scottish team in opposition between 1981 and 1992, when the then leader, John Smith, made him shadow social security secretary.

In the final years of Labour's opposition, he proved to be an excellent chief whip, flying in the face of tradition by raising the public profile of the role with television appearances selling his party's policies.

His life as first minister has not been without its challenges, and after the 1997 referendum his personal ratings fell during a rampant period for the SNP.

But he fought back in the polls and during the parliamentary campaign he overcame the SNP's Alex Salmond as the people's choice for first minister.

His political style has always shied way from "stunts" and soundbites, although he did call the numbers at a bingo game last April. His humour is sharp but not cruel and he has inspired affection among friends and foes alike.

webTitle: Netnotes: Michelangelo

fields.headline: Michelangelo
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the man who produced a drawing which is worth £8m
fields.trailText: 1. A Sotheby's man, thumbing through an album of drawings for a routine insurance valuation at Castle Howard in Yorkshire, has stumbled across a bit of a treasure.
fields.body:
1. A Sotheby's man, thumbing through an album of drawings for a routine insurance valuation at Castle Howard in Yorkshire, has stumbled across a bit of a treasure.

2. It's a drawing of a woman in mourning, by Michelangelo, and it's worth £8,000,000.

3. You might think that a bit steep. You'd be wrong. Works by Michelangelo are priceless. He remains, not to labour the point, one of the greatest artists of all time.

4. Michelangelo Buonarrati lived from 1475 to 1564. From his early adulthood to his old age, he produced works of genius unparalleled except perhaps by his famous contemporary Leonardo da Vinci. He was a painter, a poet, and an architect. Above all, he was a sculptor.

5. The full glory of the ceiling in the Sistine Chapel is perhaps the best known memorial to his sublime art.

6. The Creation of Man is one of the most powerful images ever conceived and executed.

7. For sheer tear-jerking beauty, however, there has probably never been, nor ever will be, a work to equal his statue of David.

8. Michelangelo was almost certainly nicer than he looked.

9. He had a nice sense of humour: when a papal official rebuked him for painting nudes in the Vatican - "it was no work for a papal chapel but rather for the public baths and taverns" - he responded by incorporating a portrait of the wretched man, in Hell.

10. For half a millennium people have looked in awe at the works of Michelangelo. Now he is going digital.

webTitle: Dewar is critically ill after fall

fields.headline: Dewar is critically ill after fall
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was critically ill on a life support machine at an Edinburgh hospital last night after a fall outside his official residence.
fields.body:
The Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was critically ill on a life support machine at an Edinburgh hospital last night after a fall outside his official residence.

Mr Dewar's condition worsened dramatically during the day and his daughter Marion, who lives in Brussels, and his son Ian were last night on their way to Edinburgh.

David Whitton, Mr Dewar's spokesman, said: "Although he did not bump his head, he may have damaged a blood vessel in his head. As a result of this, he is suffering bleeding to his head."

It is understood that medication Mr Dewar has been taking to thin his blood after heart valve surgery may have heightened his susceptibility to internal bleeding.

Mr Dewar, 63, was rushed to a specialist neurological unit at the city's Western general hospital after tests at another hospital. He was receiving intensive care treatment.

After chairing his usual cabinet meeting in Bute House, at around 12.15pm, Mr Dewar left his official residence to travel by car to the main Scottish executive offices around a mile away.

Before he got into the car he slipped and fell on the pavement. Later in the afternoon, Mr Dewar began to complain of feeling unwell, but continued working.

Anxious aides, however, contacted Dr Colin Currie, a special adviser to the Scottish health minister, who was in the same building. He examined Mr Dewar and then called on the advice of doctors at Edinburgh royal infirmary.

Mr Dewar was admitted to the hospital in what was initially believed to be a "precautionary measure". However, brain scans and other tests revealed that there was a serious threat to Mr DewarÍs health. His condition began rapidly deteriorating.

At 7.40pm Mr Dewar was taken by ambulance to a specialist neurological unit at the Western general. It was there that a scan confirmed that Mr Dewar was suffering from internal bleeding in the brain.

Mr Dewar, a much-loved figure in Scotland, is often dubbed the father of the nation, a sobriquet granted after he achieved his cherished political ambition last year - and delivered the first Scottish parliament for 300 years.

John Reid, the Scottish secretary, said last night: "Donald made his name in United Kingdom politics but he is unparalleled in Scottish politics, not just among those who support the Labour party but people of all political persuasions."

He said Mr Blair was taking a "great interest" in Mr Dewar's condition. "I think Tony has a tremendous respect for the decency that has always been associated with Donald Dewar in politics. He has been kept briefed very regularly throughout the day and, if necessary, will be throughout the night."

Mr Dewar had only recently returned to work after a three-month break to allow him to recover from a seven-hour operation in May to repair a leaking aortic valve.

However, brain scans and other tests revealed that there was a serious threat to Mr DewarÍs health. His condition began rapidly deteriorating. At 7.40pm Mr Dewar was taken by ambulance to a specialist neurological unit at the Western general. It was there that a scan confirmed that Mr Dewar was suffering from internal bleeding in the brain. Mr Dewar, a much-loved figure in Scotland, is often dubbed the father of the nation, a sobriquet granted after he achieved his cherished political ambition last year - and delivered the first Scottish parliament for 300 years. John Reid, the Scottish secretary, said last night: "Donald made his name in United Kingdom politics but he is unparalleled in Scottish politics, not just among those who support the Labour party but people of all political persuasions." He said Mr Blair was taking a "great interest" in Mr Dewar's condition. "I think Tony has a tremendous respect for the decency that has always been associated with Donald Dewar in politics. He has been kept briefed very regularly throughout the day and, if necessary, will be throughout the night." Mr Dewar had only recently returned to work after a three-month break to allow him to recover from a seven-hour operation in May to repair a leaking aortic valve.

webTitle: October 10 ratings

fields.headline: ITV out in front with TV awards
fields.trailText: 12.15pm overnights: Judy Finnigan's "outburst" at the National Television Awards drew large audiences last night, helping ITV to its best Tuesday peak time share of the year. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The National Television Awards - and that "outburst" by Judy Finnigan - drew large audience numbers last night, helping ITV to its best Tuesday peak time share of the year.

Overall, ITV took a barn-storming 44.6% share in peak time (7-10.30pm) last night; while BBC1 mustered only 24.7%, according to unofficial overnights. The National Television Awards averaged 11.8m/50% over two hours from 8pm, building from 41% in the opening quarter hour to 58% for the final 15 minutes from 9.45pm.

After that the Cliff Richard Story (8.7m/46% from 10pm) and ITV's Nightly News (5.7m/46% from 11pm) made the most of their inheritance from the awards show. It was the Nightly News' best audience since it began in March 1999.

ITV's Regional News & Weather - which is to be controversially cast adrift at 11.20pm when the main late evening news moves back to 10pm - showed the benefit of nuzzling up to a national news bulletin, with 4.2m/41% from 11.20-11.35pm.

This figure was almost certainly boosted by the biblically bad weather last night, but collectively the regional news and weather round-ups still got better ratings than the BBC1 9pm News (4.1m/17%).

Other BBC shows that got hit by the TV awards juggernaut included BBC1 sitcom My Family (4.6m/19%, down from 5.7m/25% last week), and BBC2 dot.com drama Attachments, which continued its ratings slide (1m/4% after 1.3m/6% last week).

In fact, EastEnders, with a trusty 11.4m/52% from 7.30pm, was probably the only thing that stood between BBC1 and another sub-20% peak time share last night.

webTitle: Brown's £10m plan to link poorest to the net

fields.headline: Brown's £10m plan to link poorest to the net
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced a £10m initiative intended to link the UK's poorest communities to the internet.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced a £10m initiative intended to link the UK's poorest communities to the internet.

Addressing an internet summit in London, Mr Brown said tens of thousands of families would receive free computers and cheap internet access in a bid to bridge what he called the "growing digital divide" between rich and poor.

While half of the wealthiest 10% of households have internet access, just one in 20 of the poorest can get on to the web.

The money will be spent on 10 pilot projects under which free computers will be given to 35,000 households which do not already own one, along with cut-price phone connections.

Community webs - linking those involved in the projects to the rest of the internet - will give training and advice on jobs, while access to local services and IT training centres will be provided as part of the public-private venture. "This will help overcome the barriers people may face in access to employment, education and local services and it will give many the opportunity for the first time to use the internet," Mr Brown said.

Liverpool's Kensington Estate, - among the most deprived 1% of areas in Britain with unemployment three times the national average - will be the first community to be "wired up". Firms ICL and Gardener Systems will work with local organisations to put 2,000 free computers in homes on the estate and ensure residents can use them.

Nine other pilot areas which will take part in the project will be named in the coming months.

The scheme will help the government meet Prime Minister Tony Blair's pledge to ensure everyone has internet access by 2005.

webTitle: Leader: Panorama flushing out killers

fields.headline: No hiding place
fields.standfirst:
Panorama will help to flush out the killers

Special report: Northern Ireland
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: One of the sorry by-products of the Troubles in Northern Ireland has been the cavalier way in which the fundamental right to free speech has been subverted. The ban on broadcast interviews with paramilitaries - now thankfully rescinded - was accompanied by any number of other oppressive measures, under the Prevention of Terrorism Act.
fields.body:
One of the sorry by-products of the Troubles in Northern Ireland has been the cavalier way in which the fundamental right to free speech has been subverted. The ban on broadcast interviews with paramilitaries - now thankfully rescinded - was accompanied by any number of other oppressive measures, under the Prevention of Terrorism Act.

Charges against Tony Geraghty, an author writing on intelligence matters, have been dropped, but his alleged source faces an official secrets trial. As 30-year-old secrets are painfully extracted by the Bloody Sunday inquiry fresh injunctions have been taken out against the Sunday Times and Sunday People, preventing them from revealing details of investigations into the shadowy FRU army intelligence unit. It was welcome news, then, that court action to prevent the BBC from broadcasting a Panorama programme on the Omagh massacre should have failed.

The motive for seeking the injunction - that the programme, by naming the suspected murderers, might prejudice any prospect of a future trial - was understandable but misguided. Firstly, any case in Northern Ireland would be heard by judge alone. Secondly, there are no proceedings remotely imminent. It would be a sad day for investigative journalism if editors suppressed material on the off-chance that it might prejudice some hypothetical trial in the future.

John Ware's reporting - like Peter Taylor's before him - was detailed, careful and damning. All credit to the BBC for backing such work by their veteran reporters. If those named feel badly maligned by the allegations they can, of course, sue for libel. Meanwhile the programme reminded us, if we needed reminding, of the enormous evil that took place in Omagh two years ago. There should be no hiding place for the men who perpetrated that evil. If Panorama helps flush out the evidence to convict them, it will have done some real good.

webTitle: Donald Dewar's year of ill health

fields.headline: Donald Dewar's year of ill health
fields.standfirst: Mark Oliver looks back over a year of health problems for Scotland's first minister
fields.trailText: Mark Oliver looks back over a year of health problems for Scotland's first minister.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar, first encountered serious health problems in April this year when he was taken to Glasgow Royal Infirmary's cardiac unit for tests following the discovery of a heart irregularity.

He then revealed he would have to undergo major surgery to replace a defective heart valve. He had to rebuff accusations of 'jumping the queue' for his operation, insisting he wanted to be treated on the NHS "like everybody else".

In May, Mr Dewar was admitted to Glasgow Royal Infirmary for treatment. He underwent a three-and-a-half hour operation to replace a leaking aortic valve with a mechanical device on May 8. His condition after surgery was "stable" and he recovered on a ventilator. His two children, Ian and Marion took him home on May 17. In his first public interview since his surgery, Mr Dewar told Scottish Television on June 21, that the operation left him "knackered" and that he had been taking to the streets of his Anniesland constituency under instructions from his doctor to take exercise.

He dismissed speculation that his illness was brought on by the stress of working long hours and insisted he was still the best man for the job. He attended an awayday meeting of ministers, officials and advisers at the Houston House Hotel in Uphall, West Lothian on June 27.

Following a series of internal squabbles among Scottish cabinet ministers, the first minister stepped in on July 5 to warn them they risk being sacked if they fail to settle their differences.

Mr Dewar made his first public appearance since his surgery on August 10, handing over the keys to a minibus at a disability resource centre in his constituency. He said he was "feeling fine" and "looking forward to getting back to work".

The crisis surrounding the Scottish Qualifications Authority, which sent out inaccurate or incomplete results to 150,000 exam candidates during the summer, was at its height as the first minister returned to his desk on August 14.

MSPs on all sides applauded Mr Dewar as he returned to the Scottish parliament's debating chamber on September 7, following the summer recess.

Mr Dewar insisted Labour would "weather the storms besetting it" after the fuel crisis and win the next general election, despite an opinion poll for The Scotsman newspaper suggesting his popularity had waned in Scotland.

He then endured a bruising question time in the Scottish parliament on October 5 with new Scottish National Party leader John Swinney, after which he looked visibly tired. Fears for his health at this stage were officially dismissed.

On the morning of October 10, Mr Dewar fell outside his official residence in Edinburgh. Although the fall seemed routine enough at first and Mr Dewar continued to work, his condition worsened during the day and he was finally admitted to hospital, complaining of feeling unwell. His condition further deteriorated as scans revealed severe bleeding inside the brain. He was put on a life support machine and his children rushed to Edinburgh to be at their father's bedside.

It is understood that medication Mr Dewar had been taking to thin his blood after heart valve surgery may have heightened his susceptibility to internal bleeding.

webTitle: The Way You See It

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Your views on Wilko's England...
fields.body:
Your views on Wilko's England...

"I will be cheering on Finland tonight," says Chris Wilkins, "Because a defeat (preferably a heavy one) is the best thing that could happen for for England. Any other result will mean business as usual; plodding on in the misguided, regressive delusion that we can play lumpen park football using coaching manuals apparently written in the 1950s."

"Frankly, Wilkinson has lost the plot," says Ilc Kumamoto. "Three strikers may pay off but it will be down to luck rather than tactical genius. England will be very vulnerable in midfield where games are won and lost these days."

If Gerry Avis had his way, he would "keep Michael Owen in and drop Andy Cole. I think Owen is a scapegoat for the incompetence of the midfield against Germany. Shearer was kept in the England squad even though he failed to score in seven matches. We need to stop playing favourites and think England first."

On the FA's Adam Crozier and his incredible new selection panel

"I believe Crozier is a sound choice for the job of revamping the FA and he is right when he says we have to stop changing the manager every 18 months," says Mark Burke, quite even-handedly. "But when it comes to picking the new coach, what qualifications have the panel got? Apart from Wilkinson, I believe, the others are self-made men who have come into football on the back of their business achievements. This in no way qualifies them to agonise and debate over what makes a good football coach. In reality they are the man in the street with a little more money in their pockets."

Mike Hoare has less time for the FA's dapper chief executive. "There seems to be a persistent thought that all we need is the right manager to produce a successful team", he says. "Surely by now there should be some recognition that every successful side at the top level has a firm infrastructure behind it. When are the FA going to look long term instead of doing FA except fire-fighting from coach to coach, tarnishing the reputation of everyone who attempts to take on the job?"

And finally a few of your many tips for the new England boss

"It should be Roy Hodgson. He's intelligent and knows how to play continental football", says Lucas. "He couldn't help it if Blackburn were shit. Or if his voice makes him sound like Brian Walden."

Arvinder Margat has an innovative suggestion. "It should be Jim Rosenthal," he says. "he needs something to fill his time since the end of the F1 season, and his ability to say 'good luck to y'all' at the end of every telephone competition will inspire more confidence than Keegan ever did."

The most audacious bid comes from Graeme King, who says: "We need to appoint Bill Clinton. He will soon be unemployed. He is second only to Terry Venables for legal problems. He can match Glenn Hoddle in his bizarre claims to be a God-fearing Christian despite behaviour to the contrary, and has about as much tactical footballing nous as Kevin Keegan. Ideally suited to be an England manager."

Alan suggests Margaret Thatcher because "she is mad enough, and like the last incumbent, will attempt to ensure that the country is out of Europe as soon as possible," but then blows his gaff somewhat by revealing that he lives in Glasgow.

webTitle: Revolution round-up

fields.headline: Revolution round-up
fields.standfirst: Published on October 11.
fields.trailText: October 11: The chief operating officer of the Trainline.com, Richard Bowden-Doyle, has quit after just four months into the job.
fields.body:
The chief operating officer of the Trainline.com, Richard Bowden-Doyle, has quit after just four months into the job, citing problems working as number two, not number one in the company.

The Committee of Advertising Practice is to institute the first ever code of conduct for online advertisers to develop clearcut advertising.

Roger Burnell, former ceo of Thomson Travel Group, has joined TheFirstResort.

Music website Clickmusic is printing an online music guide magazine, which it is to distribute in Virgin Megastores from November.

News International's FiredUp has lost its product director Lynda Rathbone who is joining Cable & Wireless.

Radio station Atlantic 252 is to set up an online nightclub.

webTitle: News of the World lands Sun columnist

fields.headline: News of the World lures Sun columnist
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: News of the World editor Rebekah Wade has signed up Sun columnist Ally Ross as her new TV reviewer. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
News of the World editor Rebekah Wade has mounted another dawn raid on her former colleagues at the Sun, signing up columnist Ally Ross as her new TV reviewer.

Mr Ross, 33, who launched the Sun's showbiz diary UK Confidential, will start at the News of the World in a month's time.

"I have always wanted to be a TV critic," he today told MediaGuardian. "I used to read Clive James in the Observer when I was little - it's why I became a journalist."

Mr Ross started working for the Scottish Sun in 1995, moving to London in 1997 when he joined the Bizarre showbiz desk to work with the then editor Andy Coulson.

UK Confidential started in 1999, and Mr Ross has more recently been writing his own weekly column.

After taking up her post at the News of the World, Ms Wade soon signed up Mr Coulson as her deputy.

"I'm taking a week off to watch even more TV," Mr Ross said. "I can't wait to start - my admiration for Rebekah and Andy knows no bounds."

fields.headline: The Hiding Place by Trezza Azzopardi
fields.standfirst: Chapter one
fields.trailText:
Six-to-four the field, six-to-one bar! Shouting the odds, the TV and my father, low down on the living room floor.

C'mon, baby! he yells, beating his flank with his fist. With the betting slip in his teeth, he gallops down the last furlong of the rug, to the home straight of the lino. Words bolt from the side of his mouth: Yankee Piggott Photo-finish. I don't understand any of it: I think my father's English leaves a lot to be desired.
fields.body:
Six-to-four the field, six-to-one bar! Shouting the odds, the TV and my father, low down on the living room floor.

C'mon, baby! he yells, beating his flank with his fist. With the betting slip in his teeth, he gallops down the last furlong of the rug, to the home straight of the lino. Words bolt from the side of his mouth: Yankee Piggott Photo-finish. I don't understand any of it: I think my father's English leaves a lot to be desired.

He curses: Jesus Christ.

At the end of the race, his face is very flushed, an inch from the set. He's watching the lines and dots as if Barney's Boy will suddenly leap through the screen. Ripping pink shreds of paper from his mouth, my father tears up his slip and spits the remains on the rug. Then he starts in on the Sporting Life, holding it out in front of him, rending it between his fists until he's tearing air. I know at these moments that he would tear me too, for the slightest thing, and I crawl ever so slowly behind the couch, until he's put on his donkey jacket and slammed the back door.

He isn't just like this about horses. My father will gamble on anything that moves. He won't do Bingo or fruit machines or snow on Christmas Day, but horses and pontoon and poker and dogs. My father's love is Chance. Look at that roulette wheel! Bet red, bet black, bet red, bet black. If he could place his bet Under Starter's Orders he would still change his mind over every fence. The Form makes no difference, the words don't make sense, and the odds at Joe Coral have no bearing on his stake.

He has always been this way, according to my mother. She made her own bet on him, in November 1948, in the church of St Mark's, in a white lace gown.

* * *

This is what happens just before I am born: it's 1960. My parents, Frankie and Mary, have five beautiful daughters, and a half-share in a cafe overlooking Cardiff docks. Salvatore Capanone, my father's oldest friend, owns the other half. The sailors on shore leave pour in through the red door to eat, and find a girl. My family lives above the cafe. They have two rooms; one long one, divided into bedroom and lounge by a thick toile curtain depicting scenes of the French aristocracy, and an airless back room which they call The Pit, because you have to climb down into it. My sisters inhabit The Pit, and my father has put a gate up in the doorway to stop Luca, who's only two years old, from climbing up the steps and falling down again. Luca swings her fat leg over the gate whenever my mother isn't looking, and falls from that instead.

There is a third room, one more flight up. It has a square wooden table covered with worn green felt, and four vinyl-backed chairs stacked one upon the other. In the far corner is a window where a blind conceals the day. My mother never goes into this room; it's not hers to use.

There is no kitchen. Every morning my mother trudges downstairs to the cafe to fetch food for my sisters to eat, which they do, sitting in a long line on the couch and watching the Test Card on the television in the corner, while she moves her washing from surface to surface, doing her impression of someone who is tidy. My father's old sea chest is the only storage space, filled with baby clothes. I'll be wearing them soon. My mother knows this, but she doesn't want to air the clothes because my father doesn't. Also, she's determined that I'm a boy this time, and so a lot of the shawls and bonnets and little woollen coats will be redundant, being mainly pink.

Celesta, who's eleven going on forty, is helping to get Marina and Rose ready for school. They look like two turnips in their cream-coloured balaclava hats, and Celesta doesn't want to be seen with them. She wears a straw boater with a chocolate-brown ribbon, bought for when she goes to Our Lady's Convent School. She won't start there until next term, by which time the boater will have a distinctly weathered look, but at the moment she wears it all the time, even in bed. Fran has just begun at primary school. She draws angry pictures of bonfires using three crayons at a time. My mother pays no attention to this, having to deal with Luca now, and the prospect of me later.

When the other children leave, my mother squashes Luca into her hip and goes downstairs to the cafe. She unbolts the front door, slipping off the heavy chain which swings against the wood, and paces the narrow aisle between the tables. At the furthest end, where the daylight doesn't stretch, are two booths and a long counter. Close to its brass lip sit a single smeared tumbler and a half-empty bottle of Advocaat. The air is sweetish here. A sleeveless Peggy Lee is propped against the gramophone in the corner - Salvatore has had a late night.

My mother eases Luca into her high chair, and as soon as she is down, with the rush of cold around her thigh, she screams. She won't stop until she has something sticky on bread, or until my father comes back from the market and swings her in his arms. Luca can't understand why she isn't allowed to practise running. Salvatore used to let her, when my mother had to go and fetch Fran, or hunt the Bookies for my father.

Frankie and Salvatore are a strange brace. My father is smooth and lean, well cut in his well-cut suit. His partner is softer, larger, with milky hands and brimming eyes. Every morning Salvatore puts a clean white handkerchief in the pocket of his apron to deal with the tears which will flow through the day. He blames the heat of the kitchen, rather than his childless wife or the plaintive tones of Mario Lanza. The air is full of music when Salvatore cooks. He plays Dino and Sammy, endless Sinatra, and his favourite, Louis Prima, who reminds him of somewhere not quite like home. The records are stacked in the plate rack on top of the counter, the plates haphazardly stowed beneath. Salvatore glides through the days and nights, dusting flour into the grooves of Julie London, wiping her clean with his napkin. And then he wipes his eyes.

There is a delicate division of labour in this business. Salvatore is a better cook than Frankie, for whom the flames of the kitchen are too much like his vision of Hell. So while Salvatore cuts his fingers, brands the soft flesh of his forearm on the searing stove, and sings and cries, Frankie wears his suit and does things with money upstairs. But Salvatore likes it this way, he gets to see people.

* * *

At first, convinced that it would tempt the passers-by, Salvatore made stews and bread and almond cakes dusted with sugar. He wedged the red door open with a bar stool, wafting the smell of baking out into the street with his tea-towel. He wrote a sign, DELICIOUS FOOD, in a careful hand, and tied it with parcel string around the rusted frame of the awning outside. But Mack the Knife spilt out on to the pavement, upsetting the barber shop owner next door, the sign ran in the rain, and soon Salvatore brought the stool back to the bar. The pigeons in the yard grew fat on unbought food.

Never mind, said my mother. It takes time.

Now he cooks for the sailors, who want egg and chips or bacon in starchy white rolls, and the cafe is busy. Sailors bring in girls, and girls attract trade. Salvatore fries everything in the flat black pan on the, stove, his thinning hair stuck to his head with steam. The combed strands come unglued throughout the day, falling one by one in lank array over his left ear. He pretends to be a widower so that the night girls will pity him. In fact he is married to Carlotta, who is respectable, and will not enter The Port of Call, our cafe. Or as Carlotta calls it in her broken English, That Den-o-Sin.

* * *

Salvatore loves my mother and my father and my sisters. He is part of the family. And he will love me too, when I am born. Until then, he has to make do with Luca, who shrieks from her high chair the moment my mother's back is turned. Salvatore watches from a safe distance as Luca's arms jolt up and down in an urgent plea to be lifted. He would free her, but he daren't. The last time he did, she ran like a river to the end of the cafe and caught her head on the edge of a table. She stared at it, astonished, while her forehead bulged and split. The knock held her silent for two days, so silent, my mother thought she was damaged: it was the only time Luca was quiet.

Now when my mother has to go out, she traps Luca in The Pit with soft toys to keep her happy for the five minutes she thinks she will be away. Luca throws them at the furthest wall, screaming like a bomb.

In search of my father, my mother is blunt and shaming. She no longer has the time to be discreet.

Have you seen Frankie? Len the Bookie? In The Bute, are they? Righto. She tracks down her husband, to the arcade, the coffee house, the back room of the pub. When she finds him, she is vocal. My father complains.

This is business, Mary. Keep out of it. The other men look down and grin into their shirts. And when my father does return, my mother points to Luca's head.

That's down to you, that is. Sufficiently shamed, or just tired of losing, Frankie starts a clean sheet. He stops betting; he has finished with it for good. But when my mother tells him about me (at six months the evidence is mounting), he takes the money he's accumulated through not gambling and opens a card school in the top room of the cafe. He wins, and wins. And suddenly I am luck personified.

We'll call him Fortuno, he says, rubbing my mother's stomach as if she's harbouring the Golden Egg. My mother has other ideas.

* * *

In the top room, all four chairs are occupied. There is a haze of cheroots, a sweat of onions, the stink of eggs in oil. My father has staked everything on the winning of the game. Away in the infirmary, I'm wailing at the midwife as Frankie decides to Twist. My mother is straining with the labour of prayer. Over and over.

Oh God, let it be a boy.

When the midwife pulls me out, she conceals me. I am shunted from scales to blanket to anteroom. She closes the door on my mother.

If you have to tell her anything, tell her it's a boy, says the midwife to the nurse.

Salvatore's wife Carlotta, waiting in the corridor with her big black handbag poised on the bulge of her stomach, catches just this one phrase - tell her it's a boy - and makes a phone-call to the cafe.

Salvatore is watching the card game from the doorway upstairs, peeping through the curtain of beads which hangs from the lintel. They cascade from his shoulders like Madonna tears. He doesn't hear the telephone; his mind is in anguish for the game he's not allowed to play. His eyes are fixed on the Brylcreem glint which crowns my father's head. Salvatore's right hand rests stiff across his heart, his left holds a spatula, which oozes slow drips on to the red linoleum floor. He should be downstairs making greasy meals for the thin night girls, but Salvatore cannot concentrate on bacon and eggs when his business is at stake.

* * *

Salvatore likes his partner Frankie, even though he's lazy and not always dependable, and he adores the night girls downstairs. The young ones perch on the stools, their bouffant heads nodding in time to the music on the gramophone; they are stiff-lacquered, clean-scented. The older ones smile, now and then flinging an arm across the booths to display their latest Solitaires. Or they sit in silence. They draw their wet fingers round the rim of their glasses, in an effort to make the last rum last.

Rita, Sophia, Gina. Salvatore recites the girls' names in his sing-song voice. These women are really Irene and Lizzie and Pat. They close around the green metal ashtrays, depressing the buttons with their jewelled hands, watching the debris swirl into the hidden bowl below. When they do leave, the imprints of their bored thighs remain a while upon the shiny leatherette. They never say thank you and they never look back. Salvatore always forgives them. He wipes his hands down the breast of his apron, and sings through the night, while Frankie gambles in the room above his head.

* * *

Tonight, Salvatore wants to watch. Here we have my father, the giant Martineau, Ilya the Pole, and crooked Joe Medora. This pack of men is busy.

Sal ... telephone, says Joe, not looking up. Salvatore rolls reluctantly downstairs.

Joe Medora wears a slouch hat, a silk scarf anchored at the neck, a Savile Row suit. He's an archetypal villain who makes sure he looks the part. He angles his cigar into the side of his lipless mouth, staring over his Hand. He's seen all the films; no gesture is wasted. He is patient.

It's my father's move. Jack of Hearts, Five of Clubs, Four - winking - Diamonds.

It's a boy! cries Salvatore, beating back upstairs. Bambino, Frankie!

And my father, who is Frankie Bambina to his friends, poor unlucky Frank to have so many daughters, Twists in reckless joy, and loses the cafe, the shoebox under the floorboards full with big money, his own father's ruby ring, and my mother's white lace gown, to Joe Medora.

At least I have a son, he thinks, as he rolls the ring across the worn green felt.

* * *

My father stands above my cot with a clenched fist and a stiff smile. He rubs his left hand along the lining of his pocket, feeling the absence of his father's ring and the nakedness of losing.

At the end of the ward, Salvatore's face appears in the porthole of the swing door. Carlotta's face fills the other, and for a moment they stare separately at the rows and rows of beds and cots. Carlotta lets out a shout, Mary! Frankie!, and sweeps towards my parents. Salvatore raises his hand in salute, but takes his time, pausing to exchange greetings with the other mothers.

A fine baby, Missus!

What a beauty! Boy or girl?

Twins? How lucky! There aren't enough babies in the ward for Salvatore, perhaps not in the world. He bends over each one with his big smile and his hands clasped at his back.

Carlotta spreads herself on the chair next to my mother's bed and rummages deep into her bag. She makes small talk, not trusting herself to mention me, or the cafe, or the future. My father stabs his teeth with a broken matchstick he's found in the other pocket of his trousers, and sucks air, and says nothing. No one looks at me. Then Salvatore approaches the foot of my mother's bed and opens his arms wide to embrace my father. Both men lean into each other, quietly choking. Carlotta produces a dented red box from her bag, prises off the lid, and offers my mother a chocolate.

Please have one, Mary. They're your favourites.

Mary is in a state of mute blankness. A girl baby, yet again. In her head, she wonders what to call me - she's exhausted her list of Saints' names on the boys she never bore, and is sick of all the arias in the names her girls have got. Dolores drifts up in miserable smoke.

Salvatore rests a hand upon my mother's arm and gazes into my cot. The pink matinee jacket is fastened too tight around my neck; it reeks of mothballs. Wearing his best suit for the visit (which is also the one he wears to funerals), Salvatore smells the same as me. He lands great kisses on my forehead and holds me up for inspection, cajoling my mother.

See, Mary! So pretty!

My mother fixes on the flaking paint of the radiator, and wishes we would all go away. Frankie, too, has had enough of Cooing and Aahing. He puts his hand on Salvatore's chest and shunts him back down the ward. He presses so hard, Salvatore feels the buttons of his shirt indent his skin.

Mary is in shock, my father tells them. Better leave her alone. This is nothing compared to the shock she'll get when she finds out she's homeless, and her wedding dress adorns a bottle-blonde from Llanelli.

* * *

I am a week old when everything changes. My parents move into a run-down house at one end of a winding street. The other end is dead, sealed by a high wall spun with barbed wire. Joe Medora owns our new house, and our old cafe. The rent increases on a whim: when Joe gambles on a loser, it goes up. But it can go up when he bets on a winner, too.

My father is put in the Box Room: it is a cell. Celesta and Marina and Rose have the back bedroom. One window overlooks the road, where Rose leans out to spit on unsuspecting heads. Marina springs up and down on her bed, tearing off the wallpaper in long strips, while Celesta puts her fingers in her ears, reads The Book of Common Ailments, and convinces herself that she is dying.

The front bedroom becomes Our Room, my mother and Fran and Luca and me. Fran has the bed in the corner, and Luca has exclusive rights over my mother, who puts me in the chest. When she's convinced that I'll survive the night, I'm allowed to share the bed.

* * *

Carlotta is recruited in these difficult times, apparently to look after us children. She's really here to make sure my mother is a Good Wife who doesn't desert her fallen-on-hard-times husband: my mother might at any second run away with, say, the Coalman. This is prescient, but not in the way Carlotta thinks.

For now, Salvatore still works at the cafe, renamed The Moonlight Club in sputtering neon, and he leaves his friend Frankie alone. But he thinks about us, he worries about me, and he asks Carlotta every night for a report.

Getting big now, Carlotta says, stretching her arms out like a fisherman to show how I'm growing.

Salvatore is not entirely convinced, and once a week he sends Carlotta with a parcel of food, stolen from his shifts at The Moonlight. He feels he is entitled; after all, he's still a partner in the business. Except these days, working with Joe Medora, he feels more like a slave.

While my mother takes to her bed and stares at the ceiling, Carlotta cooks up a steam in the little kitchen. She makes baked pasta with blackened edges, solid slabs of home-made bread. Everything she provides is sharp and hard, as if to counteract the softness of her body and the thick roll of her voice. My mother thinks of little, but she listens. She hears the sticky cough of the woman in her kitchen, and imagines Carlotta dipping her feelers in the cooking pot, testing the saltiness of the ham.

It is about this time that I am burnt.

But he thinks about us, he worries about me, and he asks Carlotta every night for a report. Getting big now, Carlotta says, stretching her arms out like a fisherman to show how I'm growing. Salvatore is not entirely convinced, and once a week he sends Carlotta with a parcel of food, stolen from his shifts at The Moonlight. He feels he is entitled; after all, he's still a partner in the business. Except these days, working with Joe Medora, he feels more like a slave. While my mother takes to her bed and stares at the ceiling, Carlotta cooks up a steam in the little kitchen. She makes baked pasta with blackened edges, solid slabs of home-made bread. Everything she provides is sharp and hard, as if to counteract the softness of her body and the thick roll of her voice. My mother thinks of little, but she listens. She hears the sticky cough of the woman in her kitchen, and imagines Carlotta dipping her feelers in the cooking pot, testing the saltiness of the ham. It is about this time that I am burnt.

webTitle: Boxman seeks to enter liquidation

fields.headline: Boxman seeks to enter liquidation
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Boxman, one of Europe's three largest online retailers of CDs, has ceased trade and is seeking to enter voluntary liquidation.
fields.body:
Boxman, one of Europe's three largest online retailers of CDs, has ceased trade and is seeking to enter voluntary liquidation.

The company suspended its website two days ago, and is now requesting approval to liquidate from investors and creditors.

It becomes the highest-profile dot.com casualty since boo.com collapsed in May.

The omens have been growing for Boxman. In April, it was forced to cancel a £300m float. And last month it asked existing shareholders to approve the issue of new stock at just 10p a share. This latest round of financing has failed.

"If a massively discounted share sale is the only way Europe's leading online music seller can get financing," asked the Industry Standard at the time, "what hope is there for everyone else?"

But all may not be lost. According to the Financial Times, talks are said to be still in progress with at least one potential buyer.

webTitle: Paul Grayson: is that it?

fields.headline: Paul Grayson: is that it?
fields.trailText: Poor Paul Grayson. A golden duck on his first appearance for England, five unspectacular overs for 20 runs, a couple of hand-stinging misfields, and every chance of instant entry to England's One-Day-Wonder Club. In his case, this means everyone is wondering why he was picked.
fields.body:
Poor Paul Grayson. A golden duck on his first appearance for England, five unspectacular overs for 20 runs, a couple of hand-stinging misfields, and every chance of instant entry to England's One-Day-Wonder Club. In his case, this means everyone is wondering why he was picked.

England are not exactly spoilt for choice when it comes to slow bowlers, so Grayson, who at 29 is young for a spinner, may have a chance of playing again. But you can't help feeling that it's all over for the county journeyman who has only just got used to loving his England No.24 shirt. Still, better to have loved and lost than to have never loved at all.

His innings was the stuff of nightmares, but at least his five overs were tidy. His first ball - unlike when he batted - was spot on and he didn't resort to firing the ball in at leg stump as so many modern spinners do. But as with the batting, he was brought on too late to make a difference.

Grayson - nicknamed Larry - has a more famous brother, Simon, who is a defender for Blackburn Rovers and is reportedly worth £3 million. If cricket had transfer fees, the man who left Yokshire for Essex wouldn't be worth a fraction of that - that's why he was about to start work for a Romford brewery when he was called up for England. But that said, Simon, 31, is unlikely to play for England's football team, whoever is persuaded to be the next coach.

Paul, who has become a useful one-day performer for Essex since joining them in 1995, only came into the party because Ashley Giles was injured, and because the England management, after putting Robert Croft on standby, had decided that slow left-arm was less likely than offspin to be cannon-fodder on the small Nairobi ground. If they had taken the decision a couple of days later, when Paul Wiseman had taken four wickets for New Zealand with his offspin, they might have come to a different conclusion.

Grayson was as surprised as anybody by his call-up and if the South Africa game is a one-off for him, he will treat it as a bonus. Team-mates describe him as a typical, dour Yorkshireman but he likes a giggle, which is obviously essential in the Essex dressing-room. He took only 10 Championship wickets this summer but his character shone through at crucial times, such as the National League Division Two match at Edgbaston in June. After making an unbeaten 41 in a total of 163 for 7, he then came on to bowl a crucial spell of three for 21 in nine overs to help Essex to a 24-run win over Warwickshire. He has become an expert bowler in the final few overs, or at the death as the players call it. Yesterday, alas, England lost so easily that the final few overs never came.

If Grayson's international career is over after one day, he joins an elite club of One-Day Wonders who are playing county cricket. Kim Barnett, the former Derbyshire captain who is now part of Gloucestershire's all-conquering one-day side, is surely the unluckiest man to have just a single limited-overs cap. There was no first-ball nought for him: he took 84 off Sri Lanka at The Oval in August 1988. But the winter tour never happened, because the Indian government took exception to the choice of Graham Gooch as captain, and the following summer, under David Gower, Barnett got a few more Tests but no one-day encore.

Mike Watkinson would have considered his single cap a bonus - just like those four precious Test caps he won under the regime of Ray Illingworth, who perhaps saw a little of himself in Watkinson's steady offspin and gritty batting. He saved a Test match with an unbeaten 80 against West Indies in 1995, but made less impact in his sole one-day game against South Afrcia the following winter - he didn't bat and bowled nine overs for 43.

Paul Taylor, the Northamptonshire left-arm seamer, played his one game in Sri Lanka in 1992-93. His record is very much like Grayson's - none for 20 off three overs. He did make a run, though.

Allan Wells is a member of both the One-Cap clubs. His single one-day appearance came against the West Indies at Lord's in 1995. As he pushes towards retirement at Kent, at least he can look back and say he made double figures (15).

The final member of the group, Graeme Swann, also of Northants, will argue that he has plenty of time on his side. He's only 21, but he evidently has some ground to make up after going on both the Test and one-day tour of South Africa last winter and bowling only five international overs, taking none for 24.

England's One-Test-Wonder-Club is, of course, more celebrated and Gavin Hamilton famously joined it last winter. He was set to emerge as a useful member of the one-day side after starring for Scotland in last summer's World Cup, but he won his only cap in the Test arena. And what a stunning appearance it was. He played in the first Test at Johannesburg, had figures of 15-1-63-0 and made a pair, caught by Shaun Pollock at slip off Allan Donald in both innings.

It was harsh on the guy - after all, England lost by an innings and 21 runs and Michael Atherton also made a pair ... nevertheless, he played no further part in the major fixtures on the tour.

Also in the club are Durham's Simon Brown (11 runs, 2 wickets), Gloucestershire's Mike Smith (4 runs, no wicket), Hampshire's John Stephenson (36 runs), and Wells again (3 runs). Warwickshire's Giles (17 runs, 1 wicket) is in there at the moment, but if he can get fit again, he has every chance of being booted out of the club this winter.

webTitle: Paul Jackson interview

fields.headline: Been there, done that, going down under
fields.standfirst:
BBC controller of entertainment Paul Jackson, who has been lured away by Granada Media to run its Australian operations, tells Jason Deans why the time was right to leave.
Jackson to join Granada Media Australia
fields.trailText:
BBC controller of entertainment Paul Jackson, who has been lured away by Granada Media to run its Australian operations, tells Jason Deans why the time was right to leave.
Jackson to join Granada Media Australia
fields.body:
BBC controller of entertainment Paul Jackson would have enjoyed working under new director general Greg Dyke, but Granada Media came along with the "very tempting" offer of running their Australian operations.

Mr Jackson, speaking this afternoon following his appointment as managing director of Granada Media Australia and chief executive of Granada/Seven Network joint venture Red Heart Productions, said it was "fairly well-known that I wasn't a Birtist and didn't agree with a lot of what went on" under previous director general John Birt.

By contrast, he added that he thought Dyke was doing a good job as director general and "in many ways would have enjoyed" continuing to work at the BBC.

But after four years running BBC entertainment, Mr Jackson said there was a sense of "been there, done that". He also felt "life is too short" to go through another BBC restructuring, following the April announcement that the entertainment department was to become part of a larger production unit, along with drama and children's, run by Alan Yentob.

Mr Jackson said: "It was against this background that Granada came along with this very tempting offer."

Mr Jackson said he was leaving BBC entertainment stronger than when he joined it, with more radio output and strong entertainment and comedy slates under David Young, and Geoffrey Perkins and Jon Plowman, respectively.

He starts his new Sydney-based job on November 1. The Granada Media role is split between overseeing the company's Australian business interests - which include broadband subsidiary Artsim and stakes in Seven Network and TV and film producer Village Roadshow - and growing Red Heart's production business. Mr Jackson said he would be looking at opportunities around the Pacific Rim, as well as drawing on his UK contacts.

Although the new job is based in Australia, Mr Jackson said he will be back in the UK "on a reasonably regular basis" and expects to be attending the Mip-TV, Mipcom and Natpe programming markets, as well as the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival. He will also continue to host Radio 4 interview show In Conversation With... .

webTitle: ITV news claim is blow to BBC

fields.headline: ITV news claim is blow to BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC suffered another setback in the TV news battle yesterday when advertising watchdogs ruled that ITV was justified in claiming that it broadcasts Britain's best news programmes.
fields.body:
The BBC suffered another setback in the TV news battle yesterday when advertising watchdogs ruled that ITV was justified in claiming that it broadcasts Britain's best news programmes.

In a press campaign this year, ITV claimed that "nobody does news better". The commercial network said it had the most popular newscasters, the best coverage and the deepest political insight.

The BBC objected, saying its news coverage won more plaudits and was more popular. ITV had made "superiority claims" that could not be substantiated, it alleged.

But the advertising standards authority ruled that, at the time of the advertising campaign, ITV had won one more television news and current affairs award than the BBC. The ruling provides further discomfort for the BBC, which is under fire for its decision to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm from next week.

"The authority noted the strong arguments made by the complainants for the quality of their news and current affairs programmes but concluded that claims such as 'nobody does news better' and 'the top stories' would be seen as an expression of the advertisers' opinion. The authority did not object to the advertisements."

One ITV executive described the BBC's complaint as "petty". A spokeswoman for the network added: "This must be rather embarassing for the BBC."

A spokesman for BBC News said last night that 3m more viewers watch its bulletins than ITV's. "We note that the ASA states that ITV's claims are an expression of its opinion. Viewers overwhelmingly choose BBC News over ITV News."

webTitle: Capital Radio calls for tighter regulation of BBC

fields.headline: Capital Radio demands tighter regulation of BBC
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Capital Radio is demanding tighter regulation of the BBC ahead of the publication of the government's communications white paper, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Capital Radio, the UK's largest commercial broadcaster, is demanding tighter regulation of the BBC ahead of the publication of the government's communications reform white paper.

The group has submitted a set of proposals to the Department of Trade & Industry that includes a demand for independent regulation of BBC Radio. Capital also wants clarification of the corporation's public service obligations and believes the BBC should be forced to comply with radio licence ownership guidelines.

Sally Oldham, strategy and development director of Capital Radio, said: "The BBC should be included in any measure of ownership legislation because it accounts for such a large share of this country's listening audience. We know it does not compete for revenue, but you cannot just leave it out there."

Capital also fears that the white paper, which will be published at the end of the year, will ignore the radio industry and concentrate on the TV sector.

Ms Oldham said: "Since the current legislation was introduced in 1990, we have been seeking to change it. It has always been out of date. I would be surprised if our concerns aren't met, but I know that TV is a far more dominant medium."

A key concern of the group is flexible legislation, as it looks to follow the consolidation process in the ITV network, which has seen three big players reduced to two. Capital currently vies for the commercial radio top spot with GWR and Emap. Capital wants the finer details of regulation to be left to the discretion of a single braodcasting and telecommunications regulator, with a radio division.

Ms Oldham added: "This regulation has to result in growth for our industry, and ownership is at the heart of that change. We would like to see relaxation of ownership rules to allow growth. At the moment we are regulated according to a points system, and most of the major players are close to the limit."

The group also wants the government to pay closer attention to the development of digital radio, claiming that allowing the roll-over of analogue licences to digital licences is not enough and that it is destabilising investment plans. Capital wants a date to be set for the switch-off of analogue services, and for more digital spectrum to be made available.

However, Capital's threefold demand of closer government attention to investment in digital radio, ownership and regulation does not include monitoring of internet radio. The group believes that the unlimited range of the internet means it should not be regulated.

webTitle: Four Feathers for almost-famous Kate

fields.headline: Four Feathers for almost-famous Kate
fields.trailText: Kate Hudson, currently wowing Stateside audiences and critics in Almost Famous, has turned down a number of big roles in favour of a period drama which has already been made six times
fields.body:
Kate Hudson, whose star is currently in the ascendant, has turned down a number of big roles in favour of a period drama which has already been made six times, seven if you count a 1977 TV movie based on the same material.

According to Yahoo News, the 21-year-old daughter of Goldie Hawn has signed up to appear in a remake of the war drama Four Feathers alongside American Beauty star Wes Bentley and Heath Ledger (of 10 Things I Hate About You fame).

Hudson turned down a lead role in the forthcoming big-budget Spiderman feature so she could work with Elizabeth director Shekhar Kapur on the project. She is currently receiving much critical acclaim in the States for her role as groupie Penny Lane in Cameron Crowe's Almost Famous (which opens here at the end of the year) and has recently worked with veteran director Robert Altman on Dr T and the Women.

Four Feathers tells the story of a British officer (Ledger) who walks away from his post just before a crucial battle. His three friends and fiancée (Hudson) give him white feathers as symbols of what they believe to be his cowardice, whereupon he attempts to redeem himself by infiltrating the enemy capital and freeing his captured comrades.

It will be the sixth time that AEW Mason's novel of the same name has been adapted for the big screen, the first being in 1915 and then in 1921, 1929, 1939 and 1955 (as "Storm Over the Nile"). The film begins shooting in Morocco on Tuesday.

webTitle: BSE fear from private slaughter of livestock by farmers

fields.headline: BSE fear from private slaughter of livestock by farmers
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The food standards watchdog, Sir John Krebs, yesterday suggested that BSE-infected meat could still be finding its way into food, 11 years after controls to prevent it.
fields.body:
The food standards watchdog, Sir John Krebs, yesterday suggested that BSE-infected meat could still be finding its way into food, 11 years after controls to prevent it.

He disclosed official fears that farmers were bypassing health checks on beef and other meat, and warned consumers to buy only from "reputable sources".

Sir John, chairman of the food standards agency, is trying to establish the extent before seeking tighter rules governing so-called private kills by farmers, and so that new rules on the use of unlicensed abattoirs can be considered by its board next month. His officials admit they have "anecdotal information" rather than evidence.

Vets voiced their concerns to the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, 18 months ago. But yesterday these concerns that beef and sheep products could slip through the anti-BSE net stunned members of the government's scientific watchdog, the spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee.

Seventy-seven people have so far died from the human form of the disease in Britain, seven others have been identi fied as having the fatal condition, and monthly bulletins show the number of victims to be rising steadily,

Peter Smith, chairman of the advisory committee, said: "I don't recall having any data on unlicensed sale of such meat. I don't recall it as being brought to our attention. webTitle: AOL-Time Warner merger approved - with conditions

fields.headline: AOL-Time Warner merger approved - with conditions
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The European Commission has today approved the merger between internet company AOL and Time Warner, on condition that the companies will not compete unfairly with media and entertainment rivals.
fields.body:
The European Commission has today approved the merger between internet company AOL and Time Warner, on condition that the companies will not compete unfairly with media and entertainment rivals.

In a statement, the commission said AOL is to sever its structural links with German media giant Bertelsmann.

Sources said the EU antitrust authorities only formally endorsed the merger after the companies agreed to several concessions, including ending ties with Bertelsmann, Europe's biggest media company.

That move will prevent AOL "from having access to Europe's leading source of music publishing rights, thereby eliminating the risk of dominance in the emerging markets for on-line delivery of music over the internet and software-based music players," it said.

The companies also have provided guarantees that they will not unfairly discriminate against other companies that provide internet content or within the music industry.

With the guarantees, the commission voted to approve the deal. EU authorities made quick progress on the issue after Time Warner last week dropped a separate joint venture plan with EMI Group of Britain, which would have created a major music company. European regulators had strongly opposed that deal.

webTitle: Missing girls: body found

fields.headline: Missing girls: body found
fields.trailText: Police searching for two girls swept into a Yorkshire river yesterday have found a body.
fields.body:
Police searching for two girls swept into a Yorkshire river yesterday have found a body.

The discovery was made about a mile downstream from the spot in Stainforth Beck, near Settle, north Yorkshire, where they went missing. The two had been "river-walking" with 13 other pupils and two teachers from the Royds school in Oulton, west Yorkshire.

They were all walking upstream in the beck when one of the girls got her foot stuck between stones, and lost her balance when her boot came off.

A teacher tried to steady her, as did another student, but the girl fell over, dragging the other student with her. Both were swept away.

The two girls have been named as Rochelle Cauvet, 14, and Hannah Black, 13, both from Leeds.

Two inquiries were under way today into how the tragedy happened.

The beck, usually about 10 metres across and two metres deep, had been swollen throughout the day by rainwater from overnight storms.

It lies at the western edge of the Yorkshire Dales in the shadow of Pen-y-ghent and close to the Settle and Carlisle railway line.

The area is popular with walkers, cavers and school parties, but rivers in a landscape famous for its limestone rocks can turn from streams to torrents after the kind of continuous rain which has fallen for the past three days.

Police said the group of 15 boys and girls had been out river-walking as part of a week-long school trip to the Yorkshire Dales.

webTitle: Vodafone sheds subsidiary

fields.headline: Vodafone sheds its Italian Infostrada subsidiary
fields.trailText: 11.45am: UK mobile phone giant Vodafone has sold its Italian Infostrada subsidiary for E11bn (£6.6bn), writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Vodafone, the UK mobile phone giant which refuses to stand still, kept up its frenzied pace of activity by selling its Italian Infostrada subsidiary for E11bn (£6.6bn).

The telecoms company was snapped up by Enel, Italy's state-owned electricity group, which will merger the operator into Wind, Enel's telecoms joint venture with France Telecom. Vodafone said it will spend the proceeds of the sale, which still needs shareholder and regulatory clearance, on reducing the group's debt levels.

Vodafone acquired Infostrada in February as part of its £104bn merger with German rival Mannesmann.

Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone, said: "This transaction will raise considerably more cash with greater certainty than we could have achieved in an IPO and is in the best interests of share our shareholders."

Vodafone's shares fell 3%, or 7p, to 240.5p in early trading, on typically heavy turnover of 54m shares. The telecoms sector was hit by last night's falls in the US Nasdaq index.

webTitle: Reuters faces an embarrassing lawsuit

fields.headline: Reuters faces discrimination and bullying case
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Reuters faces an embarrassing lawsuit accusing the company of sexual discrimination and bullying. By Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Reuters faces an embarrassing lawsuit in which two senior managers could be subpoenaed to appear as witnesses in a case accusing the company of sexual discrimination and bullying.

The case will also raise questions about Reuters' internet strategy.

A hearing will be held tomorrow, at which it will be decided whether Reuters chief executive officer Peter Job and ITN chairman Mark Wood are to be called as hostile witnesses at the tribunal.

Former Reuters journalists Kim Usher and Jonathan Birt are suing the company for unfair dismissal after a Reuters subsidiary internet project, called Project Sunrise, was canned earlier this year.

Ms Usher and Mr Birt will argue that Reuters failed to give them adequate notice that their jobs were at risk, and then failed to give them jobs in the company that matched their salary levels.

Ms Usher will also claim she was a victim of sexual discrimination, and will give evidence suggesting female journalists and managers have suffered from a masculine culture. Reuters has no women on its 12-strong board.

The case will also put Reuters' internet strategy under the spotlight. Slower to materialise than many of its rivals' strategies, it has faced criticism from many sections of the industry.

Instinet, the retail service of Reuters' global internet brokerage, has been delayed by technical hitches.

The company was this morning one of the biggest casualties in the wave of uncertainty sweeping the technology sector. Shares tumbled 6.8%, or 172p, to 1091p in early trading.

Reuters declined to comment on the legal case.

webTitle: Hollywood banishes the critics that bite

fields.headline: Hollywood banishes the critics that bite
fields.standfirst: But Get Carter gets panned as the studios' tactics backfire
fields.trailText: Film studios are releasing their worst movies without letting critics preview them in hopes of avoiding a mauling, but the tactic has backfired in the case of the Stallone remake of Get Carter
fields.body:
Film reviewers in America have begun to complain bitterly that film studios are adopting a new tactic to avoid their worst movies receiving a mauling: they are releasing them without letting critics see them.

The latest example of the tactic was the release of the remake of Get Carter - originally a 1971 British gangster movie set in Newcastle and starring Michael Caine; now a violent thriller set in present-day Seattle, starring Sylvester Stallone.

The film was premiered in Los Angeles last week but critics were not given a screening which meant that the weekly entertainment guides around the US had no chance to warn cinemagoers how bad the movie is.

At the premiere in Westwood, Los Angeles, last week the audience was mainly made up of cast and crew who cheered every name in the credits and giggled every time Stallone punched someone to a pulp. Critics who caught up with it after it opened in cinemas have found it less entertaining.

Warner Brothers, at the request of the producers, Franchise Pictures, did not offer advance screenings as is normal.

Most critics were unable to review the film before it came out for its first weekend, the period which can make or break a picture. The studios hope that by maximising their advertising they can get round a potential drubbing.

In a review that appeared in the New York Times last Saturday, after the film had opened, Elvis Mitchell wrote: "It's so minimally plotted that not only does it lack context and subtext but it also may be the world's first movie without even a text." He reported audience members filing out within half an hour of the film starting.

It appears that this was repeated in other cinemas outside New York: the box office takings for Get Carter hovered around the $6.7m mark, less than a quarter of the other main film released this weekend, Meet The Parents, a comedy starring Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro. Variety rated Get Carter's takings an "unimpressive bow".

Earlier this year the films Autumn in New York, starring Winona Ryder and Richard Gere, and Highlander: Endgame were also not shown to critics. Another film, Bless the Child, featuring Kim Basinger, was only shown at the last moment and could not be reviewed by the monthly and weekly publications.

Scott Brown of Entertainment Weekly has called the trend "disturbing" and asks if "this critic-dissing phenom is reaching critical mass". He argues that studios cannot afford to alienate too many of the critics even although an increasing number of people are now taking their reviews from internet sites that make a speciality of passing on early warnings on duff films.

The prominent critic Roger Ebert says that it is clear why certain films are not given a critical screening: "The studio has concluded that the film is not good and will receive negative reviews. All other explanations are diplomatic lies."

But Mr Brown argues that shunning the press is a gamble as studios ultimately depend on the goodwill of people who are trusted by readers.

It is the third time a film has been made of the novel Jack's Return Home by Ted Lewis. The best-known version remains the 1971 film, directed by Mike Hodges. Its star, Michael Caine, appears in a smaller role in the latest film as a ruthless British criminal.

webTitle: Home Office to target car crime

fields.headline: Government launches £8m car crime reduction campaign
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R is launching an £8m nationwide multi-media campaign for the Home Office today aimed at reducing the level of car crime across the country, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R is launching an £8m nationwide multi-media campaign for the Home Office today aimed at reducing the level of car crime across the country. The campaign, the government's first in more than four years, will run for three years and include television, radio, press and poster advertising as well as a range of leaflets, posters and other promotional material. The campaign plays a key role in helping the government achieve its target of reducing car crime by 30 per cent by 2004.

The TV ads will illustrate how cars can be made appealing to break into - either for belongings or the car itself and will carry the line "Crime. Let's bring it down".

Speaking about the launch Home Secretary Jack Straw said: "This campaign is about the simple action motorists and their passengers can take to outsmart the thief - parking in safe areas, using alarms and immobilisers, shutting windows, locking doors and not leaving things on display, will help deter the car criminal."

fields.headline: Boxman faces closure 'within two weeks'
fields.standfirst: Boxman suspends website
fields.trailText:
11.15 update:Online music retailer Boxman faces voluntary liquidation within two weeks unless a rescue package is found, writes Amy Vickers.

Boxman suspends website
fields.body:
Online music retailer Boxman has confirmed it faces voluntary liquidation within the next two weeks unless a rescue package is found.

In a statement Boxman said: "The board of Boxman.com plc is disappointed to report that the company has been unable to complete its current round of funding. The directors of the company's principal subsidiaries, Boxman UK Limited and Boxman AB, will also be seeking liquidation for these companies in the week commencing October 23."

In the meantime, trading has been suspended pending the outcome of talks regarding the potential sale of these companies.

The group attracted around 750,000 customers and revenues of £12.7m in 1999.

webTitle: Levi website goes to Good Technology

fields.headline: Good Technology bags Levi Strauss online task
fields.trailText: 11am: Web agency Good Technology has picked up the pan-European project for the development of a Levi Strauss e-commerce website, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Web agency Good Technology has picked up the pan-European project for the development of a Levi Strauss e-commerce website, following a four-way pitch against Blueberry, Oyster Partners and Red Sky Interactive.

Lateral, which has worked on the account for the past five years, said it did not pitch for the account and was still working on the global Vintage Clothing brand and has recently picked up the US Silvertab brief and developed lostbutnotlost.com for the brand.

The pan-European e-commerce brief is not understood to include the brief for an online campaign which is still up for grabs, or the Industrial Clothing Design which is with Tomato. Jon Bains, chairman of Lateral, said Levi's was now, like most clients, adopting a policy of not having a new media agency of record and appointing agencies on a project-by-project basis.

Bains added: "We're enthused by the opportunities we're getting presented with in the States and very proud of the fact that every single campaign we've done for Levi's has won awards." The pitch was called for by Levi incumbent agency Bartle Boggle Hegarty and run by creative director of digital media Steph Shaw.

Sources close to the pan-European e-commerce project expressed their surprise that BBH and Levi's opted to go with Good Tech given Blueberry's stronger e-commerce credentials.
