webTitle: Obituary: John Bishop

fields.headline: John Bishop
fields.standfirst: Publisher who gave a platform to 20th-century music and poetry
fields.trailText: In 1970, the industrial journalist John Bishop, who has died aged 69, founded Thames Publishing - initially to publish the music of his wife, Betty Roe.
fields.body:
In 1970, the industrial journalist John Bishop, who has died aged 69, founded Thames Publishing - initially to publish the music of his wife, Betty Roe. Under his guidance, the firm's output expanded to include a wide range of the work of British composers, particularly in the field of 20th-century vocal music.

There was a comprehensive series of the songs of Frank Bridge, John Ireland and Peter Warlock; lesser-known composers deserving recognition included Dennis Browne and Robin Milford, and there were anthologies, such as the ongoing series, A Century Of English Song, published in collaboration with the Association of English Singers and Speakers.

John was also convinced there was an appetite for books about British music and musicians, too small to interest established book publishers, but large enough for a smaller company. Today, Thames has a catalogue of 74 titles, with many more waiting in the wings. He was brilliant at spotting gaps, finding the right authors to fill them, and producing increasingly attractive books, most of them being the only substantial sources of information on their subjects.

In 1971, John founded Autolycus Press as an outlet for poetry. He had already compiled, and had published by John Baker, three anthologies, reflecting his particular enthusiasms, Wise, Wanton, Womanly (1967), Music And Sweet Poetry (1968), and London Between The Lines (1973). He had a flair for finding good material. An early Autolycus publication was a slim volume of his own poems, I From My Small Corner, which graphically, and often touchingly, evoked such topics as the anxieties of adolescence, or London life in the 1960s and 1970s.

John was born at Norbury, south London, the son of a tax inspector father and a creditable amateur pianist mother. He attended Whitgift middle school, Croydon, leaving in 1947 after one year in the sixth form, where his subjects - English and economics - were to prove valuable. He also took part in revues with the Mitre Players, and there met his future wife, then a young cellist and composer. John wrote very good revue songs, but gave up on seeing his wife's natural grasp of the medium.

On leaving school, he joined the Shell oil company, working first on the company's international magazine, then as founding editor of its London staff newspaper, and in the employee information division. In 1973, he moved to Pearl Assurance as founding editor of its house journal, and later manager of the company information unit.

He also freelanced, editing the Duke of Edinburgh's Award journal, Sir Robert Mayer's Youth And Music magazine, and the London Philharmonic Choir's newsletter. In the early 1970s, he wrote sleeve-notes, and was responsible for the design and production of sleeves and advertising for Unicorn Records. webTitle: Martha Lane Fox interview

fields.headline: Lastminute changes to put retailer "back in the big picture"
fields.standfirst: Lastminute turns to ex-Asda chief
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Martha Lane Fox, the chief operating officer of lastminute.com, expects the appointment of a former supermarket boss to put the beleaguered online retailer "back in the big picture". By Dan Milmo.
Lastminute turns to ex-Asda chief
fields.body:
Martha Lane Fox, the chief operating officer of lastminute.com, expects the appointment of a former supermarket boss to put the beleaguered online retailer "back in the big picture".

Ms Fox spoke to MediaGuardian.co.uk following the appointment of former Asda chief executive Allan Leighton as non-executive chairman of the company. She denied that Mr Leighton was chosen for his wealth of offline retail experience.

"It is not just about offline. He is very web-literate, has a fantastic amount of experience and will bring some fantastic ideas to lastminute," said Ms Fox.

She confirmed that Mr Leighton will have a "hands on" role on the lastminute board, and will take over from present chairman Pieter Bouw on October 20.

She added: "His role will be multi-faceted. He will do everything from helping us grow our customer base and revenues to guiding us through our operational challenges. He will bring a fantastic perspective to the company and put us back in the big picture."

Lastminute's share price has languished since the company's stock floated at 380p in March. Shares fell 1.5%, or 7.5p, to 135.5p in early trading.

webTitle: Yahoo! results upstaged by Lucent profits warning

fields.headline: Yahoo! results upstaged by Lucent profits warning
fields.standfirst: ISPs hope for positive Yahoo! results
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Yahoo! has failed to boost technology stocks, after its solid third quarter figures were upstaged by a profits warning from Lucent. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
US internet giant Yahoo! has failed to boost embattled technology stocks on both sides of the Atlantic, after its solid third quarter figures were upstaged by a profits warning from telecoms company Lucent Technologies.

Yahoo! said revenue rose to $295.5m (£204m) from $155.8m (£100.8m) for the same period last year, with pre-tax earnings up from $11.1m to $47.7m. However, there was disappointment with the all-important advertising figures, with the number of clients falling from 3,675 to 3,450 due to a subdued European market.

The figures were in line with Wall Street expectations, but did little to calm the jitters in technology stocks.

Analysts said the results were good, but did not show enough upside to turn around the negative sentiment enveloping European technology stocks. They pointed to the slowing growth in e-commerce revenues and an increase in the proportion of marketing growth to revenue - to 37%.

The technology-rich Nasdaq index closed down 115 points at 3,240.54, filtering through to the FTSE 100, which was down 48.4 points at 6,199.30 in early trading.

The Techmark index, the benchmark for UK technology stocks, shed 82.57 points at 3,536.31.

The main victims were again European internet service providers, with T-Online of Germany falling 2.75% to E22.6 (1357p) and Wanadoo of France tumbling 4.6% to E12.85.

Investors' fears were compounded by the warning from telecoms equipment maker Lucent, which said fourth quarter profits would be lower than expected due to falling sales in telephone switch equipment. TMT stocks in the US and Europe have been battered over the past month by profit warnings from sector big hitters such as Sprint and Intel.

Mobile phone maker Motorola added further momentum to the downward spiral by reporting a 66% increase in third quarter operating earnings, although it revealed slowing growth in its core cellphone business.

webTitle: Windies get what they expect in Kenya

fields.headline: Windies get what they expect in Kenya
fields.trailText:
South Africa yesterday put England's summer success against the West Indies
into its proper perspective. Yes, Nasser Hussain's men should be proud about
finally regaining the Wisden Trophy. But the ICC Knockout has shown (a) the
Windies are one of the most beatable sides in world cricket now, except when
they play at home where their record remains good; and (b) England are not
there yet. They still have a lot of work to do before they can compete with
the best in the world.
fields.body:
South Africa yesterday put England's summer success against the West Indies
into its proper perspective. Yes, Nasser Hussain's men should be proud about
finally regaining the Wisden Trophy. But the ICC Knockout has shown (a) the
Windies are one of the most beatable sides in world cricket now, except when
they play at home where their record remains good; and (b) England are not
there yet. They still have a lot of work to do before they can compete with
the best in the world.

But let's talk about West Indies. Knocked out by Sri Lanka in the
preliminary round, they were the only one of cricket's big nine not to make
the last eight. They selected a radically different team. Chairman of
selectors Mike Findlay said they were resting three players: Adrian Griffith
(can live with that), Franklyn Rose (erm, OK) and Ridley Jacobs (don't like
that). But the changes went further than that - only seven who toured
England made the trip. The selectors clearly saw the tournament as more of
an opportunity to have a look at young talent like the 19-year-old Jamaican
allrounder Marlon Samuels and 20-year-old Antiguan fast bowler Kerry Jeremy,
than a chance to win a trophy. As John McEnroe might say, they could not be
serious.

The older guys they did take tell another story. Wicketkeeper-batsman
Courtney Brown has some reasonable recent form for Barbados, as has
allrounder Laurie Williams for Jamaica. But they're not new, both having
played for the Windies a few years ago, and both are around 30. Taking them
to Kenya served no purpose. It certainly couldn't be to have a look at
players whose international credentials they already knew - decent but
modest performers. If they
wanted more experience around the kids, they should have gone for Jacobs and
Rose, who had a long enough rest after England and wouldn't have been harmed
playing in one of the world's shorter one-day competitions.

This then was a team that went to Kenya with low expectations. Still their
fans expected better. Losing to Sri Lanka is no disgrace - they're a very
attractive side and I'd travel to the moon to watch them play. But they are
not the force they were in 1996 - they were themselves swept aside in the
next game by Pakistan - and getting beaten by 108 runs in a one-day match
is the equivalent of a 5-0 walloping at football. Even Venus Williams, who's
forgotten how to lose, can expect to work harder for her victories. The
fielding was appalling even by the Windies' recent low standards: they
seemed determined to keep the matchwinner Gunawardene at the crease, by
refusing to take the catches he offered.

Brian Lara's form and state of mind continues to be a worry. He'll miss the
Windies domestic one-day competition, the Red Stripe Bowl, because he's
injured. He cannot say whether that'll be for the whole competition. You
can't play if you're not fit, but I thought it was interesting that the TnT
team manager said they never expected to have Lara anyway, because the
Windies might have progressed in the ICC Knockout. I believe his mind is not
completely on his game, and injury or no injury, TnT are not too surprised
to be without him again. He certainly looked out of sorts in falling for
only 5 against Sri Lanka.

So have the team that used to rule the world at one-day cricket sunk even
lower with this first-round exit? Yes and no. Yes, because of the margin of
defeat and the sheer poverty of the performance. No, because of the quality
of the opposition, and the obviously low expectations of the selectors. This
team got what they expected in Kenya - nothing. But all the same, they
could not have contemplated such a humbling exit. They spent longer flying
to Nairobi than playing there. Don't unfasten your seatbelts, guys: there is
more turbulence ahead.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

webTitle: England go for broke

fields.headline: England go for broke
fields.standfirst:
New coach by Christmas
Finns taking the mickey
fields.trailText: David Lacey weighs up the implications of Howard Wilkinson's team selection as Emile Heskey, Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole are given the nod for tonight's match.
fields.body:
Howard Wilkinson does not seem to share the caretaker's passion for locking doors. For England's World Cup qualifier against Finland in the Olympic stadium here tonight he is putting his faith more in cannons and a drawbridge while trusting the opposition do not discover how shallow the moat in midfield really is.

Wilkinson, in temporary charge after Kevin Keegan's resignation in the wake of Saturday's 1-0 defeat by Germany, can certainly not be accused of erring on the side of caution. Few could have expected that he would pick three strikers or, if he did, that Michael Owen would not be one of them.

Yet Teddy Sheringham, who was always likely to play once Wilkinson had called him into the squad, and even more likely to resume his Manchester United partnership with Andrew Cole, has also been joined by Emile Heskey, whose only other start for England was the friendly against Argentina in February.

Wilkinson explained his choice of the 22-year-old, tumble-prone Liverpool striker by saying he was among "those who would give England the best chance of producing the sort of performance that we want to see". Since all team selections are based on this principle it was not saying much.

Clearly Wilkinson sees the 34-year-old Sheringham's ability to link the play as the key to England's chances of softening the blow of Saturday's result by beating the Finns. "He's proved he's a winner," the coach said yesterday, "and his record with Manchester United shows he can deal with occasions like this and perform well."

Sheringham, who last appeared for England in a European Championship qualifier in Bulgaria 16 months ago, merely observed that he had never given up hope of a recall. "If I ever give that hope up," he added, "I'll let you know."

Wilkinson was giving no clues as to what his formation will be. With these players he could have three at the back and five in midfield but the more likely system would see Phil Neville recalled on the right of a back four, his brother Gary having dropped out with a damaged toe. Robbie Fowler, too, was released by Wilkinson.

For the younger Neville this will be his first international since giving away the late penalty in Charleroi that enabled Romania to beat England and send them home early from Euro 2000, yet Wilkinson has not thought it necessary to give the player a lift. "If anyone's able to do that it has to be Alex Ferguson," he said.

The probability is that Neville and Gareth Barry will be the full-backs, with Martin Keown and Gareth Southgate the two central defenders. The amount of pressure they will come under will be determined by the extent of the improvement in England's midfield compared with the first half against the Germans, when it all but melted away.

Finland are not as strong as Germany, but if Jari Litmanen is allowed the time and space granted to Dietmar Hamann at Wembley he will cause just as much damage. With this in mind the prospect of England being guarded by Dennis Wise and Paul Scholes in central midfield is worrying. Whatever system Wilkinson decides to use, his decision to play three strikers must weaken England defensively.

Ray Parlour, who will augment Wise and Scholes, is the only specialist tackler outside the back four. He has not been in an England starting line-up since the 6-0 win over Luxembourg at Wembley at the start of last season but on form he could be crucial.

So much depends on England setting a higher tempo than on Saturday and retaining the more confident passing patterns of the second half, when Keegan replaced Gary Neville with Kieron Dyer and switched to a five-man midfield. Even then Cole and Owen received only intermittent service, a fault Sheringham may rectify for Cole and Heskey.

Wilkinson believes that, if the attitude and performance are right, England will win. "There's nothing wrong with disappointment, but self-pity, whingeing, not having the self-respect or the pride to stand up and deal with disappointment... these are things we want to get out of the way. There is still a lot to play for. In the last World Cup qualifiers we lost at home to Italy and people were picking the flesh off a dead animal. But we qualified then and it's still possible now."

England have yet to lose to Finland, winning eight out of nine meetings, and the hurt will be widely felt if they do so tonight. Provided Sheringham can reproduce the form he showed under Glenn Hoddle in awkward away qualifiers and Cole responds as he does for Manchester United, the depressing events of the past four days will begin to recede.

Finland (probable): Niemi; Saarinen, Hyypia, Uha, Tihinen; Litmanen, Nurmela, Kolkka, Valakari; Johansson, Forssell.

webTitle: Sky launches 9pm bulletin

fields.headline: The nine o'clock news - from Sky
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Sky News is moving into the timeslot vacated by the BBC's Nine O'Clock News by launching its own 9pm bulletin from next Monday. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sky News is capitalising on the moving of the BBC's Nine O'Clock News with the launch of its own 9pm bulletin from next Monday.

The programme will be presented by Jeremy Thompson. Sky's seasoned presenter will "do a Kirsty", moving around the newsroom with live reports superimposed behind him. The bulletin will feature more live reports than Sky's existing 10pm news programme.

Sky's head of news, Nick Pollard, said "Our nine o'clock news will be an overview of the world at nine. We see the bulletin as a portal to allow disillusioned former BBC Nine O'Clock News viewers - used to watching the news at a set time - to make the transition to Sky News, where they can access news where and when it suits them".

There will be a half-hour of rolling news between the end of the 9pm news and the beginning of the 10pm bulletin,

Sky will maintain its 10pm bulletin with Bob Friend and Anna Botting. A spokesman said the 9pm news would not go head-to-head with the 10pm bulletin, with the 10pm news adhering to a more formal news style.

The programme will be launch edited by Jonathan Warner.

We see the bulletin as a portal to allow disillusioned former BBC Nine O'Clock News viewers - used to watching the news at a set time - to make the transition to Sky News, where they can access news where and when it suits them". There will be a half-hour of rolling news between the end of the 9pm news and the beginning of the 10pm bulletin, Sky will maintain its 10pm bulletin with Bob Friend and Anna Botting. A spokesman said the 9pm news would not go head-to-head with the 10pm bulletin, with the 10pm news adhering to a more formal news style. The programme will be launch edited by Jonathan Warner.

webTitle: Music retailer Boxman suspends website

fields.headline: Music retailer Boxman suspends website
fields.trailText: 10am: Pan-European music retailer Boxman has suspended its website after attempts failed to raise more funds, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Pan-European music retailer Boxman has suspended its website after attempts to raise more funds ended in failure.

Boxman.com, the Swedish-founded online music retailer, was trying to raise more than £30m to stay in business following the cancellation of its planned IPO back in April. Chief executive Tony Salter said there was a 50:50 chance of a rescue package being put together and that he was in talks with at least one potential buyer.

Boxman planned to raise funds by issuing new stock to shareholders at a heavily discounted price, although it is believed that shareholders -including Bernard Arnault and Alain Levy, former president of PolyGram, and musicians from bands Madness, Roxette and Ace of Base - rejected the idea.

Before suspending operations on Monday the company was understood to be burning through almost £2m each month. However, Boxman was starting to record reasonable sales and brought in £5.8m in the first half of this year.

Despite its small staff base - it only employs 71 staff - Boxman had managed to build itself up into one of Europe's three largest internet CD retailers, competing with Amazon and BOL. In its expansion drive, Boxman bought UK rival IMVS, which had only recently rebranded as Yalplay, at the end of last year, but branding and integration issues plagued acceptance of the retailer while rivals fought to build up market share.

In April, Mother and Media Insight were appointed to handle a £4m high-profile marketing campaign in the UK.

webTitle: Lastminute hires former Asda chief

fields.headline: Lastminute hires former Asda chief
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Lastminute.com has appointed former Asda chief executive Allan Leighton to its board, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online travel firm Lastminute.com has appointed the former chief executive of the Asda supermarket chain to its board.

Allan Leighton, who is also a non-executive director of satellite broadcaster BSkyB, will take over from Pieter Bouw on October 20 and "play an active role".

Mr Leighton is a senior figure in the European retail sector, having become president of Wal-Mart's continental operations after the US supermarket giant took over Asda in 1999.

Martha Lane Fox, chief operating officer of Lastminute, said: "We are thrilled that someone with Allan's track-record of leadership in customer-focused businesses is joining Lastminute. Alan is someone we have respected for some time."

Lastminute is ringing the changes following its March flotation, which saw the company's shares hit a high of 555p. The stock has since plummeted to below 150p, despite the well-received £58.9m acquisition in August of French rival Degriftour.

In its last set of results for the three months to June, Lastminute said pre-tax losses had narrowed from £11m to £9.2m, on turnover of £1.1m. The company has around £100m in cash left in the bank.

The shares remained in the doldrums this morning, falling 2.2%, or 8.5p, to 134.5p.

 Interview with Martha Lane Fox to follow later today...

webTitle: Z Group to launch in UK

fields.headline: Z Group to launch in UK
fields.trailText: 10am: Sergio Zyman, former chief marketing officer at Coca-Cola, is to launch his Z Group marketing consultancy in the UK, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sergio Zyman, former chief marketing officer at Coca-Cola, is to launch his Z Group marketing consultancy in the UK.

Michael Harrison, a former vice-president at Procter & Gamble, has been appointed head of Z Group Europe, which will next month launch an advertising campaign through Ogilvy & Mather.

The company's founding clients include the Internet Capital Group, pasta maker Barilla and an unnamed British retailer.

Mr Zyman said: "The continuing demand in the European community for fresh, constructive marketing guidance led us to open Z Group Europe. But I knew we would need a leader here who possessed not only the sharpest marketing skills but sensitivity to the diverse cultural and distinct business environments of Europe.

"Mike has precisely the executive background and experience to bring Z Group to this market."

Mr Zyman, who describes himself as "the accidental techie", said he was forced to take a crash course in the internet after he left Coke in 1998 because of the demand for his consultancy services among e-commerce companies.

The news coincides with the publication of Mr Zyman's new book, Building Brandwidth: Closing the Sale Online, which looks at how ineffective marketing is holding companies back in the digital age.

fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The BBC suffered a setback in the TV news battle when the Advertising Standards Authority ruled that ITV was justified in claiming it had the best broadcast news. (p11)

Richard Madeley took the blame for wife Judy's "popping-out" incident. She revealed her ample bosom to "millions" live on television at the National TV Awards. (p11)

Yahoo!'s results buck the "dot.com bubble" trend, but the online service revealed it had lost 200 online advertisers in three months. (p27).

The EC is expected to clear the AOL/Time Warner merger today. (p29)

Cash-strapped online retailers are forced "to the brink" of redundancy according to a survey published yesterday by Goldfish. (p29).

THE INDEPENDENT

The Data Protection Commissioner, Elizabeth France, has issued a code of conduct containing strict guidelines to monitor employers' monitoring of their employees emails. Industry leaders claim the body will be completely at odds with new powers - under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill - granted to companies, allowing them to monitor private electronic communications. (p6)

In Business Review, Gabi Thesing looks at the future of 3G mobile phone licences (p2).

Kate Bulkley interviews RTL chief executive Didier Bellens about his strategy for expanding the group's TV interests through the UK (via Channel 5) and southern Europe (throught Telefonica). (p3)

Jenny Watt, PA to Paul Robinson, MD of Disney UK, gives an insight into her boss's working life. (p7)

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

The government is considering a plan which would require all digital broadcasters to carry the main terrestrial TV channels. (p2).

Ulster politicians were united last night in slamming the BBC's Panorama for naming the suspects in the Omagh bombing. They say naming them will not help the process of bringing them to justice. (p4)

The US has rejected a package of guidelines set out by the United Nations' telecoms agency, the ITU, aiming to standardise and lower the costs imposed by telecoms companies for connecting international calls. (p12)

The US telecoms regulator, the FCC, has accused television broadcasters of duplicity for lobbying for free digital bandwidth where mobile phone providers were paying a premium for the same service. (p14)

Louise Kehoe reports on the increase in brand abuse by "cybercriminals". (p17)

Parent company France Telecom is expected to have to pay around £268m in extra cash to Orange when it floats later this year, due to a sharp fall in the mobile operator's share price. (p28)

Printing group St Ives is ascribing much of its increased profits, reported yesterday, to the growth of its e-commerce division. (p30)
Yahoo!'s third quarter results, announced yesterday, with the company's profits going from £20m to £67m, were in line with expectations but represented disappointing growth for analysts.(p33).

T-Online's planned acquisition of I-D Media has hit an unexpected glitch following a disagreement over the new management structure. (p34).

THE TIMES

Panorama reporter John Ware has declined an offer from the BBC for protection, following his controversial Monday programme, in which the names of the four Omagh bomb suspects were named. (p5)

The Times runs a leader condemning the BBC for its decision to move Panorama, in spite of Monday's programme. (p21)

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

France Telecom is nearing a deal to acquire Equant. (p1)

Deutsche Bank has announced an offer for US-based online broker National Discount Brokers' Group. (p1)

The EC is expected to clear the AOL/Time Warner merger today. (p4)BR> Yahoo!'s third-quarter earnings were in line with expectations. (p5)

EM.TV finance director Florian Haffa confirmed that he is leaving the company, following the news earlier this week that the company's shares have fallen nearly 40% in value. (p5)

THE SUN

The Sun splashes on Judy Finnigan's embarrassing faux-pas at last night's National TV awards. The Queen of Daytime revealed her ample bosom to "millions",writes Emily Smith, when she collected the Most Popular Daytime Programme award at the Royal Albert Hall. (p1)

EastEnders' long-serving nice guy Mark Fowler will be told by a doctor next week that his HIV life sentence has been lifted, giving him a further 30 years. (p3).

The paper gives extensive coverage of the awards ceremony on pages 3 and 4, complete with a round-up of the winners and pictures of various lovelies .

Dominic Mohan reveals that Chris Evans has finally quit TFI Friday in Bizarre.

(p19).

DAILY TELEGRAPH

The paper reports that the BBC's Panorama has drawn "battle lines". (p4) Swimmer Eric "the Eel" Moussambani made it to the Sun's National Television Awards last night in spite of the ongoing diplomatic row. (p5)

The Advertising Standards Authority has said ITV's claim "Nobody Does It Better" was justified, because its news programmes had won more programmes than the BBC. (p5)

THE MIRROR

The Mirror also celebrates the exposure of Judy Finnigan's boobs. (p1 and p13)

THE DAILY MAIL

The usually respectable Mail stops short of splashing on Judy, but can't resist a front-page photograph. (p1), with a full report on page 3.

The Mail's diary notes that the Telegraph's chief executive Dan Colson is expected to give staff a ticking off for their continued campaign of complaints against cost-cutting in the staff canteen. (p17).
And the diary wouldn't be complete without a final dig at beleaguered Andrew Marr, the BBC's political editor, who has quit his post on the government's Commission on the Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain. (p5)

ITV sports anchor Des Lynam is linked to an ongoing stalking case involving an "international footballer".

The Mail says the BBC was "emphatically right" to broadcast the names of the Omagh suspects on Monday's Panorama. (p21)

THE EXPRESS

The paper goes big on Judy's chest. (p3)

The Express's Brutus notes that the Mirror's 3am girls have been given a makeover, following disparaging remarks made by celebrities. (p9)

AND FINALLY...

THE STAR

Melinda pips Judy to the front page of the Star in a silver sequinned dress. (p1)

The Star looks forward to the release of no-holds-barred Big Brother Uncut with a shot of Sada and Nichola snogging. (p11)

And The Royle Family's Ricky Tomlinson has swapped his "humble home" for a posh riverside apartment. (p21)

fields.standfirst: Published on October 11.
fields.trailText: October 11: ISBA is to allow media owners to join its ranks for the first time in its 100-year history.
fields.body:
ISBA is to allow media owners to join its ranks for the first time in its 100-year history. Speaking at the marketing launch for next year's ITV schedule, ITV marketing chief, John Hardie has told 1000 of the UK's leading advertisers and agencies that the network plans an aggressive fight back against a more commercially driven BBC.

Levi's is planning to sell clothes through its European website for the first time as it tries to boost flagging sales.

The BBC has announced its shortlist of roster agencies which includes Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters, Fallon, Leagas Delaney, Publicis and TBWA. Jean Paul Gaultier is to front a new ad campaign for Renault.

UBS Warburg, the global investment bank, has hired Starcom Motive to handle its international media account.

Hasbro has consolidated its European creative account into DDB, taking £6m worth of business out of TBWA.

L'Oreal is expanding into the grey market with the launch of a new skincare range, Age Perfect, designed for older women.

webTitle: Marketing Week round-up

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Published on October 11.
fields.trailText: October 11: Virgin.com's marketing department has been offered voluntary redundancy after Virgin decided to pool the operation with its internet service provider, Virgin.net.
fields.body:
Virgin.com's entire marketing department has been offered voluntary redundancy after Virgin decided to pool the operation with its internet service provider, Virgin.net. However, Virgin expects the 11-strong marketing department, including marketing director Robert Pepper, to stay on and accept redeployment rather than take the redundancy offer.

Channel 4 has kicked off a £10m sponsorship bidding war for three of its most popular series: Ally McBeal, Frasier and ER. Ally McBeal sponsor BeMe.com is likely to renew its contract, but Frasier and ER, sponsored by Equitable Life and Volvo respectively, are expected to seek new sponsors.

Barclaycard has reshuffled its marketing department. The company has reappointed former head of brand marketing Colin Woodcock as head of marketing strategy, and promoted Mark Duckworth to head of brand marketing.

Stella Artois-owner Interbrew is testing its "Reassuringly expensive" advertising campaign in markets outside the UK, in a move that could strengthen agency Lowe Lintas's hold on the business. Lowe handles the account in the UK, while McCann-Erickson has the business in the rest of the world.

Capital FM is ditching its famous smiling sun logo in a bid to update its image. The revamp will be supported by an ad campaign through Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy.

webTitle: BT moves into webcasting

fields.headline: BT moves into webcasting
fields.trailText: 8.15am: BT is taking its first steps into webcasting after striking a deal with US personal broadcasting firm POPcast.
fields.body:
BT is taking its first steps into webcasting after signing a deal with US personal broadcasting firm POPcast.

Starting next week, the broadband portal Btopenworld will allow users to create their own videos or webcams, which can be published on a personal section of the site.

Ben Andradi, chief operating officer of BTopenworld, said: "Personal broadcasting is the future of the Internet. The success of fly-on-the-wall TV shows such as Big Brother, combined with the power of digital broadband technologies and the distribution reach of the net, will lead to a wave of online creativity and video-based e-commerce."

webTitle: Families may sue bombing suspects

fields.headline: Families may sue bombing suspects
fields.standfirst:
Mixed reaction to Panorama's naming of four men

Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk

Northern Ireland Office
Omagh district council
fields.trailText: Families of those murdered in the Real IRA bombing of Omagh are to consider suing four suspects named in a BBC television programme.
fields.body:
Families of those murdered in the Real IRA bombing of Omagh are to consider suing four suspects named in a BBC television programme.

Following the groundbreaking Panorama broadcast the families will discuss a civil action for damages, a private murder prosecution, or even action to ensure the suspects are tried as war criminals for murdering civilians.

The move came as the row over the programme intensified with the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, supporting the broadcast, while the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, and Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, condemned it.

Most bereaved families who spoke out supported the naming of the suspects in the bombing on August 15 1998 in which 29 people died. Some will meet in the next week to discuss issuing writs against those named by the BBC in a civil action for damages.

Michael Gallagher, chair of the Omagh support group whose 21-year-old son Aidan died in the blast, said: "We're two-and-a-half years down the line and not one person north or south has been charged with a single murder of a person in Omagh. I've spoken to 15 families informally and they've expressed support for a civil action." The RUC yesterday refused to answer any questions about the programme, including whether it contained information previously unknown to detectives.

The BBC said the four men it named were linked to mobile phones investigated by police. After the bombing, detectives were able to track the movements of two of these phones from the Irish Republic to Omagh and back again on the day of the atrocity, said the programme. Their movements determined from records of the phones' use, were consistent with the journey which could have been made by a scout car and the vehicle in which the bomb was transported. When challenged by Panorama, the four refused to explain their actions.

Panorama said one of the suspects was a former IRA gun runner, another a member of the Real IRA's political wing whose neighbour, another suspect, is the commanding officer of the Real IRA.

In Ulster opinion over the decision to name the suspects was divided and threw up unusual allies. Mr Mandelson said: "I thought it was very powerful, actually a very professional piece of work. I hope that as a result of the programme, people will be able to come forward with that last piece of evidence that we need that will clinch a conviction."

Mr Trimble joined the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, and Andrew Mackay, the Conservatives' Ulster spokesman, in condemning the naming of the four suspects. Mr Trimble said: "I have very grave doubts about the wisdom of the programme. It's the case with so many terrorist atrocities in Northern Ireland that identities are known. Is it wise to broadcast that?"

Sinn Fein president's, Gerry Adams, also criticised the BBC. "I am against the naming of people involved for all sorts of reasons. Not least because those involved in the killings on Bloody Sunday are remaining anonymous in the courts." The programme attracted an audience of 4.2m, larger than average for Panorama. Final credits did not include names of production staff, after threats during the making of the programme.

 Mr Mandelson yesterday predicted the end of the Good Friday agreement unless thre is "some give and take" from nationalists to protect Mr Trimble from being toppled by his Ulster Unionist party rank and file. fields.bodyText: Families of those murdered in the Real IRA bombing of Omagh are to consider suing four suspects named in a BBC television programme. Following the groundbreaking Panorama broadcast the families will discuss a civil action for damages, a private murder prosecution, or even action to ensure the suspects are tried as war criminals for murdering civilians. The move came as the row over the programme intensified with the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, supporting the broadcast, while the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, and Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, condemned it. Most bereaved families who spoke out supported the naming of the suspects in the bombing on August 15 1998 in which 29 people died. Some will meet in the next week to discuss issuing writs against those named by the BBC in a civil action for damages. Michael Gallagher, chair of the Omagh support group whose 21-year-old son Aidan died in the blast, said: "We're two-and-a-half years down the line and not one person north or south has been charged with a single murder of a person in Omagh. I've spoken to 15 families informally and they've expressed support for a civil action." The RUC yesterday refused to answer any questions about the programme, including whether it contained information previously unknown to detectives. The BBC said the four men it named were linked to mobile phones investigated by police. After the bombing, detectives were able to track the movements of two of these phones from the Irish Republic to Omagh and back again on the day of the atrocity, said the programme. Their movements determined from records of the phones' use, were consistent with the journey which could have been made by a scout car and the vehicle in which the bomb was transported. webTitle: Eric the Eel arrives - at last

fields.headline: Eric the Eel arrives - at last
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Eric "the Eel" Moussambani seems to be getting into the habit of taking his time over things. After his record slow performance in the 100m freestyle, the Olympic swimmer has had a bit of trouble getting to Britain for an awards ceremony.
fields.body:
Eric "the Eel" Moussambani seems to be getting into the habit of taking his time over things. After his record slow performance in the 100m freestyle, the Olympic swimmer has had a bit of trouble getting to Britain for an awards ceremony.

Moussambani's journey from Equatorial Guinea already something of a marathon at four days almost had to be abandoned when his country's president threatened to prevent him from making the trip.

Organisers of last night's National Television Awards wanted him at the Royal Albert Hall in London to present a gong, but President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo had pencilled the athlete in for a ceremony of his own.

The president was so determined that his country's most famous athlete should attend a reception for Guinea's other Olympic contenders that he ordered Moussambani's plane to be intercepted in the neighbouring west African state of Cameroon.

The jet was grounded for an hour while the British high commissioner, George Boon, and the awards programme producer, George Mitchell, argued for the swimmer to be allowed to travel on to Britain.

The 22-year-old was eventually allowed to continue after Mr Boon persuaded the president that Moussambani's appearance on last night's awards show would increase the country's profile.

Moussambani said after arriving in London yesterday: "The president wanted to stage a reception for all the Olympic athletes, but I had to explain to him that I had already agreed to come here for the National Television Awards.

"He has delayed the reception until the end of the week. I'm very excited, I would never have dreamed of being able to come to London."

The swimmer was taken from Heathrow to a tailor to be fitted for a suit and shoes, before presenting the award for Britain's most popular entertainment presenter. Davina McCall, Michael Barrymore, Chris Tarrant, Jim Davidson and Dale Winton were the nominees.

Moussambani said he had left his home by boat on Saturday to travel to the Equatorial Guinean capital, Malabo, and then flown to Cameroon where his jet was delayed while the diplomatic wrangle over his departure was settled.

He then flew on to Heathrow via Paris. He said his journey had been "very relaxing".

The swimmer hit the headlines during the Sydney games when he swam his 100m freestyle heat in the slowest time in Olympic history.

Last night's show was hosted by the ITN newscaster Sir Trevor McDonald, and was expected to attract an audience of more than 10m. Some 500,000 viewers voted for the awards.

webTitle: Town rankles at 'trial by TV'

fields.headline: Town rankles at 'trial by TV'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: At McDonnells in Dundalk, Co Louth, posters in lurid, child-like scrawl advertised the screening of tonight's Ireland versus Estonia World Cup qualifier, and Friday's long-awaited attraction, Co Down songstress Andrea Rice. But inside, regulars were roughly repelling all interlopers.
fields.body:
At McDonnells in Dundalk, Co Louth, posters in lurid, child-like scrawl advertised the screening of tonight's Ireland versus Estonia World Cup qualifier, and Friday's long-awaited attraction, Co Down songstress Andrea Rice. But inside, regulars were roughly repelling all interlopers.

The reason? Ostensibly, Monday night's BBC Panorama programme, which identified four suspects in the Real IRA's bombing of Omagh, Co Tyrone, in August 1998, and included secretly filmed footage from inside the pub. But no one there seemed in need of a new excuse to bar a Brit.

It is a dangerous street. Carlton's, the pub next door, remains boarded up. Its owner Stephen Connolly, was shot dead in July, apparently for failing to pay protection money to another republican offshoot, the INLA.

Dundalk has been here before, and it was weary and angry yesterday as it was once more cited as the citadel of the dissident republican group responsible for 29 deaths and the single worst atrocity of the Troubles.

McDonells' owner Colm Murphy, 48, was the only person charged in connection with the Real IRA's attack two years ago. Owing to the Irish Republic's generous regulations on bail at the time he was charged, Mr Murphy is at liberty, pending his prosecution for conspiracy to cause an explosion.

He was absent from the pub yesterday, and was said to be away from his home just north of the town.

Dundalk reacted with outrage immediately after the bomb, with those who had suffered the insults about their town at last shaking off the shackles of the silent majority. About 20,000 people, two-thirds of the population, marched in sympathy for the victims, but the protest two years ago was as much to show the perpetrators in their midst the contempt they felt for their deed.

Even today, the print shop in the town's Long Walk shopping centre which was owned by the reputed leader of the Real IRA and his partner, remains deserted. It is left just as it was when people power forced them to flee soon after the massacre.

While the Real IRA boss and his partner moved to a new village, three miles from their family's semi-detached home close to the sea, they retained lucrative interests in a taxi firm in the town and in at least one fish and chip shop. They laid low for a time, just like the dissident outfit.

Dundalk's fury gradually abated, and the fellow residents who were shunned for a while gradually won some sort of reluctant tolerance. People have returned to their own lives, enjoying rising prosperity in what was long a badly deprived community.

But the anger was back after Monday's programme. This time, however, the town was fearsomely split on whether the BBC was right to name the suspects.

Joe Donnelly, 34, said: "I think it was wrong. It's trial by media, and the law should take its course. If the police feel there is no chance of convicting them over Omagh, I don't understand why they don't charge them with Real IRA membership at the very least."

In the immediate aftermath of the bombing, the British and Irish governments rushed in draconian legislation lowering the burden of proof to secure convictions on the charge of belonging to an outlawed organisation.

Patrick O'Connor, 43, compared the evidence forwarded in the programme against the four suspects to that against a man jailed over the 1996 gangland slaying of journalist Veronica Guerin. Panorama outlined how mobile phone calls were tracked to and from Omagh on the day of the bombing, and similar evidence was crucial to convicting Brian Meehan over Ms Guerin's murder.

He said there had been a crackdown on gangs after Ms Guerin was shot dead in June 1996.

But he believed the Real IRA had escaped such action, because the garda were afraid of retaliation.

Fine Gael TD Brendan McGahon, who attracted republican ire in 1981 by refusing to close his shop for IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands' funeral, said: "While I am very much in favour of stern, even repressive legislation, necessary to control terrorism, I cannot go along with this.

"Given the fact that the international press knows the identity of these main perpetrators, Mr Ahern, should reconsider the reintroduction of internment to lock these animals up."

One woman, aged 55, said: "It is right to name them if there is no chance of them coming to trial. People should shun them and their businesses.

"Our memories are too short here. People are feeling upset again because of the inquests recently, but we should feel like this all the time.

"I hate the way we are all made out to be raving republicans. We may want a united Ireland, but no one wants it at this price. These people should be ashamed of themselves."

At least one appears to be. One man believed to be involved in driving the bomb to Omagh is said to have gone to the pub after hearing of the tragedy, and has stayed there virtually ever since.

Meanwhile, Liam Campbell, 38, charged last week with being a member of the Real IRA, was remanded in custody in Dublin yesterday. He is expected to apply for bail on Friday.

Tracing the calls

1. August 13 1998 Two days before bombing, red Vauxhall Cavalier stolen in Carrickmacross, Co Monaghan. Man who stole car makes cell phone calls to intermediary, who is logged making three calls to suspect X.

2. August 13-15 Car hidden while bomb installed.

3. August 14 Suspect Y, on eve of bombing, hands over his mobile and another to suspect X at bar in Dundalk. Later Y tells gardai he knew mobiles were to be used to arrange movement of bombs.

4. Morning of August 15 Bomb car and a scout car start journey to Omagh. Passengers communicate via mobiles.

5. 12.41pm Mast in republic at Castleblaney picks up call from one of mobiles handed to X. Second call at 1.13pm.

6. 1.29pm Mast at Aughnacloy picks up another call from same mobile.

7. 1.57pm Local mast picks up phone in Omagh area.

8. 2.18pm CCTV at an Omagh petrol station records red Vauxhall Cavalier similar to bomb car passing.

9. 2.19pm Second mobile calls the first.

10. 2.30pm One of mobiles, close to phone box in Newry area, receives text message. This mobile belongs to Z, linked to Real IRA's political wing. Z tells police this mobile was missing, but it is rung by another belonging to Z. Suspect A, officer alleged to be commanding Real IRA, is said to have one of Z's mobiles later this evening.

11. 2.31pm Last of three bomb warnings made from phone box in Newry area.

12. 2.38pm Last call from one of mobiles, alleged to be held by A, detected at mast in Ballygawley, south of Omagh.

13. 3.10pm Bomb explodes.

14. 3.30pm Phone linked to X calls a businessman.

webTitle: Dentsu agrees $30m web venture

fields.headline: Japanese ad giant seals $30m web venture
fields.trailText: 8am: Japanese advertising giant Dentsu has agreed a $30m joint venture with Chicago-based internet consultants MarchFirst, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Japanese advertising giant Dentsu has agreed a $30m joint venture with Chicago-based internet consultants MarchFirst.

The two have formed a new internet group, DentsuMarchFirst, which will launch on 1 January offering internet consulting, net branding and other services to clients in Japan and across Asia.

The companies are each investing $13.6m (£9.4m) in the project, which will have a staff of around 40 people. The company will be headed by Koici Segawa, who moves from Dentsu to become representative director and chairman.

Dentsu will soon list its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and plans to use the proceeds from the listing to bolster its digital media capabilities as well as boost its overseas operations.

MarchFirst operates in 14 countries worldwide.

webTitle: US portal offers webcams in UK expansion

fields.headline: US portal offers webcams in UK expansion
fields.trailText: 8am: US webcam portal Cammunity.com is talking to UK websites about providing webcam facilities on their sites as part of its UK expansion, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
US webcam portal Cammunity.com is talking to UK websites about providing webcam facilities on their sites as part of its aggressive move into the UK.

Having already signed a deal with Sportal, Cammunity says it is talking to Peoplenews about setting up fly-on-the-wall webcams in key celebrity havens that would sit on the Peoplenews website.

The Sportal deal, which involves installing webcams in sports venues, was signed in the summer and webcams are expected to be installed in venues over the next few months.

Cammunity.com's chief executive, Garland Simon, said she expected webcams to take off much faster in the UK than they did in the US, and the success of Big Brother over here had created a demand for watching fly-on-the-wall programming via the web.

Cammunity's plan for the UK market is to develop a portal that aggregates people's webcams and sorts them into channels. Its business model also relies on syndicated content where its best webcams are screened on third party websites, such as AltaVista.com and FoxSports.com.

Cammunity is also working with South African webcaster AfriCam on an interactive webcam that follows a man on safari in Africa.

webTitle: Mark Ritson on marketing

fields.headline: Marketing is a balancing act
fields.standfirst: The most challenging experience as a marketer is to spend time in the presence of an engineer. Many face recurring organisational problems when confronted by the product development team, writes Mark Ritson.
fields.trailText: 8am: Marketers are obsessed with seeing things from the consumer's perspective. Product development folk see things from no perspective at all, says Mark Ritson.
fields.body:
Probably the most challenging experience as a marketer is to spend time in the presence of an engineer. This is not to claim that engineers are not nice people, or that marketers have a problem with the engineering profession. Rather, it reflects the recurring organisational experiences many marketing managers have when confronted by the product development, research and design, and manufacturing groups.

Marketers are, as we all know, obsessed with seeing everything from the perspective of the consumer. Product development people are typically (but not always) obsessed with seeing everything from no perspective of any kind. They eschew subjectivity and instead adopt the cold, rational objectivity of performance. It is not about what the customer thinks. Iit is not even about what they want. It is how the product performs. In and of itself, this is a healthy pursuit. After all, that is what the product people are paid for, right?

The trouble begins when production people begin to dominate other aspects of the company structure. They spread their belief in objectivity and product performance around an organisation. Pretty soon many organisations have reversed the traditional healthy mantra of market-oriented organisations: find out what people want, sell it to them and to mutate a great movie tagline: "If we build it, they will buy."

We will make it so nice, so good and so great that they will have to buy it.

Great expense is invested in adding features. Even more expense goes into improving performance. Unfortunately, no one (ie the marketing managers) was around to warn the production people that objectivity is, unfortunately, a myth. There is only subjectivity in the market.

So we add new features to an existing product but never check with consumers that these features are necessary, valuable, or advisable given the increase in price needed to justify their addition. So we improve performance by 30% but never check to see if, glimpsed from the subjectivity of the market, such improvements are valid, or even noticed.

A good example is a friend of mine who spent six months as part of a consulancy team halving waiting times in a national bank. It succeeded - at great cost - only to discover that consumers were quite comfortable with the original four-minute wait and, provided it did not extend beyond 10 minutes or dip below 60 seconds, they were unlikely to ever notice the difference and alter their behaviour accordingly.

The classic indication that a company has been over-run by objective, product-driven people is the product range. How many brand names exist that sound like R2-D2's cousin from Endor?

When asked about its Q234-R or FJ-65, a company will usually shrug and claim: "That's what we have always called it."

Production people become so entwined with their products that they often cannot accept the customers' vision: "Why don't they understand how important torque is?" This often leads to marketing that attempts to educate the consumer as to what is important and how to decide on a purchase, rather than appealing to their enduring issues.

Products and services are not, in and of themselves, the raison d'etre of organisations. It is the satisfaction of those needs in the mind of the "needer" that make a company strong. This satisfaction is partly driven by the performance of the product or service. But who defines performance? Is it the engineers looking to develop a new product? Or is it the consumer looking for satisfaction? Follow the money.

The goal is not to discourage product obsession. Many great marketing successes came directly from such an obsession. The goal is to unite this obsession with the prevailing needs and perceptions of the market.

A good marketing manager forms a dialectic between their engineers and their focus group participants. And they keep that dialectic turning. What can the product people do? What does the market think? Once again, we encounter marketing in its most common form: the simple concept that becomes incredibly hard to apply.

Marketing managers must forge ongoing, intra-organisational connections between the alpha and the omega, the solution and the need, the producer and the consumer... and then keep the wheel turning. Easier said than done. Welcome to the world of marketing.

 Mark Ritson is assistant professor of marketing at London Business School.

When asked about its Q234-R or FJ-65, a company will usually shrug and claim: "That's what we have always called it." Production people become so entwined with their products that they often cannot accept the customers' vision: "Why don't they understand how important torque is?" This often leads to marketing that attempts to educate the consumer as to what is important and how to decide on a purchase, rather than appealing to their enduring issues. Products and services are not, in and of themselves, the raison d'etre of organisations. It is the satisfaction of those needs in the mind of the "needer" that make a company strong. This satisfaction is partly driven by the performance of the product or service. But who defines performance? Is it the engineers looking to develop a new product? Or is it the consumer looking for satisfaction? Follow the money. The goal is not to discourage product obsession. Many great marketing successes came directly from such an obsession. The goal is to unite this obsession with the prevailing needs and perceptions of the market. A good marketing manager forms a dialectic between their engineers and their focus group participants. And they keep that dialectic turning. What can the product people do? What does the market think? Once again, we encounter marketing in its most common form: the simple concept that becomes incredibly hard to apply. Marketing managers must forge ongoing, intra-organisational connections between the alpha and the omega, the solution and the need, the producer and the consumer... and then keep the wheel turning. Easier said than done. Welcome to the world of marketing.  Mark Ritson is assistant professor of marketing at London Business School.

webTitle: Five agencies in Fisherman's Friend pitch

fields.headline: Five pitch to net Fisherman's Friend
fields.trailText: 8am: Fisherman's Friend is planning to launch its first pan-European campaign and has shortlisted five European agencies to pitch for the business, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Fisherman's Friend is planning to launch its first pan-European campaign and has shortlisted five European agencies to pitch for the business.

Springer & Jacoby, which handles the German account; High Involvement, the Dutch incumbent for 10 years; Dentsu-associated Travis Sully Harari, which has worked on the UK account on a project basis; Frankfurt-based Kastner & Partner; and Target will all pitch for the account. No budget has been released.

The review is being handled by Arnim Dipping, European co-ordinator at Impex Management, the marketing and distribution company of the lozenge manufacturer.

Mr Dipping is looking for a strategy that will work across Europe but be relevant to the brand's individual European markets.

The winning agency is expected to launch a regional campaign early next year.

webTitle: What's behind Gordon Brown's petrol tax plan?

fields.headline: What's behind Gordon Brown's petrol tax plan?
fields.standfirst: Julian Glover explains the background to chancellor Gordon Brown's scheme to mollify drivers and hauliers
fields.trailText: Julian Glover explains the background to chancellor Gordon Brown's scheme to mollify drivers and hauliers.
fields.body:
A picture of a set of tightly gritted teeth ought to have accompanied today's reports that Gordon Brown is planning to hand some sort of sop to rural motorists and the haulage industry. The chancellor may see the political necessity of staving off petrol protestors, whose 60-day deadline for government action expires on 13 November, but you can be sure that he's not happy about taking a dent in his iron reputation.

That's why his plan, which is said to involve cutting the road tax paid by some motorists in the most distant, rural parts of the country from £155 to £45, is so insignificant. Affecting virtually no one, it will appease just as few motorists - and many of those who may benefit will not need the aid, anyway. The plan may well mean cheaper motoring for the Queen at Balmoral and the Duke of Westminster on his highland estate, but for the rest of us it might as well not exist.

As a result, motoring organisations, who represent rather more suburban Mondeo drivers than green-wellied Land Rover owners, have attacked the plan even before it has been properly announced. Motoring lobby groups such as the AA want cheaper petrol for all, achieved either by lowering the world price of oil (which is beyond even New Labour's powers) or by cutting tax to levels found elsewhere in Europe. Even the Tories' promise of a 3p cut is hardly enough to sate them.

There is no way that the present chancellor is going to grant even that. Whether he is persuaded by the environmental case for high levels of energy taxation is open to doubt. What is certain, though, is that he enjoys seeing the government's coffers fill with the motorists' gold, and enjoys his unbending reputation even more.

But though Gordon Brown is part fiscal-strongman, he is also part politician, a would-be prime minister in a government that wants a second term above almost anything else. When New Labour loses seats next May, the chancellor will take some of the blame; and perhaps most of it if his refusal to deal with the cost of motoring becomes a big election issue.

As a result he has shifted from his position last month, which was to dismiss all talk of changing motoring taxes as political blackmail, downplaying even the vague promise of doing something in his autumn statement. His new plan to help rural drivers may be only the start, a way of breaking the political ice and introducing the idea that he will act. The oldest political trick in the book is to lead everyone to think you are going to do very little and then suddenly do quite a lot.

The chancellor may be playing this game. His "secret" meeting with representatives of the haulage industry last Friday, also uncovered today, may be part of it.

So may be suggestions that the prime minister has "told" the chancellor to do something about the problem. These may make Tony Blair look like a leader, but they also make him part of the cave-in if one comes about. "It wasn't my fault, mate. The other guy made me swerve," is a standard line to give the police after a car crash.

Gordon Brown may be about to employ it to get out of the government's recent political calamity, too.

webTitle: Tax cuts planned for rural motorists

fields.headline: Tax cuts planned for rural motorists
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is on the brink of taking action to appease those worst hit by the high price of fuel, including tax cuts for rural motorists, reports suggest today.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is on the brink of taking action to appease those worst hit by the high price of fuel, including tax cuts for rural motorists, reports suggest today.

But he appears to have ruled out an across-the-board reduction in duty on petrol and diesel, as protesters demanded during blockades last month.

According to a report in the Daily Telegraph, the chancellor is studying ways of reducing road tax in the countryside, possibly by using postcodes to decide tax levels.

Meanwhile the Financial Times has revealed that Gordon Brown and the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, travelled to Leeds last Friday to meet representatives of the road haulage industry. The chancellor may offer aid to help manage over-capacity in the industry, in his autumn statement, due at some point in the next two months.

The plans, which would see the annual road tax for drivers in the Scottish Highlands, mid-Wales and remote parts of England cut from £155 to £45, received a cool response from motoring organisations today.

The AA said that the scheme might prove impractical. "If it can be done, we would not be unsympathetic. What you then get into is the question of can it be administered fairly in the real world," said the organisation's policy director John Dawson.

The chancellor's hand appears to have been forced by political necessity. His unbending stance during the blockades has been blamed within the government for political damage which saw the Conservative party record its first opinion poll lead for eight years.

He has been further pressured by the 60-day deadline set by fuel protestors when they ended their blockades in late September. The deadline comes up in about a month, and though ministers have made it clear they do not want to give in to what they see as political blackmail they are also keen to avoid a repetition, even on a small scale, of the protests.

As a result the autumn statement, which had been expected in November, may be moved forward to the end of October.

webTitle: Israeli conflict pushes oil price back up

fields.headline: Israeli conflict pushes oil price back up
fields.standfirst:
Tension Bond yields rise with inflation fears
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Increasing tension in the Middle East sent the price of oil surging on global markets last night, re-igniting fears of higher inflation in the developed economies.
fields.body:
Increasing tension in the Middle East sent the price of oil surging on global markets last night, re-igniting fears of higher inflation in the developed economies.

Saudi Arabia's warning that it would not remain aloof in the event of an Israeli attack on Lebanon or Syria helped to send the cost of a barrel of crude up almost a dollar to $32.79 (£22.60) in New York.

Earlier the International Energy Agency set alarm bells ringing when it said the West was heading into winter with inventories well below the seasonal norm.

"Fundamentals are tight and the market is fragile. The system is strained and running hard just to keep even. Vigilance is the order of the day," the IEA said.

Oil prices have retreated from their 10-year peaks last month after pressure from the G7 industrial nations on pro ducers to pump more crude and the US decision to release 30m barrels from its strategic reserve.

After briefly dipping below $30, prices have risen amid concerns that demand will exceed supply in the coming months, particularly if the violence in Israel leads to a broader conflict.

"Refiners can only process so much crude; ships, barges and pipelines can only transport so much product," the IEA said yesterday.

"The global energy market is coming to grips with the reality that there are physical lim its on what can be accomplished this winter."

Oil prices are seen as a threat to the prospects of low inflation in the West, and yesterday's increases spilled over into bond markets, where worries about Wall Street and energy shortages had already driven yields higher.

Britain and Germany yesterday reported higher than expected inflation figures, reflecting the recent surge in the cost petrol. Ernst Welteke, the Bundesbank president, said: "I hope that no inflation expectations will build up in bond yields and wage demands."

webTitle: An ethical poser for charity fundraisers

fields.headline: Purse strings
fields.standfirst: Just take the money or worry about where it's coming from?  Liza Ramrayka on an ethical poser for charity fundraisers
fields.trailText: Just take the money or worry about where it's coming from? Liza Ramrayka on an ethical poser for charity fundraisers
fields.body:
The pitch by NCH Action For Children for an employee fundraising deal worth £600,000 with arms manufacturer BAe Systems unleashed both media criticism and staff protests. While the charity did not win the pitch, the incident has fuelled debate on where fundraisers should draw the line in their relations with the corporate sector. Should charities take the money and run, or refuse to get into bed with business and forgo much-needed funds?

Increased sophistication in fundraising and the current desire of companies to appear socially responsible has resulted in a host of potential partnerships. Many charities take the view that relations with a company seemingly at odds with their aims could tarnish their reputation, upset staff and alienate supporters. Increasingly, however, fundraisers are challenging such anxieties and questioning the grounds on which negative decisions are made. In many cases, for instance, a move to veto a fundraising proposal may be based on long-established views of staff or trustees - rather than the charity's stated aims or principles.

The Charity Commission says that trustees are responsible for establishing a clear, written policy so that anyone making decisions on their behalf knows the rules. "It is acceptable for trustees to decline to enter into a fundraising venture with, or accept a donation from, a company who is in direct conflict with the charity's purposes," says a spokesperson, "but neither trustees nor employees are allowed to pursue their own moral agenda."

The challenge for many fundraisers is to find some middle ground between absolutism and irresponsibility. In the case of NCH, the charity has a long-standing relationship with BAe Systems. The company is involved in an annual fundraising event and its staff sit on NCH's local project committees.

Tony Manwaring, director of external affairs, says NCH would have been happy to get involved in a fundraising project with BAe, particularly as many NCH staff have family and friends at the company. "It says something about the lack of self-confidence in the voluntary sector that it is not prepared to consider the benefits of such relationships alongside the disadvantages."

He admits NCH would not have agreed to a cause-related marketing relationship with the company "because it implies a wholesale corporate endorsement", but he believes charities should take a closer look at how and why they decide not to work with fundraising partners. After a 12-month internal consultation programme, NCH will produce an ethical fundraising policy by the end of the year.

Shelter, the homelessness charity, courted controversy last year with two high-profile fundraising partnerships. The Strip for Shelter campaign saw it team up with the Sun newspaper, with readers asked to get themselves sponsored to wear their favourite football team's strip on a fundraising day. Shelter also tied up with Nescafé, owned by baby milk group Nestlé, in a cause-related marketing deal that branded coffee jars with the charity's name. The Sun deal will generate £1m for Shelter this financial year and represents the equivalent of £2m in media coverage for the charity. The Nescafé campaign will be worth a minimum £500,000 over two years.

John Trampleasure, former fundraising director at Shelter and now development director at Forum for the Future, a social and business solutions group, worked on both initiatives. "It dawned on us that you can have personal views, but this doesn't necessarily reflect the market," he says. "We're all working in a bit of a bubble in the voluntary sector. The important thing is to look for concrete evidence. Will the money come in? Does the company have a track record of working with a range of charities? It's also important that, as fundraisers, we're here to deliver the money so that charities don't have to keep hammering the public."

Many charities are wrestling with what constitutes an ethical policy. The Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers last year produced guidelines on the acceptance and refusal of donations. But its head of policy, Andrew Watt, says it has steered clear of being prescriptive. "It could be ethical for one charity to accept funds from an organisation but unethical for another.

"It's the sort of thing where you'd feel comfortable with the concept [of guidelines], but it could be difficult in practice."

One safeguard is to have other checks and balances in place alongside an ethical policy. The environmental charity WWF-UK introduced a business and engagement policy last year. Building on previous work on ethical investment and eco-standards for merchandise, it includes an ethical framework and covers fundraising, suppliers and organisations commissioned to do work for the charity. A business and industry core group monitors decisions made in accordance with the policy on whether to accept or refuse funds.

"It's fair to say that there are areas of grey, so it's important to have a core group to review decisions," says Steve Waygood, who chairs the group.

Manwaring at NCH agrees with this approach. As a nod to its Methodist roots, NCH still includes a pastoral director in its senior management group."I think there is a need for this sort of role which is independent of individual departments and their aims - whether this means a trustee, a supporter group or user group."

webTitle: LA becomes the strike capital of the US

fields.headline: LA becomes the strike capital of the US
fields.standfirst: Duncan Campbell seems to one of the few in Los Angeles still working
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell seems to one of the few in Los Angeles still working.
fields.body:
The bus drivers and train operators are on strike, the actors are on strike and today the nurses, librarians, probation officers, clerical workers and just about every other public employee in the city are going on strike. Next month, the teachers look likely to join them.

Los Angeles, the city that used to attract businesses by claiming it had none of the disruptive union problems of its more radical northern rival, San Francisco, is now the strike capital of the United States. And every week a new group of workers seems to join the fray.

The transport workers strike, in protest against plans to change overtime rules, is now entering its fourth week. Already it is the longest transport stoppage in 21 years. While any other major city in the world would be crippled by such a lengthy strike, many people in LA, the city of the car, seem completely unaware of it. This is because of the remarkable fact that only 4% of workers commute by public transport and only 2% of all travel is public.

Of the 9.4m inhabitants of LA county, only 450,000 use public transport while there are 5.9m registered cars. So the only people stranded by the strike are the very poorest, the most incapacitated and the banned. Those without cars have either had to bicycle or pay illegal shared cabs to get them to work.

Mayor Richard Riordan was on a cycling holiday in France when the strike started and did not even bother flying home immediately - the sort of behaviour that would have led to calls for his resignation anywhere else in the world but passed almost unremarked here.

Attempts by California's Governor Gray Davis to broker a return to work have failed and yesterday the head of the metropolitan transportation authority, Julian Burke, described the situation as "square minus one".

But the longest-running and most divisive strike is that of the actors. It is now in its 24th week, as members of the screen actors guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists refuse to take part in commercials until an agreement is reached over how they are paid.

The advertising industry want to change the 'residuals' method of payment which the actors claim will leave them worse off. The advertisers argue that with the growth of cable and the internet the game has changed and want to agree a flat fee system.

Hopes that negotiations in New York last month would lead to a settlement have evaporated and people are becoming increasingly despondent. Actors are estimated to be losing $1m a day in total wages and many of the service industries dependant on the business are suffering.

Now public employees are going on strike today. They have been seeking a wage increase of 15% over three years but have been offered only 9%. Already rolling one day strikes have been taking place but now they are moving to an all-out strike.

Next month, the county's 43,000 teachers are also due to go on strike, which would leave 700,000 pupils without classes to go to. Los Angeles Times columnist and broadcaster Patt Morrison asked in her column: "am I the only one in Los Angeles who's still going to work?"

At the moment the city is still functioning but there is a growing air of dismay amongst strikers and those affected by them alike that a failure of political leadership is in danger of paralysing the city's services.

The LA author Mike Davis in his book Ecology of Fear cites the number of times that LA has featured in disaster movies or books estimating that the destruction of the city has been the central theme of 138 novels and films since 1909. He concluded: "no other city seems to excite such dark rapture."

So far a general strike has not been one of the causes for a meltdown. But if it is going to happen now would seem to be the time; at least there will be plenty of available actors ready to play the parts of extras if they can just find someone to give them a lift to the set.
