They have been seeking a wage increase of 15% over three years but have been offered only 9%. Already rolling one day strikes have been taking place but now they are moving to an all-out strike. Next month, the county's 43,000 teachers are also due to go on strike, which would leave 700,000 pupils without classes to go to. Los Angeles Times columnist and broadcaster Patt Morrison asked in her column: "am I the only one in Los Angeles who's still going to work?" At the moment the city is still functioning but there is a growing air of dismay amongst strikers and those affected by them alike that a failure of political leadership is in danger of paralysing the city's services. The LA author Mike Davis in his book Ecology of Fear cites the number of times that LA has featured in disaster movies or books estimating that the destruction of the city has been the central theme of 138 novels and films since 1909. He concluded: "no other city seems to excite such dark rapture." So far a general strike has not been one of the causes for a meltdown. But if it is going to happen now would seem to be the time; at least there will be plenty of available actors ready to play the parts of extras if they can just find someone to give them a lift to the set.

webTitle: John O'Farrell on a  European rapid reaction force

fields.headline: It'll be blood, sweat and dictionaries
fields.standfirst: This plan for a European rapid reaction force will end in tears
fields.trailText: This plan for a European rapid reaction force will end in tears.
fields.body:
This week it was proposed that the Royal Air Force would soon be engaging with the German armed services. Lady Thatcher thought it the best birthday present she could have wished for, until someone explained: "No Margaret, we mean British and German forces on the same side".

The idea of a European rapid reaction force has been gaining ground ever since the debacle of Kosovo, even though the words "European" and "rapid" do not sit comfortably together. The reasoning is that, with the Americans becoming less willing to finance military interventions, the European Union should have its own capability based in Brussels, to operate independently of Nato, which is based in, er, Brussels. Then European military powers like Britain and France could combine to launch operations without having to seek the approval of the US. Well, it worked so well over Suez, why not?

It is claimed that language would not be a problem - apparently the European soldiers would find the British officer class just as incomprehensible as our squaddies always have done. But it's hard to imagine that in the heat of battle the odd second might not be lost. A British soldier would shout "Enemy fire! Take cover!" and all the French troops would get out their Petit Larousse dictionaries and eventually smile and reply: "Yes, I am liking the Beatles also."

The British government is one of the leading advocates of the so-called European defence identity - although if it came to any major conflict it might be politically difficult for our leaders to appear too enthusiastic. We would probably opt out of the single European army until conditions were right. Labour would insist we would not join any war until the five military tests were met, while the Tories would say that Britain would not invade anywhere for the lifetime of the next parliament. The outbreak of war would then be delayed while each of 15 member states organised a referendum.

In fact, the Conservatives want all military operations to remain under the command of Nato, by which of course they mean the Americans, since Nato is basically the US plus the skinny kids who hover behind the legs of the biggest bully. The establishment of a European defence identity would at least bring military decisions back to the countries deploying the troops, but because the EU does not have a single president or prime minister, any military intervention would have to be agreed by committee. Why on earth would 15 different European heads of state want to use military force at once? They can't all have elections coming up at the same time. Any declaration of war would have to be organised like the Eurovision song contest: "United Kingdom, Royaume Uni - can we have your vote please?" Gerhard Schröder would say into the microphone as Terry Wogan jested about the early casualty figures.

With the planned eventual expansion of the EU to include Turkey, Chad and Australia, it's hard to know against whom they could launch an attack. If I was a soldier in Switzerland I would be getting very nervous, especially since the Swiss army only have those little penknives with which to defend themselves.

"Er sarge, do any of these blades fold out into a grenade launcher?"

"Um, I don't think so - but there's a little pair of nail scissors there, you could really hurt someone with that."

The deeper problem, of course, is not how to organise military intervention but whether it works or not. The people of Serbia did not overthrow Milosevic because Nato dropped bombs on them a few months back. And if Nato was sincere in its claim that it bombed Belgrade for humanitarian reasons, let's now see the same countries spend more on helping rebuild Serbia than they spent on the bombs that destroyed it.

Any new force will soon learn that military action is always easier to embark upon than it is to curtail. Throughout history, political leaders have gone to war and found themselves in a longer conflict than they had expected. When poor Edward III got embroiled in the hundred years' war he said: "Blimey, I didn't think it was going to go on this long." And his advisers said: "Well, the actual name of your war might have raised the odd suspicion, your majesty".

If there's to be a European rapid reaction force, its use must be limited to emergency and humanitarian aid. They could try developing a full-blown European army but there would be only one outcome. Arguments would break out among the various European ethnic groups. Minor skirmishes between British, French and German troops would escalate, nation states would mobilise, and Europe would once more be plunged into all-out war.

Still, I suppose it would save us having to make a decision on monetary union for another few years.

 John O'Farrell's first novel, The Best a Man Can Get, has just been published by Doubleday. Contact: comment@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Mother is jailed for assaulting teachers

fields.headline: Mother is jailed for assaulting teachers
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A woman who assaulted four teachers after criticising their efforts to discipline her 11-year-old son was yesterday jailed for four months.
fields.body:
A woman who assaulted four teachers after criticising their efforts to discipline her 11-year-old son was yesterday jailed for four months.

Tina Smith, 31, who has three children, lashed out at staff at Willingsworth high school, Tipton, West Midlands, on two occasions after teachers expressed concerns about the conduct of her eldest son, Liam, West Bromwich magistrates heard.

Sentencing Mrs Smith, who is unemployed, district judge Michael James said her actions in punching the headteacher, John King, and splitting his lip had been "outrageous".

Mrs Smith, whose husband, Wayne, 33, was sentenced to 60 hours' community service after pleading guilty to assaulting three teachers during one of the incidents, admitted four counts of common assault at an earlier hearing.

Mr James told the couple: "It is all too prevalent in society today that people resort to violence to solve problems."

Mr James also dismissed claims that Liam had been "victimised" by staff, saying: "It seems that there were concerns about Liam's conduct and certainly Mrs Smith appeared incensed by the school's actions.

"She was, no doubt like many parents, quite unable to accept that any fault might lie with her son.

"In her state of anger and maybe frustration, Mrs Smith went to the school on two separate occasions and struck a number of people who I am satisfied made absolutely no move to offer any violence of any kind towards either of you.

"Teachers are regularly faced with angry, unreasonable and violent children and parents. They are entitled to expect and receive the protection of the courts.

"The example set to children in circumstances like this one clearly goes towards undermining school discipline."

Nelson Jerram, for the prosecution, told the court that Mrs Smith assaulted Anne Hollings on February 17 this year, pulling the teacher's hair and slapping the victim outside the school staff room.

The Smiths, who live in Tipton, were then both involved in an attack on a total of five teachers on April 12.

During the later attack, Mrs Smith, who was on bail awaiting trial for the first offence, swore at Mr King after he asked her son to leave the school premises, the court heard. Mrs Smith, whose solicitor claimed she was on anti-depressants at the time of both incidents, then split Mr King's lip in the playground as pupils watched.

Mr Jerram, who described claims that Mrs Smith had been assaulted herself as utter nonsense, added: "Mr King's inside lip was split and he could taste blood."

Mrs Smith then cuffed a female teacher before punching teacher Steven Williams with her right fist.

Mr Smith admitted manhandling three teachers by grabbing them around the neck, but did not strike out at any of the victims, the court heard.

The prosecuting solicitor added that Mrs Smith's claims of victimisation had impugned the good name of experienced teachers, who were in an extremely difficult position.

She had been on school premises without permission on both occasions, the court heard.

webTitle: Lecturer cleared of rape kept sex diary

fields.headline: Lecturer cleared of rape kept sex diary
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A university lecturer who was yesterday cleared of the date rape of an 18-year-old student kept a diary logging the 90 women he claimed to have slept with.
fields.body:
A university lecturer who was yesterday cleared of the date rape of an 18-year-old student kept a diary logging the 90 women he claimed to have slept with.

In the diary, entitled The Sexual History of Russell Griffiths, the student who made the rape complaint against him, which led to the court case, was listed as number 84.

Griffiths, who worked at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside at the time of the incident in May last year pleaded guilty to a charge of lying when he signed a declaration stating that he had no previous convictions on his job application.

He in fact had three - one for making threats to kill and two for making obscene communications. The jury who cleared Griffiths of rape yesterday were not allowed to be told of his criminal past.

Derek Crothall, vice chancellor of the university said Griffiths had signed a declaration on an application form in July 1998 stating that he had no previous criminal convictions. He later admitted that the declaration was false.

"What this case does show is the need for higher education institutions to be allowed to access the criminal records of prospective employees," Mr Crothall said.

Griffiths, 36, now of East Kilbride, Lanarkshire, had been accused of spiking a drink with a sleeping tablet and handing it to the woman at a nightclub in Lincoln. A jury at Lincoln crown court took just over 90 minutes to clear him of rape.

Griffiths grinned at his de fence counsel as the not guilty verdict was read out. He was bailed and will be sentenced in November for the offence of lying on his job application.

The jury did not hear about his logbook of sexual conquests after legal argument in their absence. The trial judge ruled the book inadmissible, saying it would have had a profound effect on the jury.

Griffiths resigned from the university - which has campuses in Lincoln and Hull - in August 1999 before the student complained to police.

After he was cleared of rape, it emerged that he had three previous convictions. In 1995, he had been given a two-year suspended sentence by Swansea magistrates court for making threats to kill.

In a separate case during the same year, he was also fined for making obscene communications after he sent nude photographs of his former fiancee, a student at Swansea University, to the university, claiming she had been sleeping with her lecturers to boost her grades. Pictures were also sent to her mother, friends and to a former boyfriend.

In 1996, he was convicted of making obscene communications and fined.

When another university asked for a reference in August 1999, Lincolnshire and Humberside University made it clear he was not a suitable person for a teaching role.

A spokesman for the Committee of Vice Chancellors and Principals, which represents British universities, said: "We are determined to do all we can to prevent such an event happening again. We will be having discussions with the Department for Education and the police with a view to considering new guidance in the light of this court case."

Verity Coyle, president of the students' union at Lincolnshire and Humberside University, said students there had been shaken by the case.

"When lecturers work at the university, they take on an almost pastoral role," she said. "He has lied about his past and that has damaged that relationship by his own admission."

Griffiths' former fiancee Julia Ferguson, a librarian from Hull, said: "I left my old house because of him - I can't believe we actually got engaged. When we split he made my life hell, he kept coming after me."

webTitle: Plane crash lands as wheel collapses

fields.headline: Plane crash lands as wheel collapses
fields.trailText:
Four people were taken to hospital last night after the undercarriage of a plane collapsed on landing at Bournemouth airport following its diversion from Gatwick, where another aircraft 
was stuck in the mud after sliding off the runway.
fields.body:
Four people were taken to hospital last night after the undercarriage of a plane collapsed on landing at Bournemouth airport following its diversion from Gatwick, where another aircraft was stuck in the mud after sliding off the runway.

There were no casualties in either case but two adults and two children were taken to hospital "as a precautionary measure" after the nosewheel of the plane that landed at Bournemouth international airport gave way as it landed.

The plane, carrying 40 passengers and four crew, was originally heading for Jersey from Gatwick but severe weather in the Channel Islands had forced the pilot to turn around and fly back.

The twin-engined turboprop aircraft was then forced to divert to Bournemouth after a Boeing 767 carrying 146 passengers slid off the runway at Gatwick and got stuck in mud while landing in heavy rain.

A spokeswoman for Bournemouth airport said: "We can confirm that an ATR-72 aircraft operated by CityFlyer Express experienced a nosewheel collapse while landing at Bournemouth international airport."

She added: "A full emergency was declared and police, fire and ambulance were in attendance. There were no casualties but as a precaution two adults and two children were taken to hospital for a check-up."

Glen Jones, the airport's managing director, said: "We obviously take incidents like this very seriously but it was a relatively minor incident. We have had no other occurrences like this this year and it is a very rare form of accident."

Air accident investigators from the Department of Transport examined the plane last night and the airport remained closed.

Meanwhile, at Gatwick, emergency service teams were struggling to pull the Boeing 767 out of the mud. Airport officials closed the runway, forcing all inbound flights to divert to other airports including Luton, Heathrow, Stansted and Manchester.

The Britannia flight from Manchester to Gatwick had landed safely, but slid off the runway into wet grass and mud as it taxied to its stand.

A Gatwick airport spokeswoman said: "At 7.50pm a Britannia 767 300 aircraft inbound from Manchester landed normally and safely at Gatwick. When the aircraft vacated the runway it left the taxiway and travelled into the soft wet verges at the side of the taxiway. All 146 passengers and crew were uninjured as a result of the incident."

Passengers and crew were escorted from the Boeing 767 and on to coaches before being taken to the airportÕs south terminal and put up in local hotels for the night.

Fire crews later managed to drag the aircraft back on to the runway where safety checks were carried out.

A spokesman for Britannia said engineers were checking the nosewheel of the aircraft and it was hoped the plane would be back in service this morning.

Passengers and crew were escorted from the Boeing 767 and on to coaches before being taken to the airportÕs south terminal and put up in local hotels for the night. Fire crews later managed to drag the aircraft back on to the runway where safety checks were carried out. A spokesman for Britannia said engineers were checking the nosewheel of the aircraft and it was hoped the plane would be back in service this morning.

webTitle: Eight councils put on adoption 'shame' list

fields.headline: Eight councils put on adoption 'shame' list
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The government yesterday named eight local authorities with the worst record for child adoption, as ministers stepped up their drive to find more permanent homes for children in care.
fields.body:
The government yesterday named eight local authorities with the worst record for child adoption, as ministers stepped up their drive to find more permanent homes for children in care.

John Hutton, health minister in charge of adoption and fostering, appointed a taskforce to improve performance in Coventry, Peterborough, Torbay, Slough, Northamptonshire and the London boroughs of Barnet, Lambeth and Newham.

The Department of Health said the eight were picked out because they placed a low proportion of their "looked after" children with adoptive parents. In some cases, their adoption services were also criticised by the social services inspectorate.

The three authorities with the best adoption record were Nottinghamshire, Gateshead and Bradford.

Although Mr Hutton said the intervention was meant to help the poorer performing authorities, there were fears last night that it would stigmatise them, making it harder to attract skilled staff to organise successful adoptions.

The British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, representing social services departments and voluntary adoption groups, said the decision to name and shame could be "self-defeating".

Felicity Collier, chief executive, said there was good progress this year in raising the adoption rate. However, "if I was an adopter and I lived in one of the areas that the Department of Health announces is lagging behind the pack, adoption might look unappealing.

"And if I was a social service worker coming off a course, the more I saw councils examined and blamed, the more unattractive a career in the social services would become."

Ms Collier said 20%-30% of posts in social services were vacant, and the announcement might make it harder to fill them. "Social services departments need the confidence of their clients, and if this sort of naming and shaming goes on it adds to the difficulties they have in providing a good service."

Moira Gibb, president elect of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said they welcomed help from the taskforce, but the identification of low-performing authorities was likely to be counter productive.

"If there was resistance to improvement then it would be appropriate to name and blame." But the likelihood of achieving the government's overall aim of improving adoption services could be reduced, by slowing down improvements in low performing authorities.

"What we need is the evidence that naming and shaming works, but the evidence at the moment points in the opposite direction."

Mr Hutton said naming councils to be helped by the taskforce was not intended to shame them. "There is a steady rise in the number of adoptions taking place, but we need to keep the momentum going."

The government is planning a white paper this year to increase adoptions by 50% and reduce numbers of children in local authority care. This follows a statement from Tony Blair in July that "too often in the past adoption has been seen as a last resort".

However councils and adoption agencies often find a mismatch between those wanting to adopt babies and children in care, who are mostly aged over four, with 40% having learning difficulties or physical disabilities and 20% a history of sexual abuse.

webTitle: Ten million dollar questions

fields.headline: Ten million dollar questions
fields.standfirst:
Jack Straw must explain why he gave British passports to Indian businessmen accused of taking bribes

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Jack Straw must explain why he gave British passports to Indian businessmen accused of taking bribes
fields.body:
With its low ceiling fans, metal trunks full of legal papers and general air of chaos, room 221 of Delhi's district court is as good a place as any for a trial. To stave off the mid-afternoon heat, you can go and buy a soft drink from the noisy seller outside, before settling back into an ancient rattan chair and enjoying the proceedings. The legal argument may be obtuse, the court overcrowded and the lawyers excitable. But there is a sense that, though the Indian legal system moves with ponderous speed, it eventually gets its man.

It is unlikely that the Hinduja brothers, Britain's wealthiest Asian family, will ever set foot inside and try out the chairs for themselves. On Monday they were formally charged there with accepting $10m (£7.1m) in bribes in India's most notorious corruption scandal. The claim is that they used their influence with the late Indian prime minister Rajiv Gandhi to secure a massive contract for the Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors. Their reward was a huge commission, hidden in a series of secret Swiss bank accounts, charmingly codenamed Lotus, Tulip and Mont Blanc.

What remains unclear is how much Jack Straw knew of all this when he recently decided to grant two of the Hindujas - Gopichand and Srichand - British passports. The allegation of corruption had been hanging over them for 13 years. For most of that period, the Hindujas had kept Indian investigators at bay by blocking the release of crucial bank documents from Switzerland. Two years ago, however, the writing was on the wall that the Swiss federal courts were preparing to hand over the documents.

In June 1998, the home secretary approved Gopichand's application to become a British citizen and in April, 1999, Srichand got his British passport.

The Hindujas' relationship with new Labour was well known. Tony and Cherie Blair were guests of honour at the Hindujas' annual "inter-faith" dinner last November, and it was the Hindujas who performed the government a useful service by agreeing to sponsor the flagging Millennium Dome's spirit zone. Until Monday, they might reasonably have expected peerages. Keen students of last year's Hinduja dinner, however, would have noted that India's then high commissioner in London did not turn up.

The case against the Hindujas has yet to be proved. They have consistently denied any wrongdoing. But the affair should at least provide Mr Straw with a moment of reflection. For 13 years the brothers had denied all involvement in the Bofors scandal and had refused to cooperate with India's Central Bureau of Investigation. The documents sent from Switzerland last December, however, which the brothers had fought so hard to withhold, showed payments from Bofors turning up in the accounts of McIntyre Corporation, a Hinduja front company based in Panama.

Two weeks ago events took a dramatic turn. In an astonishing volte-face, the Hindujas finally admitted a "business association" with Bofors. But they denied the $10m discovered in their accounts had any connection with the controversial deal to supply howitzer guns to the Indian army. They have not so far explained what the payment was for. Most of the other players in the saga who could shed light on the affair are not in a position to do so: Rajiv Gandhi is dead, blown up by a Tamil extremist, while other members of his inner circle who allegedly took a cut of the Bofors cake have wisely left India.

The inevitable suspicion remains that when it comes to granting British nationality, New Labour takes an indulgent attitude towards its friends. The hapless Mohamed Al Fayed had his application turned down by Mr Straw last year on the grounds that he was not of good character, had broken into Tiny Rowland's safe deposit box, and had bribed MPs. But then Mr Fayed was never a member of the establishment. The Hindujas, by contrast, have been influential powerbrokers in India and the UK for 20 years.

On November 20 the judge hearing the Bofors case, Ajit Bharihoke, will rule on whether the CBI's application to charge the Hindujas with corruption has been accepted. The same Dickensian characters will turn up: the lawyers in their black coats and white ties; the clerk, with his prehistoric manual typewriter; and the itinerant soft drinks seller.

If Mr Bharihoke finds in the bureau's favour then it will be a long hard struggle for the Hindujas to salvage their personal and political reputations. And Mr Straw will face another headache: whether to extradite back to India the men whose passport applications he approved.

 Luke Harding is the Guardian's New Delhi correspondent. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Riverboat to dome goes under

fields.headline: Riverboat to dome goes under
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Millennium Dome
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The limited success of the Millennium Dome has sunk the government's much vaunted fast riverboat project between central London and Greenwich. It had been heralded by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, as a key part of its integrated transport policy.
fields.body:
The limited success of the Millennium Dome has sunk the government's much vaunted fast riverboat project between central London and Greenwich. It had been heralded by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, as a key part of its integrated transport policy.

Whitehorse Fast Ferries Ltd announced yesterday that it was going out of business with the loss of 20 jobs and debts of £1.6m which it was paying off. Its only profits were made on the three days after the dome opened.

The government and the dome's backers had promised a string of 20 piers along the Thames to attract visitors but only six have been completed. The company complained that it was not allowed to erect signs or ticket machines.

Richard Lay, an executive director, said: "If the infrastucture had been put in place, as promised, we might have stood a chance. You always have operational problems, but there were just too many."

webTitle: Rising cost of young in city's care

fields.headline: Rising cost of young in city's care
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Councillors in Salford, Greater Manchester, admitted yesterday that the city faces a "social timebomb" because of the increasing number of children being taken into care.
fields.body:
Councillors in Salford, Greater Manchester, admitted yesterday that the city faces a "social timebomb" because of the increasing number of children being taken into care.

Worried by demands on diminishing budgets, the council commissioned an independent report which found that the problems with the parents of many of Salford's children in care went back for generations. The report cites causes including drug and alcohol abuse, neglect, poverty, unemployment and high crime levels.

The number of children in the city's care has risen from 336 in 1994 to 588 this year, an increase significantly above the national average. Last year's increase cost £2m more than estimated.

The report's author, Anne Harris, a social work and management consultant, interviewed staff in the social services department, examined reports and studied a sample of children in care.

Peter Connor, a councillor for community and social services, said: "The city is facing a social timebomb. We are seeking urgent meetings with the government."

The problems are compounded by troubles at Moorfield, which opened last years as a reception centre for children coming into care. Councillors ordered a second independent report after complaints from neighbours about the home's residents.

webTitle: Queen's historic prayer with Pope ruled out

fields.headline: Queen's historic prayer with Pope ruled out
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A proposal that the Queen should join in symbolic prayer with the Pope during her state visit to the Vatican next week has been dropped after concerns that it would upset factions in the Church of England, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
A proposal that the Queen should join in symbolic prayer with the Pope during her state visit to the Vatican next week has been dropped after concerns that it would upset factions in the Church of England, the Guardian has learned.

The move, which would have seen the Supreme Governor of the Church in England praying with the head of Roman Catholicism, would have been interpreted as a hugely significant act of reconciliation fol lowing nearly 500 years of largely rancorous division since Henry VIII led the church in England away from Rome.

It is understood from senior sources involved in organising the visit that the plan for private prayers was supported by both Buckingham Palace and the Vatican, but was dropped following fears that it would annoy extreme Protestants and Anglo-Catholics within the Church of England and reopen sensitivities concerning the Queen's role as head of the established church.

It was made clear last night that George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, was not consulted over the proposal for prayers. The Queen will now have a private audience, lasting no more than half an hour, with the Pope in the Vatican next Tuesday - hardly long enough for anything more than the usual exchange of diplomatic pleasantries.

Both Buckingham Palace and the archbishop's office sought to play down the possibility that joint prayers would ever have been said yesterday. A palace spokesman said: "Very early on there were dis cussions with the Vatican about the content of the meeting. The Queen is visiting the Pope as head of state, not as head of the church."

The archbishop's spokesman said: "Any advice we would give would be a private matter. I don't see how the Church of England would be involved. This is a private visit."

Suggestions that the Queen and the Pope might use the occasion of their meeting to apologise for wrongs committed on both sides during the religious persecutions of the 16th and 17th centuries have been firmly denied. The meeting will take place as part of a four-day state visit to Italy, during which the Queen will attend a state banquet given by the Italian president and visit Milan to see the newly-restored Leonardo fresco of the Last Supper.

British monarchs have paid state visits to the Vatican several times over the last 100 years, the first being by King Edward VII in 1903, but always on the level of courtesy calls between heads of state. The Queen visited Pope John XXIII in 1961 and the current Pope in 1980 and the two also met at Buckingham Palace in during the papal visit in 1982.

At next week's meeting it is thought likely the Queen will discreetly breach long-standing Vatican traditions by wearing pastel colours when she meets the Pope. On her previous visits in 1961 and 1980 the Queen followed protocol as a non-Catholic monarch by dressing entirely in black.

During his visit in 1982 the Pope joined in prayer with the then Archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie in Canterbury Cathedral, the first time the leaders of the two churches had done so and an event regarded as having great significance for future relations. Even during that generally acclaimed visit, there were protests from some fundamentalist Protestants including the Rev Ian Paisley.

The Pope on his visit to Britain in 1982 was seen to defer to the archbishop but in a sign of ongoing sensitivities, the Vatican's publication last month of its controversial declaration of Dominus Iesus has caused outrage among Anglicans because of its traditional ist assertion that other churches are of lesser status.

The move - seen as an attempt by conservative factions in the Vatican to exercise control and influence over an ailing papacy - runs counter to the Pope's earlier attempts to build bridges with other faiths.

Although the Pope has insisted that the declaration was not meant to denigrate other churches, its publication would have been enough to stifle any proposal of joint prayers with the Queen.

webTitle: Italians feast on royal fear of garlic

fields.headline: Italians feast on royal fear of garlic
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Buckingham Palace was exasperated yesterday after informal advice passed to the Italian government about the Queen's eating habits, particularly an aversion to garlic, was splashed in Italian newspapers.
fields.byline: Stephen Bates and Philip Willan in Rome
fields.body:
Buckingham Palace was exasperated yesterday after informal advice passed to the Italian government about the Queen's eating habits, particularly an aversion to garlic, was splashed in Italian newspapers.

The suggestion that garlic should not be used in the preparation of food at a state banquet given by the Italian president at the Quirinale Palace during a visit to Rome next week was meant to reflect the fact that the Queen did not want her breath to smell when meeting other guests. But the Rome newspaper Il Messaggero passed on the advice in a front-page article on Monday on court etiquette and royal culinary preferences.

"It is only common sense. If you are going to be meeting people you don't want to be breathing garlic fumes over them," a palace spokesman said.

Il Messaggero reported that "her majesty's antipathy for 'boorish' garlic and onion is well known", and detected a symmetry with the rightwing opposition leader, Silvio Berlusconi, who also apparently hates "these plebeian, intrusive breath problems".

The newspaper's culinary expert, Giacomo A Dente, also reported that the palace wanted spaghetti and other long pastas kept off the menu - because of the danger of undesirable splashes of sauce - as well as all forms of seafood, strawberries and wild berries: "those berries so dear to the majority of the Queen's subjects".

Buckingham Palace said: "This is mostly rubbish. The Queen always steers clear of seafood on foreign visits for obvious reasons."

The paper claimed that organisers of the royal visit have opted for traditional Roman flavours "revisited in a sophisticated key". On the wine front, they have chosen Brunello di Montalcino - one of the Queen's favourite wines - for the dinner.

In a country that has abolished its own monarchy, the idea of the visit of a "real" Queen stokes the flames of snobbery, the paper said. And also those of excitement.

The Milan daily Corriere della Sera offered advice on how to dress, bow and curtsy. Beppe Severgnini advised those introduced to the Queen to: "Say little, do the obvious, go where the invitation tells you to and wear what good sense suggests. On dress, after all, we have little to learn. The English have taught us many things: but apricot dress suits with little round hats will meet with our firm resistance. Forgive us, your majesty."

Only during a visit to the Vatican may there be some breach of custom. Traditionally, non-Catholic royals have worn black when meeting the Pope - Catholics wear white - but it is thought the Queen may opt for pastel colours.

A spokesman for Carluccio's restaurant in Covent Garden said: "We can provide any dish without garlic if the customer does not like it, or has an important meeting to go to afterwards. It is not a problem for an Italian chef."

fields.headline: Doves must be hawks
fields.standfirst:
If peace is to prevail in the Middle East, the peacemakers will have to become as tough as their enemies
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: This war is far from over; indeed, it may have only just begun. The peacemakers and diplomats are piling into Israel - Robin Cook arrives today - talking of calm. But the stone-throwing and shooting has not stopped. Yesterday another Palestinian boy, this time a nine-year-old, took a bullet in the head. Dread and panic still stalk the promised land.
fields.body:
This war is far from over; indeed, it may have only just begun. The peacemakers and diplomats are piling into Israel - Robin Cook arrives today - talking of calm. But the stone-throwing and shooting has not stopped. Yesterday another Palestinian boy, this time a nine-year-old, took a bullet in the head. Dread and panic still stalk the promised land.

The blame game rages on. For Palestinians, and much of world opinion, the culprit is clear: Likud leader Ariel Sharon started the trouble by swaggering onto that contested patch of holy Jerusalem turf revered by Jews as the Temple Mount and by Muslims as the site of the Al-Aqsa mosque. Sharon's crime has been compounded by an Israeli military which has used jeeps, tanks and even helicopters to rain down rubber bullets and worse on prepubescent boys armed with nothing more than rocks and slingshots.

Most Israelis see it differently. The left admits that Sharon lit that fateful first spark and that the Israeli army has since used excessive force. But that leaves plenty of blame left to go round. They point the finger at Yasser Arafat and his Palestinian Authority. He has 40,000 policeman at his disposal, a quasi-army which could have quelled the Al-Aqsa uprising before it had even started. Arafat has crushed dissent among his own people before, he could have done it again. Nor, adds Israeli opinion, did Palestinian TV have to stoke the fires of rebellion by broadcasting archive pictures of the 1987-93 intifada: a kind of how-to guide to the new generation.

There is almost no common ground between these two views, as Kofi Annan and co are doubtless discovering. But if consensus is impossible on the causes of the current war, agreement may be more likely on what it has cost.

Everyone can see that more than a hundred people, mostly Palestinians, have lost their lives. They can agree, too, that the tentative trust that took seven years to build since the Oslo accords has evaporated, that both sides have returned to the hardline positions of more than a decade ago. Suddenly Israelis who had made a reluctant peace with the idea of an eventual Palestinian state are having second thoughts: that police force, they now fear, could soon be a full-fledged hostile army, on Israel's doorstep. For their part, Palestinians who had come to accept a two-state solution - one for them, one for the Israelis - are now back on a 1970s agenda, demanding Israel's destruction.

There are two deeper shifts, which could well be felt for decades to come. The first is the well-documented inclusion of Arab citizens of Israel in the current rebellion. For 52 years, through five wars, the so-called Israeli Arabs kept their counsel, enduring often grotesque discrimination. They did not join the struggle of their cousins on the West Bank and Gaza; the intifada never spread inside Israel's borders. Their position was always ambiguous - members of the Palestinian people, yet citizens of a Jewish state - but they maintained it. Not now. The 52-year balancing act is over: the Palestinians of Israel are in revolt, too.

The second, related shift is even more troubling. When Arafat and Israel's Ehud Barak met at Camp David in July they sat as two neighbours engaged in a land dispute, secular politicians tussling over borders and maps. Now the battle is no longer about real estate, but theology. The dispute over Jerusalem has turned a national conflict into a religious war - Jew against Muslim. Such a conflict does not recognise the "green line" that separates Israel proper from its occupied territories; it engulfs the Arabs of Haifa as well as Hebron. What's worse, it takes the Israel-Palestine conflict into a realm impervious to the secular, rational solutions of modern diplomacy: we have entered the realm of jihad.

This spells doom for both sides. Barak's position has been rendered all but untenable. He was elected last year on a promise to make peace; he went further than any Israeli ever before to achieve that goal - and now he has been made to look a fool. He withdrew from Lebanon, agreeing an unofficial accord with Hezbollah, only for that group to kidnap three Israeli soldiers. He discussed with Arafat a deal that would have seen further Jewish holy sites placed under the protection of the Palestinian authority: after Joseph's Tomb in Nablus was sacked on Saturday - with Palestinians tearing the pages from Jewish prayer books - few Israelis will allow Barak to sign such a pact now. They will demand that Jewish holy sites remain under Jewish protection.

Similarly, Barak was beginning to prepare Israelis to right a historic wrong: the dispossession of hundreds of thousands of Palestinian refugees. Israelis were realising they would eventually have to open their doors and let those Palestinians return home. "Now it is clear it would be madness," wrote Ze'ev Schiff for the left-leaning Ha'aretz newspaper yesterday, "to add to [Israel's] Arab minority" after so many have "raised the banner of revolt." The last fortnight has convinced Israelis that the Arabs among them are a fifth column, and Barak cannot be seen to add to their ranks.

Not that this is good news for Arafat. He will not be able to ride this wave of Muslim anger forever: if there is a jihad in Palestine, his people will want Hamas, not a secularist like him, to lead it. More immediately, can he not see what this confirmation of Israelis' worst fears will lead to? Does he not realise that the last two weeks have been the model election campaign for a new Likud government, headed by Sharon or a reborn Binyamin Netanyahu?

Which brings us back to the blame game. For perhaps the real culprits are those two would-be peacemakers, Barak and Arafat. Neither man realised that doves must be as tough as hawks - that in proposing compromise they must be as unbending as the rejectionists who would do nothing. Barak should have barred Sharon from his walkabout. He should have maintained his surveillance operation on the border with Lebanon. He needed to do all this not to be a warlord, but to be a peacemaker - to prevent the violence that would make his own people fear compromise.

The same applies to Arafat. He needed to push aside Hamas and the other rejectionists and to prevent the sacking of Joseph's Tomb - if only to reassure the Israelis with whom he is seeking an accommodation. But he should also have quieted the holy war propaganda, which can only make his fellow Palestinians regard his dealings with the Israeli enemy as treachery. Instead he has fed the appetite for jihad, so that even his own achievement in Oslo is in peril.

There is a lesson here for peacemakers everywhere, including Northern Ireland. Those proposing compromise have to bend over backwards to provide security, to reassure their own side that peace is a risk they can afford to take. For if they slip up, their people will not easily agree to compromise next time: they won't be fooled again.

jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

webTitle: Analysis: UK's poor record in dealing with its rubbish

fields.headline: What a waste
fields.standfirst:
Plans to use recycling, composting and incineration to reduce the amount of rubbish we throw into holes in the ground are in deep trouble
Special report: the landfill tax scandal
fields.trailText: The United Kingdom has a bad record in dealing with its rubbish compared with other European countries.
fields.body:
The United Kingdom has a bad record in dealing with its rubbish compared with other European countries.

In the 90s, international pressure stopped the dumping of chemical and sewage waste directly into the North sea, a practice that had led the UK under Mrs Thatcher to be dubbed the "dirty man of Europe". On land, nothing has changed.

While Germany, Denmark and the Netherlands forge ahead with recycling, composting and using waste to generate energy, the UK carries on dumping in landfill sites. The result is that this country is years behind the best in Europe in dealing with the growing mountain of domestic and commercial waste. And we are failing to gain the new industries and jobs that active recycling of rubbish brings.

The explanation is lack of political will both at national and local level and an easy option - lots of big holes of the ground.

Take a country with virtually no available holes and no forgiving sea to dump things in - Switzerland. A crisis seen approaching more than 20 years ago led to every option for disposing of waste being explored there. By 1995 the Swiss were already recycling 31% of their waste, composting another 11% and burning 45% to make energy. The ash from the incinerators is recycled as hardcore for roads and construction. The remainder of the rubbish - a mere 13% - is buried.

In the UK at the end of last year only 8% of waste was recycled, 8% burned to make electricity and - in a nation of gardeners - only 1% composted to improve the soil. This left 83% simply being dumped in holes.

There are wide regional disparities. Hampshire began running out of holes in which to dump waste five years ago and is now hoping to hit 40% recycling by 2003. Scotland, with plenty of dumps, remains below 4% in recycling.

It is not that the Blair government or its predecessor have done nothing. Both have had waste reduction targets at which local authorities were supposed to aim. Both favoured more incinerators to burn waste and generate electricity. The Tories wanted to recycle or compost a quarter of all waste by 2000. They introduced the first green tax, a landfill charge that was supposed to make options other than dumping more attractive. It did not work. Realising the ambition was unattainable John Prescott deferred the 25% target date to 2005. But his replacement strategy faces problems too.

Pressure on the UK has come from a series of European Union directives intended to restrict use of excessive packaging and so cut the ever-climbing amounts of waste a consumer society throws away. To comply with the latest EU landfill directive the government has set new targets for recovering and recycling materials. More waste has to be converted into energy. By 2005, 40% of waste must be recovered or burned. The target for 2010 is 45% and 67% by 2015.

Subsidies are available for recycling; best practice is being highlighted and laggard councils chased up. It is estimated that between 100 and 200 new materials recovery facilities are needed - places that sort cans, plastics and other recyclable items. Between 150 and 300 new composting plants should be provided - a tall order for local authorities with other priorities on how to spend their limited funds.

Meanwhile, the other main plank of official policy, incineration, is in deep trouble. The idea of reducing waste bulk by burning it while at the same time generating electricity is appealing. The problem in the UK is that there has been successful and continuing opposition that may veto any expansion.

On Monday, Greenpeace closed down the largest waste-to-energy plant in the UK at Edmonton, which burns 38.5% of the waste produced by eight north London boroughs. The public authority that runs it wants to expand, aiming to burn around 60% of the boroughs' waste - some 850,000 tonnes of rubbish a year. The boroughs want to increase recycling beyond their current performance, which at 14% is already over the average: add the incineration increase and this part of London would reach European standards. Provided, that is, Edmonton can overcome a Greenpeace campaign that yesterday won the support of mayor Ken Livingstone.

This is likely to be a test case. There are 15 similar if smaller plants elsewhere and the government wants a dramatic increase in that figure. Whitehall is hoping for some 100 additional waste-to-electricity schemes. More than 60 have planning permission. But Greenpeace, together with protest groups throughout the country, points to the body of evidence that associates waste-to-energy schemes with the release of toxins into the atmosphere. Dioxins, which can cause cancer and birth defects, have been cited in particular.

With waste-to-energy schemes an accepted part of waste management elsewhere in Europe, the UK's plan is in trouble even before it has been properly established. Many councils look like falling back on reuse of waste and recycling as the best available options.

Experience in Europe and North America, where just about every variant has been exhaustively tested, shows that the maximum level of recycling that is economically efficient is 40%. No one quarrels with composting, though most are a way off the performance of Austria with 14% of waste ground down as soil supplements. What is left is burning the waste or dumping it in landfill sites.

 Paul Brown is the Guardian's environment correspondent

paul.brown@theguardian.com

webTitle: After 500 years, the barriers remain

fields.headline: After 500 years, the barriers remain
fields.standfirst:
Organisers of next week's meeting between the Queen and the Pope are all too aware of the need to be discreet

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: It is sometimes overlooked just how sensitive relations between the British monarch and the papacy remain even in the 21st century, nearly 500 years after the secession of the Church of England from Rome.
fields.body:
It is sometimes overlooked just how sensitive relations between the British monarch and the papacy remain even in the 21st century, nearly 500 years after the secession of the Church of England from Rome.

Any visit between the Supreme Governor of the Church of England and Sovereign of Great Britain and the Bishop of Rome, Vicar of Jesus Christ, Successor of the Prince of the Apostles, High Pontiff of the Universal Church, Patriarch of the West, Primate of Italy, Archbishop and Metropolitan of the City of Rome, Servant of the Servants of God and Sovereign of the Vatican City State - all 110 acres of it - is bound to cause annoyance to someone.

For next week's visit, the Queen's third to Rome, even for a meeting of less than half an hour's duration with an aged and ailing pontiff - though one who is fewer than six years older than she is - there would have been more than usually delicate diplomatic negotiations. Courtiers have been dispatched to Rome at least twice to discuss the protocol of the meeting - as well as the rest of the state visit to Italy - to discuss what both sides hope to get out of it.

It is likely that that is when the idea of joint prayers was discussed and when soundings were taken in Britain.

The Foreign Office would have been consulted about the visit. Last night, after being approached by the Guardian, the Archbishop of Canterbury's staff reluctantly admitted that he had not been asked about prayers but declined to say what general advice he might have given on the meeting in the Vatican.

Sensitive

Forty years ago the then Archbishop of Canterbury - Dr Geoffrey Fisher - met a Pope, John XXIII, for the first time since the Reformation. So sensitive was the meeting that no photographs were taken.

Although visits by British monarchs have been going on for longer - since Edward VII paid a call in 1903 - they have mostly been in the way of tourist - almost sightseeing - jaunts, with long gaps between meetings and resolute downplaying of any possible significance.

It is not so long since the idea that Prince Charles might marry a Catholic was stamped upon. When the prince said he wanted to attend an early morning mass, his mother is said to have refused him permission to do so.

There are still sensitivities within the Church of England from fundamentalist Protestants - now little more than a sect but still a vociferous one, whose fortnightly church magazine, the English Churchman, routinely attacks the Pope as the anti-Christ. Its latest edition suggests that the Queen should remind the Pope of the 39 articles - promulgated as recently as 1571 to define what the church stands for - and ask whether he subscribes to them.

It naturally supports the Rev. Ian Paisley who demonstrated against the Pope's visit to Britain in 1982 and has been known to travel to Rome - into the very belly of the beast - to harangue the Vatican.

In this context, there are sensitivities to the situation in Northern Ireland, where the Queen is held up by loyalists as a symbol of the nation, even as republicans of Catholic origin insist that any reference to royalty should be dropped from local institutions such as the police force.

But it is not just the fundamentalists who were thought to have reservations about joint prayers. The Anglo-Catholic wing of the Church of England - firm believers in church and state - were also thought likely to be concerned that the head of the church should kneel down with the Pope, though some last night derided that suggestion as groundless.

For its part too, the Vatican has often failed to appreciate the unique position of the British monarchy as head of state and head of church.

It does tend to regard the Church of England as a bastard offshoot on an offshore island and only since the 1960s have British Catholics stopped praying for the reconversion of England.

When Dr Robert Runcie paid a four-day visit to Rome in 1989, during which he had six meetings with the Pope, for talks billed as bolstering the growing tide of ecumenism, the archbishop admitted that John Paul II appeared to have difficulty understanding the delicate constitutional balance in Britain. After all, the Pope is "supreme, full, immediate and universal" head of his church and - as last month's Vatican declaration Dominus Iesus showed - some in Rome have difficulty envisaging any other religious legitimacy at all.

The Roman Catholic church has problems with some Anglican tenets and the tide towards ecumenism appears to be stalled over the issue of the ordination of women but in many ways John Paul II ought to be able to recognise Queen Elizabeth, head of a church whose structure and practices are often so similar to those of his own.

And, after all, it was one of his predecessors who gave her ancestor the title of Defender of the Faith.

fields.headline: Workers turn on Milosevic cronies
fields.standfirst:
Staff oust bosses who were loyal to the former leader

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The crowds may have melted from the streets but Yugoslavia's revolution is continuing, surging into factories and offices to oust bosses loyal to the old regime.

The crowds may have melted from the streets but Yugoslavia's revolution is continuing, surging into factories and offices to oust bosses loyal to the old regime.

Academics, miners, policemen, secretaries and chefs are among the employees sweeping managers from their jobs in a wave of popular revenge.

Company directors are being escorted from their desks by strike committees determined to build a new country from the ground up. Last night, Jagos Puric, the rector of Belgrade University, looked likely to be the next victim. More than 70 colleagues crammed into the smoke-filled chamber next to his office to vote on his dismissal. Speakers took the microphone to denounce him as a stooge imposed by Slobodan Milosevic to control staff and students after university autonomy was abolished in 1998.

Lectures were suspended for the day but students lurked in the hallways to hear the outcome. "He won't survive. He allowed himself to be used by Milosevic. We all knew it but couldn't do anything about it," said Petar Petrovich, 30, a student of Serbian literature.

Mr Puric had not been seen since gathering his belongings from his office early in the morning. "Don't reckon he'll be back in a hurry," a smiling porter commented.

At the faculty of political science, meanwhile, a newly formed teachers' council dismissed Vladimir Stambuk, a dean and member of the Yugoslav Left, the party led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic.

On the outskirts of the city a police station was paralysed by officers' demands for the resignation of superiors who had tried to follow orders to suppress last week's protests.

And strikers at the Kolubara mine persuaded the Serbian electric power company to sack or suspend senior executives, including the managing director, Milan Obradovic.

Their colleagues at the RTB mine in Bor, near the Romanian border, dismissed their managing director and dissolved the board, while strikers at the 14 Oktobar machinery plant in Krusevac took over the running of the company after purging their board.

In Nis, workers stormed the state-run textile factory, Nitex, and demanded that its management be dismissed.

On it went. Any boss suspected of loyalty to the ousted president was at risk. But amid the euphoria, there was suspicion that the purges could mutate into personal vendettas and cronyism as the new elite manoeuvred for top jobs.

"A large number of people are hiding behind our name," said Zarko Korac, of the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (Dos).

But Zoran Sami, the vice-president of Dos, said that swift changes were necessary to stop the old regime exploiting the chaos. "We have taken over some of these institutions only temporarily to prevent this plunder."

President Vojislav Kostunica, promising "a wave of democratic change", has been leading the charge. He has installed his supporters into the police, judiciary, banks and state-run companies.

At Genex, the largest state-run import-export company, the ousting of the perma-tanned, dapper Radoman Bozovic was accompanied by cheers. As the firm's head, the former prime minister had controlled an empire which allegedly lined Mr Milosevic's pockets. After resigning, he was jostled and barred from taking his limousine.

Staff at the firm froze all financial transactions and called for the return of the former boss, Milorad Savicevic, who was forced to quit when Mr Milosevic rose to power.

But not all the mighty fell. Borka Vucic clicked across the marble floors of Investbanka's offices on Terazije Street as usual. Some staff demanded that their boss, who allegedly ran slush funds for Mr Milosevic, leave the building for her own safety. She thought otherwise and remained at her first-floor desk.

"She is a witch. Hanging from a tree is the best thing for her," said a female bank teller. "She knows all Slobo's secrets so the new government needs her help in tracking down the money. But it's not right that she keeps her job.

"The other bosses are like snakes. For the past two weeks they didn't know which side would win; now they're wriggling from their skins."

It would be a relief to no longer feign respect, but other staff reckoned it safer to hold their tongues. "It's very sad, but Borka is a survivor," said the teller.

 The French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, indicted for war crimes, like other western leaders, by Milosevic's regime, was met with a mixture of applause and abuse as he toured old Belgrade yesterday.

In talks with President Kostunica, Mr Védrine said a team of French specialists would arrive in Serbia this week to start assessing how the west can help repair the damage caused by Nato's bombing campaign.

webTitle: Arafat laughs off new Barak ultimatum

fields.headline: Arafat laughs off new Barak ultimatum
fields.standfirst:
Diplomatic efforts clouded by Lebanon-Israel tension

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Fears of an immediate war between Israel and the Palestinians went into momentary retreat yesterday after both sides yielded to dogged diplomatic efforts led by the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Tel Aviv and  Brian Whitaker  in Amman
fields.body:
Fears of an immediate war between Israel and the Palestinians went into momentary retreat yesterday after both sides yielded to dogged diplomatic efforts led by the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan.

But tensions ratcheted up a notch on the second front in the crisis to engulf the Middle East: the prospect of a renewed war between Israel and Lebanon. In Beirut yesterday, Hizbullah guerrillas stepped up their demands in return for the release of three Israeli soldiers kidnapped at the weekend. They said Israel must free 19 Lebanese men held illegally in Israeli jails for years, just to get information on the three soldiers.

After a day of diplomacy, punctuated by threats and isolated violence in the West Bank and Gaza, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday finessed his ultimatum to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to end the violence or consider the peace process dead.

The morning after the expiry of his earlier deadline, he said he was willing to give the Palestinians a few more days. "If we find ourselves in a long, painful, difficult confrontation of many long months, there'll be no importance to our having held on for another 72 or 96 hours," Mr Barak said.

His adversaries appeared underwhelmed. "Threats, threats, threats," Mr Arafat told reporters, laughing at the extension of the deadline. "Unfortunately, there are still violent clashes in which the Israeli army is using tanks, artillery, rockets and helicopters against our people."

The true solution to the crisis, the Palestinians argue, would be to convene an international investigation into the violence. Last night Mr Barak hinted that he might accept an inquiry under US auspices.

Mr Annan pronounced himself pleased. "I think we can rein in the situation. I think we have a window of opportunity to do it," he said.

With Palestinian activists calling for all-out war, including attacks on some 200,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank, and the kidnapping of Israeli soldiers, Mr Annan appears to have produced only a tentative peace.

After the carnage of the past days - more than 90 dead, almost all Palestinian, and more than 2,000 injured - it is politically impossible for Mr Arafat to publicly declare an end to protests or to engage wholeheartedly in negotiations for a peace settlement.

Yesterday, more than 1,000 Palestinian officials and intellectuals signed a petition deploring the killings and calling on Mr Arafat to suspend peace talks with Israel.

The worst violence erupted in Gaza, where a boy, thought to be as young as nine years old, was declared brain dead after being shot in the head by Israeli soldiers. In the West Bank town of Hebron, Jewish settlers traded gunfire with Palestinian villagers overnight, and there were angry demonstrations in Ramallah.

With neither Mr Barak nor Mr Arafat prepared to offer iron-clad guarantees for a cessation of hostilities, international diplomatic efforts look likely to continue. The British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is expected to travel to the region today.

Any signs of progress in averting confrontation between Israel and the Palestinians was offset by the raising of the stakes in Israel's showdown with Hizbullah guerrillas.

Israeli anxieties about the fate of the three soldiers deepened after the army said yes terday that it had positively identified bloodstains near the scene of their abduction. Mr Barak said he held Lebanon, and Syria, which has 35,000 troops in that country, directly responsible for their fate.

Yesterday, a Hizbullah spokesman said the price for answering questions about the men and any future questions was "that Israel must release all Lebanese prisoners and detainees in the occupation jails". The Islamist militia is also seeking the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, mainly members of the Hamas and Islamic Jihad.

webTitle: Serb journalist who was first to publicise atrocities is freed

fields.headline: Serb journalist who was first to publicise atrocities is freed
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: A Serb journalist who was jailed this summer after interviewing soldiers about atrocities in Kosovo was released yesterday pending a new trial.
fields.body:
A Serb journalist who was jailed this summer after interviewing soldiers about atrocities in Kosovo was released yesterday pending a new trial.

Miroslav Filipovic, who wrote for the independent Danas daily and the London-based Institute for War and Peace Reporting, had been sentenced to seven years in jail by a military court in Nis for publicising state secrets and "spreading false information".

Western governments and human rights organisations had condemned the sentence.

Two British policemen and a Canadian, charged with espionage, and four Dutchmen, accused of plotting to kill Mr Milosevic, were freed at the weekend by the new president.

The government's Tanjug news agency said Mr Filipovic was not amnestied, but released because of "faulty court procedure". It did not give further details.

But the move is the latest sign of a relaxation since Slobodan Milosevic's overthrow.

"I feel wonderful. I believe that justice will be fulfilled be cause I am completely innocent," Mr Filipovic said as he left prison.

In the first article by a Serb to discuss war crimes by Serbian forces against Albanian civilians in Kosovo, Mr Filipovic had cited what he said was a secret Yugoslav army intelligence report on atrocities. It included testimony from a commander who admitted watching a soldier decapitate a three-year-old boy in front of his family.

Another soldier told how tanks indiscriminately shelled a Kosovo Albanian village before paramilitary police moved in and massacred survivors.

While the crimes described were well-known in the outside world as Albanian eyewitnesses poured out of Kosovo during the war, they were suppressed in Serbia by a combination of self-censorhip and bans by editors.

"I have no regret", Mr Filipovic said. "I criticised atrocities of individuals, not the nation as a whole. I will be able to prove that everything I wrote was not false. It was not the Serb people who did it, but criminals."

webTitle: 'It's nothing personal. It's Arab against Jew'

fields.headline: 'It's nothing personal. It's Arab against Jew'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli newspapers declared a state of civil war yesterday, hours after mosques and Arab businesses in Tel Aviv were besieged by Jewish mobs in a night of mayhem.
fields.body:
Israeli newspapers declared a state of civil war yesterday, hours after mosques and Arab businesses in Tel Aviv were besieged by Jewish mobs in a night of mayhem.

The attacks in the city were the worst explosion of sectarian hatred since the Jewish state was created 52 years ago.

"Today you have a chasm that will take years to bridge. The last years we had succeeded - a great part of society - in finding a formula for Jews and Arabs to live together," said Joseph Algazy, a veteran commentator on the Israeli Arab community for the liberal Ha'aretz newspaper. "Now this is destroyed. The poison seed has been planted, and it will not be easy to root it out, or to forget."

On the beachfront in the southern suburb of Bat Yam, a young man named after an Israeli war hero slouched on a car outside the smashed shutters and glass display-cases of the Victoria ice-cream parlour, savouring his handiwork of the night before.

"We are not going to sit quiet anymore. The government does not do anything to stop the Arabs, so we have to take the law into our own hands," said Moshe Dayan, 22.

His friend, Meir Moyal, who was also present when a mob of hundreds of Jews destroyed the Arab-owned business with their bare hands, said: "This is a Jewish area, and there should only be Jews here."

Until Monday night, however, that would never have occurred to Simon Sasin, the owner of the shop. Although ethnically a Palestinian, he says he speaks Hebrew better now than his mother tongue, Arabic. "I know it's nothing personal," he said. "It's just Arab against Jew."

Increasingly, that is the way it is beginning to appear in much of Israel, as ugly attacks on Israeli Arabs spread across the country.

The unravelling of Israel's delicate social fabric began last week when Arab Israelis in northern Galilee began to protest in solidarity with their Palestinian cousins in the West Bank and Gaza.

That display of anger was in itself enough to send pulses racing in many parts of Israel. But the destruction of a Jewish pilgrimage site in Nablus by Palestinian mobs at the weekend sent those passions spinning out of control.

On two consecutive nights this week, Jewish mobs attacked the 200-year-old Hassan Bek mosque in central Tel Aviv. They destroyed the storeroom with a petrol bomb before returning after evening prayers on Monday. "They stood at the gates and started screaming: 'Death to Arabs' and throwing stones," said Nuwar Daka, the imam.

The police arrived promptly and pushed the mob back, but the Arab community is still fearful. Several Arab men stand on the mosque's front steps; they say they will spend their nights here. Several people said they were afraid to turn up to work for their Jewish employers.

"Everybody is afraid - Jew and Arab. We don't know what is going on, and how we arrived at this. Who knows? Maybe we are going to start shooting at each other," said Yakub Yusuf, an accountant.

webTitle: £8m Michelangelo unearthed

fields.headline: £8m Michelangelo unearthed
fields.trailText: A Sotheby's art expert, flicking through an album of drawings for a routine insurance valuation at Castle Howard, the mansion near York ,has uncovered a lost early Michelangelo, valued at up to £8m.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A Sotheby's art expert, flicking through an album of drawings for a routine insurance valuation at Castle Howard, the mansion near York ,has uncovered a lost early Michelangelo, valued at up to £8m.

The drawing of a heavily draped woman is in superb condition, despite having been glued into the album almost 200 years ago.

It is one of a handful of Michelangelo works still in private hands.

The identification was made by Julien Stock, Sotheby's Old Master drawings expert, who was trawling through dozens of volumes of drawings in the library.

Castle Howard has a renowned art collection in cluding several Holbeins and works by Rubens, Gainsborough and Reynolds

Simon Howard, who lives in one wing of the house, which featured in the television version of Brideshead Revisited, said the discovery came as a surprise -but meant the immediate loss of the drawing to the house.

The cost of insuring it would be prohibitive, he said. "It should be on display in a national gallery or museum where everyone can enjoy it."

James Millery, deputy chairman of Sotheby's, said: "It's like finding part of the Holy Grail. Everyone is extremely excited. It is the most significant Michelangelo work to be discovered in living memory."

There are major collections of Michelangelo drawings in the British Museum, in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, and in the Royal Collection. Sotheby's is in discussions with the National Gallery of Scotland, Edinburgh, which already has a number of works from Castle Howard.

A spokeswoman for the gallery said: "There is no Michelangelo in a public collection north of Oxford. This has left us with a great deal of thinking to do."

The gallery's trustees will meet this week to decide whether to try to acquire the drawing, which has been offered as a private treaty sale.

However, director Timothy Clifford has already expressed interest in another Michelangelo, a working drawing for his late sculpture of the risen Christ, sold at Christie's last summer for £8.14m.

It is believed to have been acquired for the Metropolitan in New York, but is likely to have a temporary bar imposed if an export licence is sought, allowing a British institution time to match the sale price.

webTitle: Supermarkets inquiry rejects rip-off charges

fields.headline: Supermarkets inquiry rejects rip-off charges
fields.trailText: The UK's biggest supermarket chains were cleared yesterday of profiteering and overcharging - but ordered to draw up a legally binding code of conduct to ensure they deal more fairly with their suppliers.
fields.body:
The UK's biggest supermarket chains were cleared yesterday of profiteering and overcharging - but ordered to draw up a legally binding code of conduct to ensure they deal more fairly with their suppliers.

The findings are the result of an investigation by competition authorities which has taken more than two years to complete.

The inquiry, estimated to have cost £20m, was ordered in 1998, when the government launched a crusade against "rip-off Britain". But since then the supermarket business has changed dramatically. Price wars broke out and US discount giant Wal-Mart bought out Asda.

The final report of the Competition Commission, which runs to three volumes and more than 1,100 pages, largely exonerates the big grocers, which dominate the £90bn UK food market.

The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, said the competition watchdog was "satisfied that the industry is broadly competitive and that overall excessive prices are not being charged nor excessive profits earned".

But the commission did identify three situations "where competition is distorted and operates against the public interest". It criticised the big supermarkets for their dealings with suppliers and recommended that a code of conduct be put in place.

The watchdog also targeted supermarkets which sell below cost prices and carry out "price flexing" - changing prices according to store locations and local competition. These two practices, said the commission, distort competition and are against the public interest.

But in both cases the watchdog is to take no action because the remedies "would themselves have adverse effects".

Supermarkets have been heavily criticised for the power they wield over small suppliers, especially farmers, whose livelihoods depend on getting their produce on the supermarkets' shelves. Last year the store groups faced a stream of protests that they were squeezing ever lower prices for produce while shelf prices remained unchanged.

Under the new code, supermarkets will have to spell out their terms of business in writing, give reasonable notice if they want to change those terms and pay up promptly for goods delivered. They will be banned from current practices such as charging suppliers for visits by their buyers, demanding contributions towards store refurbishments and asking for payments to keep goods on their shelves.

webTitle: Three IT pioneers share Nobel prize for technology fathers

fields.headline: Three IT pioneers share Nobel prize for technology fathers
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A Russian and two Americans who sparked the information technology revolution shared the Nobel prize for physics yesterday.
fields.body:
A Russian and two Americans who sparked the information technology revolution shared the Nobel prize for physics yesterday.

The £634,000 prize went to Zhores Alferov, 70, of St Petersburg, Herbert Kroemer, 73, of Santa Barbara, California and Jack Kilby, 77, of Texas. Prof Kilby was honoured for his part in the invention of the microchip, or the monolithic integrated circuit. The other two invented and developed the semiconductors that made fast transistors possible.

Between them they paved the way for radio link satellites, mobile phones, CD players, bar code readers, laser pointers, magnetic resonance cameras, electronic watches, pocket calculators and personal computers.

"Two simple but fundamental requirements are put on a modern information system for it to be practically useful," the Swedish Royal Academy of Sciences said yesterday.

"It must be fast, so that large volumes of information can be transferred in a short time. The user's apparatus must be small, so that there is room for it in offices, homes or pockets.

"Through their inventions, this year's Nobel laureates laid a stable foundation for modern information technology."

Prof Kilby holds 60 US patents. His first simple microchip - developed at Texas Instruments on September 12, 1958 - became the basis of a trillion dollar industry.

"Without Kilby it would not have been possible to build the personal computers we have today," said Hermann Grimeiss, of the Swedish Royal Academy.

"And without Alferov, it would not be possible to transfer all the information from satellites down to earth or to have so many telephone lines between cities."

The Nobel prize for chemistry, also announced yesterday, is shared by two Americans and a Japanese, for their work on plastics that conduct electricity.

They were Alan Heeger, 64, at the University of Santa Barbara, Alan MacDiarmid, 73, born in New Zealand but now at the University of Pennsylvania, and Hidei Shirakawa, 64, at the University of Tsukuba, Japan.

Their research has led to anti-static substances for photographic film and radiation shields on computer screens. Their polymers have also been used in solar cells, mobile phone displays, mini television screens and "smart" windows that block bright sunlight.
