webTitle: NHS ban on flu drug may be eased for at-risk patients

fields.headline: NHS ban on flu drug may be eased for at-risk patients
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The NHS is expected to row back on its ban on Relenza and allow use of the anti-flu drug for some elderly patients, asthmatics and other at-risk groups this winter.
fields.body:
The NHS is expected to row back on its ban on Relenza and allow use of the anti-flu drug for some elderly patients, asthmatics and other at-risk groups this winter.

Under new guidance from advisers, the effective ban on GPs using it for state-funded patients that was imposed last year will be relaxed within the next few weeks in time for the worst of the annual flu season. Doctors will be told, however, not to prescribe the treatment for mainstream flu sufferers.

Even those who might benefit from the new limited availability will usually be expected to have been immunised first, although GPs cannot compel patients to have flu jabs.

Nice, the national institute for clinical excellence, which monitors the cost-effectiveness of NHS treatments and has prompted rows over alleged rationing, is understood to be changing its guidance. Proposals from its appraisal committee, which met last month, have been sent to health professionals, and an announcement will be made soon.

NHS leaders are worried about the possibility of huge extra bills if Relenza were to become freely available, because its cost, £24 for a five-day course, is vastly more expensive than immunisation. GPs also fear they could not possibly meet demand and believe paracetemol, hot drinks and a couple of days in bed are adequate for the vast majority of otherwise healthy flu sufferers.

However, 500 people in England and Wales are believed to have died directly because of flu last winter. Others are believed to have died from complications that might be linked to the illness.

Nice advisers now believe that Glaxo Wellcome, the manufacturer of Relenza, has made a case that its product will benefit some patients. These might include some with diabetes and severe heart problems and others with respiratory problems.

Last year Nice said there was not enough evidence that the drug prevented serious complications, such as pneumonia, in patients deemed at risk.

It argued then that clinical trials in otherwise healthy individuals reduced the average duration of flu symptoms only from six days to five and that it would be irresponsible for it to be generally available through GPs at the busiest time of the year, especially since it should be prescribed within two days of the onset of symptoms to be effective.

Last year's decision severely dented Glaxo Wellcome's hopes for the drug, which is administered by inhaler. This year it warned that there were possible side-effects for people with asthma and severe lung conditions.

In Britain, its use is mainly restricted to private practice, where it is believed up to 8,000 prescriptions have been issued. Sales worldwide are thought to amount to nearly £20m, mainly in the United States.

Nice last night refused to discuss new guidance but said it would be issued late this month or early next month. Consideration last year had been fast-tracked because the government wanted advice before the flu season started, a spokeswoman said.

The institute had always said that it would review the guidance.

The Department of Health would not comment beyond saying: "Once their guidance is issued, we expect health authorities to follow it. We are monitoring uptake of guidance [from Nice]. Ultimately the decision is still up to clinicians."

Glaxo Wellcome declined to comment.

webTitle: Old guard battles to regain control of police force

fields.headline: Old guard battles to regain control of police force
fields.standfirst:
Socialists hold up creation of government

Special report: Serbia
Milosevic's Socialist party
Democratic Opposition of Serbia
Serbia's Ministry of Information
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party colleagues are trying to regain control over the Serbian police, according to Zoran Djindjic, a key member of the crisis committee set up by Yugoslavia's new leader.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party colleagues are trying to regain control over the Serbian police, according to Zoran Djindjic, a key member of the crisis committee set up by Yugoslavia's new leader.

As revenge attacks and sackings of former regime officials continued yesterday, he said that the Socialist party (SPS) wanted "to be in charge of the police so as not to be victimised by people's anger".

The Socialist party's extraordinary demand was holding up negotiations on forming a new government. Mr Djindjic tried to make light of the row, saying that since the resignation of the former police minister, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, on Monday "no one is in charge of the police. The police is not a car that needs a driver."

But there is anxiety that groups within the police, and particularly the security services, are trying to regroup. Mr Djindjic said: "What we know informally is that high-level surveillance is again under way. A week ago it was cut off but then they activated some other sources of monitoring ... We know they are bugging, that there is fierce surveillance and an attempt at consolidation within those forces."

He also revealed that the country had come close to war the day after protesters used an excavator to smash their way into the federal parliament, and the constitutional court announced that Vojislav Kostunica had won the election. "People around Milosevic gave orders for the army to move on Friday and Saturday. If they had acted, we would have had civil war", he said.

The last-minute delay in forming a Serbian government surprised the country's new rulers. The 19-party alliance which defeated Mr Milosevic for the Yugoslav presidency assumed it would run the country on its own. But in return for agreeing to early elections for a new Serbian parliament in December, the Socialists are insisting on having ministers in the transitional government which will operate until then.

The Socialists are the largest party in the Serb parliament, which was elected in 1997. Talks between Mr Kostunica's allies and the Socialists, as well as the Serbian Renewal Movement led by Vuk Draskovic, dragged into a second day.

Vojislav Seselj, the leader of the ultra-rightwing Radical party, pulled his officials out of the talks in protest at the stones and abuse hurled at him outside the Serbian parliament on Monday. Hundreds of demonstrators threatened to storm the building in the same way they broke into the federal parliament last week.

Mr Seselj is playing a double game. Although he agreed to early elections in private talks on Monday, he used his speech during the parliament's televised proceedings to claim that Mr Kostunica's people were conducting "a coup".

While the Socialists continue their obstruction in the Serbian government, Mr Milosevic is in contact with them by mobile phone, according to Bratislav Grubacic, a Belgrade analyst. "They're still hypnotised by this man," he said.

But Socialist party officials also see the danger they are in if they try to resist the tide of change. Mr Grubacic said: "On Sunday night, before the Serbian parliament met, I got a nervous call from a friend in the SPS. 'Will you be using the bulldozers again?', he wanted to know.

"After the session ended with an agreement on early elections, he rang again and said: 'The bulldozers can go back to the garage, I hope'."

Miroljub Labus, the head of the crisis committee who called himself "acting prime minister", said yesterday that he supported the sacking of Milosevic cronies who are directors of state-owned companies, provided that all staff agreed on the measure.

He indicated that it was good to go back to the old system of self-management instituted by Tito after the second world war.

"We can't allow chaos in the enterprises," he said. "The trade unions should decide on removing the directors ... We need to restore self-management temporarily, and then move to privatisation and the normal management of a market economy."

webTitle: A better deal in store for suppliers

fields.headline: A better deal in store for suppliers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Tesco's chief executive Terry Leahy has worked hard to cultivate his New Labour credentials. The boss of Britain's biggest supermarket chain sits on four government taskforces and is known to have the ear of Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Tesco's chief executive Terry Leahy has worked hard to cultivate his New Labour credentials. The boss of Britain's biggest supermarket chain sits on four government taskforces and is known to have the ear of Tony Blair.

So it was a shock, in the summer of 1998, when government ministers began bandying around the words "rip-off Britain", attacking the supermarket industry with obvious relish.

Mr Leahy has always argued that Britain's supermarkets are among the most competitive in the world, fighting regular price wars and battling for the best development sites. Yet suddenly his industry was subject to an investigation by the office of fair trading.

For a government short of targets, supermarkets have been easy to demonise. There has always been a perception that goods are cheaper in the rest of Europe, and the disparity between farm gate and retail prices throws up some astonishing statistics. Why, for example, should farmers get less than 5p for a pound of potatoes sold in the shops for close to 30p?

Despite the popularity of out-of-town superstores, many Britons dislike the way their local high streets have fallen on hard times. So there was little to lose politically in attacking the big merchants.

During its inquiry, the competition commission has received thousands of submissions highlighting the overwhelming power of big retailers. Lutterworth and District Dairy, for example, wrote that it was seeing the most alarming changes in its 100-year history due to "the fierce activities of the multiples" in undercutting doorstep milkmen.

The Federation of Bakers claimed that by selling loaves for as little as 17p, the chains were making massive losses. By subsidising bread sales with profits from other goods, supermarkets were driving small bakers out of business.

The National Consumers' Council was worried about "choice and value for money". There were similar cries of pain from local authorities, environmentalists and private individuals.

The commission's problem was that the complaints came from both directions- one claim was that the supermarkets charged too much, ripping off consumers, an other was that they charged too little, driving smaller rivals to the ground.

A close look at supermarkets' profits scotched the impression that they were prospering at everyone else's expense. The commission found that British chains were less profitable than their rivals in the rest of Eu rope and that average earnings have fallen since 1996, largely due to the poor performance of some supermarket chains.

The authors added, however, that profits "had been higher in previous years", suggesting that the investigation had come too late.

Paul Smiddy, a retail ana lyst at City bank Credit Lyonnais, said: "That the result of this inquiry is next to nothing is not a total surprise. It was always going to be difficult for Byers to come up with measures which were both practical and which achieved anything."

But he said the report had exposed the way some super markets treated food producers: "It will make crass, brutish behaviour towards suppliers more difficult."

The commission has settled for a code of conduct forcing supermarkets to be more gentlemanly with their farming suppliers. They will have to give reasonable notice of changes to their orders, pay their bills on time and stop demanding payment to give products more prominence. They will also have to consult more carefully on further out-of-town superstores.

Mr Leahy can breathe a sigh of relief and go back to plotting his next merger. But for Britain's embattled farmers, the pain goes on.

Shelf life: the main points

No excessive profits or prices

Supermarket industry is "broadly competitive"

Three situations where competition is distorted and operates against the public interest:

1) The relationship between big supermarkets and their suppliers. An enforceable code of conduct to be set up banning many current practices, such as demanding payments from suppliers and changing agreed prices retrospectively or without notice. Disputes procedure to be included in the code

2) Selling below cost prices. May be good for low income consumers but bad for smaller rival retailers. But no action to be taken because remedies would have adverse effects disproportionate to the problem

3) Changing prices according to local competition. Distorts local competition. But no action to be taken as again remedies would have adverse effects disproportionate to the problem

There is a limited choice of supermarkets in some areas. Commission did not make an adverse finding, but said the situation should not be allowed to deteriorate further. New planning legislation would be required to address this problem, and the trade and industry secretary to consider it if necessary

webTitle: Campaigners scorn Straw's cannabis warning

fields.headline: Campaigners scorn Straw's cannabis warning
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A claim by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday that cannabis was two to four times more dangerous than tobacco was last night challenged by drug law reform campaigners.
fields.body:
A claim by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday that cannabis was two to four times more dangerous than tobacco was last night challenged by drug law reform campaigners.

Dame Ruth Runciman, who chaired the Police Foundation's landmark inquiry into the drug laws this year, insisted that while cannabis was not harmless it was still less dangerous than alcohol or tobacco.

Meanwhile, Charles Clarke became the first serving minister since the current debate began to admit he had smoked dope. The Home Office minister responsible for the police confirmed he had lit up in his younger years though friends stressed it had happened rarely.

Mr Straw, who yesterday said he had never used cannabis, argued that the law should not be changed as pharmacologists and psychiatrists had testified that the drug could have very severe effects.

"The long-term effects include a very severe exacerbation of mental illness and also include cancer," he said. "It is reckoned that cannabis is between two and four times as carcinogenic as tobacco. If cannabis were legalised, then consumption of a drug for which the evidence is very strong that it is harmful will unquestionably increase."

While a cigarette smoker might get through a pack of 20 a day it was highly unlikely that somebody would smoke 20 joints a day. They also said that if Mr Straw's only argument was that it was dangerous to smoke dope then it would be a recipe for everybody to eat it instead.

Dame Runciman's inquiry report quotes the BMA's conclusion that "the acute toxicity of cannabinoids [the active ingredient] is extremely low: they are very safe drugs and no deaths have been directly attributed to their recreational or therapeutic use".

She said yesterday: "Our view is that cannabis is not a harmless drug, but in terms of the main criteria of harm, which are mortality, morbidity, relationship with crime, addictiveness, etc, it is less dangerous than all the other main illicit drugs, or than alcohol or tobacco."

webTitle: Hepatitis C victims sue NHS for millions

fields.headline: Hepatitis C victims sue NHS for millions
fields.standfirst:
Consumer Act used to press case against blood service
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: More than 100 people infected with the hepatitis C virus through receiving blood transfusions, blood products or organ transplants launched a high court claim yesterday that could cost the NHS millions of pounds in damages.
fields.body:
More than 100 people infected with the hepatitis C virus through receiving blood transfusions, blood products or organ transplants launched a high court claim yesterday that could cost the NHS millions of pounds in damages.

The case is the first group action to reach court under the 1987 Consumer Protection Act, which came into force in March 1988 and was intended to allow people injured by a defective product to claim compensation without proving that the manufacturer or supplier was negligent.

The act was brought in to implement the European directive on product liability, which imposed "strict liability" - without proof of fault - for defective products. Lawyers will be watching the outcome of the case closely because the act has proved problematic in practice and has been used seldom since it became law.

The latest claims follow a compensation battle in the 1980s by people infected with HIV through blood, blood products and transplants. The government eventually settled those claims out of court in the early 1990s but has refused to compensate people infected with hepatitis C.

The legal action at the high court in London, brought by 112 people represented by six "lead" cases, is expected to last three months. Michael Brooke QC, for the claimants, told Mr Justice Burton that those bringing the case had been infected over the years since March 1 1988, when the act came into force, and were infected with the hepatitis C virus (HCV) "in a wide range of circumstances".

Some had transfusions after childbirth, during planned operations, or during surgery after an accident. Others were receiving treatment for blood disorders such as leukaemia.

The claimants, who have been granted anonymity by the judge, have launched their claims against the national blood authority (NBA) in England and the Velindre NHS trust in Wales, which are contesting the action. The defendants are the NHS bodies answerable today for the production and supply of blood and blood products by the national blood transfusion service since March 1 1988, Mr Brooke said.

The virus causes inflammation of the liver, but the long-term prognosis is uncertain in any particular case. Some people spontaneously "clear" the virus, meaning that traces of it no longer appear in their blood. Many do not experience symptoms or liver changes for a long time but have the threat hanging over them for years, Mr Brooke told the judge. Some people progress eventually to liver disease, cirrhosis and liver cancer, and the virus can be fatal.

He said the court would have to investigate the discovery of HCV, which was identified in May 1988, and "may have to consider the introduction of safety procedures to reduce the risk to people of being infected with the virus by blood and blood products, both as it in fact progressed in this country, and as it could have done".

For the defendants, Nicholas Underhill QC said there was no way that the risk of HCV infection could have been prevented at the time the Consumer Protection Act came into force in March 1988.

He added: "Mr Brooke is right to say that a time did come when a screening test did become available; and that that test was introduced later in this country than in most - though not all - other countries in the developed world.

"The NBA does not accept that the moment that the first country introduces screening, unscreened blood products in every other country automatically become defective."

Mr Underhill said: "There were good reasons why the national blood transfusion service (NBTS) in the UK did not move as fast as the fastest other countries. The NBA believes that the NBTS acted sensibly and appropriately in the measures taken for the introduction of screening and does not believe that there is any basis for legal liability."

webTitle: Lib-Lab pact firm despite resignation

fields.headline: Lib-Lab pact firm despite resignation
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership in Wales said yesterday its alliance with the Liberal Democrats would not be disrupted by the abrupt resignation of the assembly's education secretary, Tom Middlehurst, on Monday.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership in Wales said yesterday its alliance with the Liberal Democrats would not be disrupted by the abrupt resignation of the assembly's education secretary, Tom Middlehurst, on Monday.

Mr Middlehurst said that bringing the Lib Dems into cabinet was "too high a price to pay" for stable government. Days earlier the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, and the Lib Dem assembly leader, Mike German, had agreed a partnership giving Lib Dems two of nine cab- inet posts, in order to end the turbulence of minority rule since devolution.

Mr German is expected to be deputy first secretary if his party approves. Mr Middlehurst attacked the six-strong Lib Dem group for conspiring with Conservatives and Plaid Cymru to censure the former agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther, and, in "the ultimate act of treachery", helping bring down Alun Michael, previous first secretary.

webTitle: Britain builds up Sierra Leone force

fields.headline: Britain builds up Sierra Leone force
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The government announced a significant increase in its military presence in Sierra Leone yesterday, in effect placing a British command structure in the strife-torn west African country.
fields.body:
The government announced a significant increase in its military presence in Sierra Leone yesterday, in effect placing a British command structure in the strife-torn west African country.

A British brigadier will be sent to Freetown with his own headquarters, while senior British officers will be attached to the UN force in the country and to UN headquarters in New York.

Baroness Symons, the defence procurement minister, also told the Lords that up to 5,000 British troops - a brigade already on offer in principle to the UN - would if necessary be deployed in Sierra Leone.

Senior British officials at a Nato defence ministers' meeting in Birmingham described the rapid reaction brigade as an "over-the-horizon force" that could go into Sierra Leone "in extremis".

They insisted, however, that it would remain under British control, and ultimately under the command of the prime minister, and would not form part of Unamsil, the UN peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone.

In the short term, the number of British troops in Sierra Leone will be increased from about 300 to at least 400, to step up training for the Sierra Leone army. A further 60 British soldiers are participating in an international advisory team.

British officials said the moves did not amount to a "massive mission creep", and added that there were no plans "at the moment" for British troops to get involved in combat against rebels.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said British forces would be in Sierra Leone until at least next year.

By placing a brigade headquarters - in the words of Baroness Symons - "to command the overall UK effort and to provide high-level operational advice to the Sierra Leone army", the government clearly believes that its earlier limited plans to help train the local soldiers were far too optimistic.

Its decision to strengthen the UN military mission in Freetown also suggests that it remains deeply concerned about the calibre of senior officers in Unamsil. The British army has trained 3,000 members of the Sierra Leone army so far and aims to train a further 3,000 by spring next year.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said the move reaffirmed Britain's commitment to democracy. "The decision to train 3,000 more troops for the Sierra Leone army will contribute significantly to their ability to take the fight to the rebels," he said.

A foreign office source said the role of the UN was to go in behind the Sierra Leone army in support, rather than spearheading the assault on the rebel Revolutionary United Front, and that was why training was to vital.

But Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, said that Sierra Leone had become a personal issue for Mr Cook and that was why the government's policy kept changing. "Labour is clearly making their policy on Sierra Leone on the hoof," he said.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, has been scouring the world, trying to build up the Unamsil force, which has been riven by rows between the Nigerian and Indian contingents. Its current strength is 13,000, but India is to pull out its 3,000 troops, mainly because of the arguments with the Nigerians.

Bangladesh, which has a small contingent in Sierra Leone, has offered to increase its force, but that still leaves the UN well short.

Mr Annan has gone back to countries that have offered to provide troops for other UN peacekeeping operations in Africa - for the Congo and Eritrea - and asked them to switch them instead to Sierra Leone, saying that this was the priority. The UN needs a success against the rebels to rebuild the credibility of its peacekeeping operations.

Mr Annan has on his desk a shortlist of commanders to take over Unamsil in place of the Indian officer, General Vijay Jetley, who resigned.

webTitle: Kosovo security is Nato's priority

fields.headline: Kosovo security is Nato's priority
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Nato defence ministers adopted a softly-softly approach yesterday to Slobodan Milosevic and others indicted for war crimes, making it clear that the alliance's immediate worry is the possibility of renewed political instability, and security concerns in Kosovo.
fields.body:
Nato defence ministers adopted a softly-softly approach yesterday to Slobodan Milosevic and others indicted for war crimes, making it clear that the alliance's immediate worry is the possibility of renewed political instability, and security concerns in Kosovo.

The problem of what to do with indicted war criminals was "fundamentally a legal issue", Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, declared during an informal meeting of allied defence ministers in Birmingham.

Although Walter Slocombe, the US undersecretary for defence, told journalists that "Milosevic and all the others indicted should be accountable before the [Hague war crimes] tribunal", a Nato official insisted later that it was not "the dominant issue".

Nato's most pressing concern is the outcome of elections in Kosovo on October 28, when the vast majority of ethnic Albanians are expected to vote for independence - an outcome that Nato governments firmly oppose.

The defence ministers adopted a wary approach towards Vojislav Kostunica, Yugoslavia's new president and no friend of Nato. "We should drink from the cup of euphoria but not too deeply," one said.

They are also awaiting conciliatory measures from Mr Kostunica, including the release of some 700 Kosovan Albanians in Serb prisons.

William Cohen, the US defence secretary, issued a blunt warning to EU governments to back up their plans for close defence and security cooperation with practical steps to improve their ability to mount speedy and effective operations in response to crises.

It would be a serious waste of resources, he said, "if Nato in the EU were to proceed along the path of relying on autonomous force planning structures".

Mr Cohen insisted that non-EU Nato countries, notably Turkey, should be fully consulted about the union's decisions on defence.

webTitle: Two girls swept into river

fields.headline: Two girls swept into river
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: An air and land search was under way in North Yorkshire last night after two teenage girls were swept into a river during a school trip.
fields.body:
An air and land search was under way in North Yorkshire last night after two teenage girls were swept into a river during a school trip.

Cave rescue teams and RAF helicopters led the search after the two, both 14, fell into Stainforth Beck, near Settle, at around 3.30pm.

A search near a waterfall where the beck joins the river Ribble failed to find the girls, and rescue teams concentrated their search on the river during the afternoon.

Acting inspector Stuart Mackleston of North Yorkshire police confirmed that the two had been "river walking" with 13 other pupils and two teachers from the Royds school in Oulton, West Yorkshire.

They were all walking up stream in the beck when one of the girls got her foot stuck between stones, and lost her balance when her boot came off.

Mr Mackleston said: "A teacher tried to steady her, as did another student, but the girl fell over, dragging the other student with her. Both were swept away."

The missing girls' parents were being kept informed, he said.

Police helicopters with heat seeking equipment made a sweep of the area at 6pm last night, with no success. Although forces from across the county border in Lancashire had lent equipment and support, police said nightfall and heavy rain made it hard to continue.

A police spokesman said: "We have searched the beck and the Ribble as far as Settle, and helicopter have searched this far and well on into Lancashire."

He said a further search would be made later in the evening when the river level had dropped.

The beck, usually about 10 metres across and two metres deep, had been swollen throughout the day by rainwater from overnight storms.

It lies at the western edge of the Yorkshire Dales in the shadow of Pen-y-ghent and close to the Settle and Carlisle railway line.

The area is popular with walkers, cavers and school parties, but rivers in a land scape famous for its limestone rocks can turn from streams to torrents after the kind of continuous rain which has fallen for the past three days.

Police said the group of 15 boys and girls had been out river walking as part of a week long school trip to the Yorkshire Dales.

A boy had also fallen into the beck but had been rescued by a teacher.

As weather conditions deteriorated and night began to close in, residents from the village of Stainforth joined in the search for the two girls.

When asked whether there was any hope of finding the them alive in the river, a spokesman from North York shire police said: "Miracles do happen."

A shop assistant working in Settle, 10 miles south of the search area, said that when he heard about the search, "I phoned home immediately to check whether my little brother and sister were OK, but customers are telling me they [the missing teenagers] were on a school trip from Leeds."

Roger Whittaker, spokesman for the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents, said rivers were at their most dangerous at this time of year as heavy rainfall combined with cold temperatures.

Mr Whittaker emphasised that the only safe place to swim was a properly supervised pool or beach.

Recent figures had shown that more and more children and young teenagers were drowning in rivers and streams across the UK.

More than 54 children aged under 15 drowned in rivers last year, he said, compared with 36 in 1998.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Paul Mason, 22, on remand for burglary, killed himself by hanging while in a double cell at Birmingham jail, the prison service said yesterday. It was the third death this year at the jail.
fields.body:
Remand inmate kills himself

Paul Mason, 22, on remand for burglary, killed himself by hanging while in a double cell at Birmingham jail, the prison service said yesterday. It was the third death this year at the jail.

Health files found by road

Confidential files on 26 mental patients were found by a road in Northumberland. They were returned to Gateshead NHS trust, which called in police.

Rampaging bullock shot

Police shot dead a bullock after it escaped from a livestock market and rampaged through Malton in North Yorkshire. A man received minor head injuries.

Elderly couple's suicide pact

Thames police said yesterday they believed a couple in their 70s had killed themselves. Jack Lowy, a retired professor with leukaemia, and Ruth, his wife, were discovered at their bungalow in Oxford.

Cigarette factory arrests

Customs raided a factory in Halesowen, West Midlands, and found a cigarette making machine and eight tonnes of tobacco. Six men were arrested.

Ad in Guardian found offensive

A Guardian front page advert, showing filmstar Cameron Diaz with her hand in her knickers, was likely to cause serious offence as an explicit reference to masturbation, the Advertising Standards Authority says today. The paper told the authority the ad was submitted late, so was not checked for suitability.

webTitle: Alarm as cult announces plan to clone humans

fields.headline: Alarm as cult announces plan to clone humans
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: US scientists said yesterday that little could be done to stop a UFO-worshipping cult from pursuing a plan to clone a human being, after the group said it had both the money and the medical knowledge to carry out the act.
fields.body:
US scientists said yesterday that little could be done to stop a UFO-worshipping cult from pursuing a plan to clone a human being, after the group said it had both the money and the medical knowledge to carry out the act.

A former French sports journalist, who calls himself Rael, and his followers claim to be on the verge of cloning an embryo from cells grafted from a 10-month-old girl who died as a result of a medical mistake.

The girl's parents, whom the group have not named, are reportedly paying $500,000 (£357,000) for the procedure. It is not clear whether the Raelians have begun their attempted cloning.

Since the first successful cloning of a mammal, Dolly the sheep in 1997, biologists and ethicists have worried that a private group might attempt human cloning in the absence of clear regulations.

"This is terrible. It really starts to turn the production of human beings into a kind of manufacturing technology," Stuart Newman, a professor of cellular biology at New York Medical College said. "You're creating individuals according to a prototype, but in reality you don't know what you're going to create."

US law only prevents federal funds being used for human cloning. Don Ralbovsky, a spokesman at the national institute of health, a government research body, confirmed that there was no law to prevent a privately-funded venture. In theory, the food and drug administration (FDA) has the authority to regulate any attempt at human cloning, but that authority has yet to be tested in court.

"A cult is very well suited to do these things, because it's well suited to taking the risks involved," Mr Newman said.

In fact, the more fanatical the organisation the more likely it is to succeed. In view of the high failure rate among cloned embryos, any cloning attempt would require a large number of women volunteers to carry embryos in their wombs in the hope that at least one would succeed.

In Montreal last month, Rael appeared with five women, who he said had volunteered to carry cloned human embryos in their wombs. He said his group had 50 willing surrogates.

The group's scientific director, Brigitte Boisselier, a French chemist, claimed to have assembled a team of scientists - a biochemist, a cell fusion expert and a doctor - to carry out the cloning.

The cloning technique which has so far proven most successful with mammals involves using an electrical charge to help fuse living cells with human eggs from which genetic material has been removed, implanting the healthiest resulting embryos in the surrogates' wombs.

webTitle: The best recording session scene: O Brother, Where Art Thou?

fields.headline: The best recording session scene: O Brother, Where Art Thou?
fields.trailText: The early 1930s. A primitive radio station, Tishamingo, Mississippi. Escaped convicts Everett McGill (George Clooney), Pete (John Turturro) and Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson) arrive with hitchhiking guitarist Tommy Johnson (Chris Thomas King) in tow. Inside, Everett strides up to a rotund middle-aged man carrying a white cane.
fields.body:
The early 1930s. A primitive radio station, Tishamingo, Mississippi. Escaped convicts Everett McGill (George Clooney), Pete (John Turturro) and Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson) arrive with hitchhiking guitarist Tommy Johnson (Chris Thomas King) in tow. Inside, Everett strides up to a rotund middle-aged man carrying a white cane.

"Who's the honcho around here?" he asks.

"I am," replies the man. "Who're you?"

"Well, sir, my name is Jordan Rivers, and these here are the Soggy Bottom Boys out of Cottonelia, Mississippi - Songs of Salvation to Salve the Soul. We hear you pay good money to sing into a can."

"Well, that all depends," mutters the man. "You boys do negro songs?"

Everett hesitates before answering.

"Sir, we are negroes. All except our accomp... uh, company... accumpli... uh, the fella that plays the guitar."

"Well, I don't record negro songs," says the radio station man. "I'm lookin' for some ol' timey material. Why, people just can't get enough of it since we started broadcastin' the Pappy O'Daniel Flour Hour. So, thanks for stoppin' by, but..."

"Sir," Everett interjects, "the Soggy Bottom Boys have been steeped in ol' timey material. Heck, we're silly with it, ain't we boys?"

"That's right," says Pete.

"That's right," agrees Delmar. "Except we ain't really negroes."

"Except for our accump-ianist," points out Pete.

The three convicts form a semi-circle around a can microphone, with Tommy on guitar behind them. Everett leans into the mic.

" I-I am a man / Of constant sorrow... "

See also: Boogie Nights, This Is Spinal Tap, Beyond The Valley Of The Dolls

Don't see also: Give My Regards To Broad Street

webTitle: Dior revels in luxurious tat

fields.headline: Dior revels in luxurious tat
fields.trailText: There is a certain point in every show by John Galliano when you are not sure if he is laughing at you or with you.
fields.body:
There is a certain point in every show by John Galliano when you are not sure if he is laughing at you or with you.

His spring/summer 2001 collection for Christian Dior shown in Paris yesterday sat squarely on the fine line between very good and very bad taste. You could almost picture Galliano dancing around backstage, laughing his head off.

With the self-assurance of a madman or a genius - you decide - he unveiled a collection that contradicted itself at every turn: cheap versus expensive; tacky versus dignified; offensive versus innocuous. The references were as numerous as they were disparate: rock-chick white cotton vests were decorated with sequins and ribbons; punk-style zips wound their way around black cocktail dresses; stripes on ribbed waistbands and sleeves smacked of sportswear; camouflage print brought in the military.

It all reflected the street trend for "personalisation", which brings cut and paste to the world of fashion and goes something like this: take a lovely dress, rip off the collar, slash it up the sides and glue on a few souvenir badges.

There were badges, graffiti, ribbons and bows stuck everywhere; frayed faded waistbands from jeans were worn as belts over everything. The outfits were topped off with diamante tiaras and heads full of badly done highlights.

The most staggeringly beautiful silk tulle evening dresses were thus customised and worn with nylon jogging pants; silk taffeta tops dripping with trash were paired with denim cut-offs. Surely no one but those lovely wee things at Dazed and Confused could pull off this look.

But for all this, these garments have plenty of hanger appeal. Together they formed the sort of collection for which the Dior label is renowned: beautiful, luxurious clothes in a class of their own. Strip down the tat and remove the dodgy pants and this collection will look very lovely indeed. On that basis alone you have to take your hat off to Galliano.

webTitle: War grave gardeners face pay cut

fields.headline: War grave gardeners face pay cut
fields.trailText: A war of words broke out yesterday in defence of the men who tend the headstones that King George V once called "the most potent advocates of peace upon earth".
fields.body:
A war of words broke out yesterday in defence of the men who tend the headstones that King George V once called "the most potent advocates of peace upon earth".

Some 77 Britons, employed as gardeners by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission at cemeteries across Europe, protested that proposed changes to their allowances would reduce their income by up to 30% from the end of this month. Chris Kaufman, an official of the Transport and General Workers' union, claimed it was an attempt to push the Britons out to make way for lower paid local staff. The commission replied: "We totally deny that."

The gardeners, who tend nearly 1m graves from two world wars, are paid what the commission says is the UK basic horticultural rate of £11,000-£13,000 a year, but cost of living allowances push this up to about £20,000. "The only reason they can rub along has been the decent level of allowances," said Mr Kaufman, who yesterday visited the cemetery at Arras in France.

The commission conceded that most staff would get less as a result of the new allowances, but said some, including gardeners, would get more. However, Mr Kaufman said: "Our legal advice is that there is a very strong case that the gardeners are being unfairly treated by this draconian change in their contracts."

He further claimed that British staff were essential to understanding the language and culture of those visiting the graves, giving the example of a poignant letter taped to a gravestone read by a gardener and preserved for the cemetery's museum.

The commission said its British gardeners deserved great credit, but any implication that non-British staff lacked skills and dedication was misplaced

A spokesman added: "We are looking to talk to our staff and unions about pay structure. These talks could produce a pay increase."

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The former England football manager Bobby Robson is not yet Sir Bobby Robson, as we styled him yesterday, The job that nobody wants, page 1.
fields.body:
The former England football manager Bobby Robson is not yet Sir Bobby Robson, as we styled him yesterday, The job that nobody wants, page 1.

The chorus in the centenary performance of Elgar's The Dream of Gerontius in Birmingham last week consisted of the City of Birmingham Choir and the City of Birmingham Symphony Chorus, not just the latter as we said in The secret Edward Elgar, Saturday Review, page 5, October 7. Radiohead has released three albums before Kid A, not two as we said in a piece, Radiohead album lays into Blair, page 5, October 9. We neglected to include the band's first album, Pablo Honey.

The Glasgow thoroughfare referred to in a leader, page 21, yesterday, is Sauchiehall, not Sauciehall.

The overnight oncall payment for midwives is £5.95 per night, not per hour, as we said in a piece, Midwife crisis over hours and workload, page 8, October 9. We were also wrong to refer to midwives as nurses in the headline on an accompanying sidebar, Skilled nurses labour for little reward. Some midwives may also have trained as nurses, but midwifery is a separate profession.

webTitle: Homecoming: Autonomy to list on London exchange

fields.headline: Homecoming: Autonomy to list on London exchange
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software firm, yesterday boosted the London Stock Exchange's attempts to position itself as Europe's leading market for hi-tech companies by confirming plans to list its shares in the City.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software firm, yesterday boosted the London Stock Exchange's attempts to position itself as Europe's leading market for hi-tech companies by confirming plans to list its shares in the City.

Listing is expected early next month and will provide an opportunity for long-term investors and chief executive Mike Lynch, above, to sell a small portion of their holdings. Mr Lynch's 19.3% stake is valued at $1.9bn (£1.3bn) and he is expected to dispose of around $100m of shares.

Autonomy is valued at $6.4bn and at that level will go into the FTSE 100 index at the December review. The shares are listed now on Brussels' Easdaq and New York's Nasdaq.

Mr Lynch said the listing was an indication of how far the London market's at titude towards technology companies had evolved over the past two years.

When Autonomy first looked at listing in London it was a tiny, loss-making concern and the authorities were reluctant to entertain the prospect of it using one of its exchanges to raise new funds.

"It's a great shame that when we listed on Easdaq in July 1998 London didn't have its act together," he said. "Since then, and de spite all the recent shenanigans we've read about the exchange, they've really put their house in order and it's a world class exchange.

"We're a UK plc, with our HQ and research and development in this country and we're delighted to be coming home."

About $300m of shares are likely to be sold at the time of listing, with seed investor Apax Partners accounting for most of that.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Say what you will about New Labour, it knows how to learn from its mistakes. A fortnight after a report here about attempts to fix the selection procedure for Ken Livingstone's successor in Brent, tension mounts over the London Labour party's meeting on November 11, Armistice Day. Of 44 motions proposed, 11 call for Ken's reinstatement to Labour and seven more demand a rejection of the public-private partnership for the tube. The word is - and yes, I think you've guessed - that none will make it to the meeting. LLP director David Wilkinson blethers the non-denial denial. "Look, no decision has been taken yet," he tells us. "There is a meeting on Friday to consider the agenda and we'll decide after that." Mmm. Geoff Martin from Unison's London branch states that rejecting these motions would be "the politics of Milosevic, and that's something the Labour London party won't stand for", and for all the cool-headed understatement it's a fair point. Mr Wilkinson and his sycophantic Blairite loyalist sidekick Jim Fitzpatrick, have been warned.

 With the trouble in Israel continuing, a Dubai entrepreneur spots an opening. Noting that missile-throwing has led to a shortage of rocks, Siddiq Fateh Ali Al Khaja is advertising for people to send him stones for transportation to Palestinian territories. Mr Al Khaja plans to send 50 truck loads of stones overland through Saudi Arabia, along with hundreds of traditional Arabic catapults, and insists patriotically that rocks from the UAE's mountains should be thrown at Israeli heads. The stones are being cut to the right shape by stone crushers before making their desert journey.

 Bemusement mounts over that standard cabinet minister response to cannabis enquiries - "we do not take part in surveys". How odd. Anyone refusing to answer a census can be prosecuted, while the government invites us to answer a proliferating number of non-mandatory surveys. "You don't want people to decline, because the maximum response gives the best results," says the national statistics department's David Marder. "A very strong non-response rate would be disappointing because you wouldn't get a proper sample." Indeed. So buck up Milburn, Byers et al.

 Many of us whose ancestors fled pogroms may be tempted to return to the Ukraine for a tourist opportunity. That country's army is throwing open 11 military training grounds and three air bases for fee-paying visitors who wish to play with AK-47 assault rifles, T-72 tanks and Mig-29 fighter jets. "Today's tourists are hard to surprise with anything," says Hryhory Zhorov of the Alaris travel agency, "so we decided to offer something really spicy... military tourism." Enchanting.

 The letter has arrived from West Yorkshire police's central ticket office (camera unit). Headlined "notice of intended prosecution", this wonders whether I or my colleague Richard Adams was driving "motor vehicle No. RR1" at 54 mph in a 40 mph zone in Leeds at 21.21 on August 25. As even a dumb-ass traffic cop should know, asking anyone to incriminate themselves in this manner is a breach of human rights legislation as incorporated into British law this month, so I'm refusing to respond on a point of principle. That's my position, at least, until someone who knows what they're talking about can advise what the chances of getting away with it might be.

 In Canada, a breakthrough is reported in the keenly contested air freshener market. "Bring the clean, natural freshness of a country meadow indoors. Freshen the air in your home with a clean, back-to-nature scent - as refreshing as the summer grass and fragrant flowers of a country meadow," the blurb informs. It sounds great. "Warning," says the message at the can's base. "Inhaling the contents can be harmful, or fatal."

webTitle: Yahoo! result bucks the bubble trend

fields.headline: Yahoo! result bucks the bubble trend
fields.standfirst:
Bottom line concerns grow
Net news
fields.trailText: Yahoo!, the internet sector leader, announced results at the top end of analystsÕ expectations last night but also revealed that it had lost more than 200 online advertisers during the past three months.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, the internet sector leader, announced results at the top end of analystsÕ expectations last night but also revealed that it had lost more than 200 online advertisers during the past three months.

The companyÕs shares were down about 1% in after hours trading following the announcement as traders digested Yahoo!Õs reliance on internet companies for advertising revenues.

Yahoo! earned 13 cents a share in the three months to the end of September, up from six cents a share a year ago and just above the market consensus of 12 cents. It also confirmed the most optimistic revenue forecast with sales of $295.6m in the period.

Tim Koogle, the chairman and chief executive, said last night: ÒOnce again, we exceeded expectations for financial performance by posting record revenues, operating profit and cashflow.Ó

However, analysts last night feared that these marginally better than expected results would not be enough to lift the gloom over the internet sector. They also focused on signs that Yahoo! was being hit by the downturn throughout the internet sector.

In a conference call with analysts after the stock market closed, company executives blamed Òfinancial pressures facing companiesÓ for a decline in the number choosing to advertise on Yahoo! sites.

They also revealed that 40% of Yahoo!Õs revenues come fromnet firms. In an interview with CNBC last night, Holly Becker, internet analyst at Lehman Brothers, said this was Òstill a big numberÓ.

Yahoo! depends on online advertising for about 80% of its revenue. Its dependence on the dot.com sector has increasingly worried investors, prompting a fall of more than 30% in its share price since the beginning of the year.

In a bid to cheer investors, Yahoo! added that the contribution of finiancially questionable companies to its sales had continued to fall below 10% in the period. It said that its top 200 clients contribute 60% of sales, suggesting that they are sizable and can withstand market gyrations.

Several Wall Street analysts have already raised concerns about the impact of low advertising sales on the companyÕs bottom line.

The companyÕs traffic rose to 780m page views per day on average during September, compared to an average of 680m page views in June.

Market nervousness had intensified earlier in the day as two analysts published bearish notes on the semiconductor chip industry, citing slower corporate demand and higher oil prices .

webTitle: Francis Wheen on Slobo's appeasers

fields.headline: Slobo's appeasers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: How our politicians helped keep the Butcher of the Balkans in power...
fields.body:
At a rather rightwing lunch last Friday, I expressed my pleasure at the popular uprising in Serbia which had toppled Slobodan Milosevic. "Popular?" a Tory gent harrumphed, in the way that only old Tory gents can. "I think there's something deeply suspicious about it. Look at those cars and buses driving into Belgrade, led by a bulldozer to deal with police roadblocks. It wouldn't surprise me in the least to learn that the drivers had all been paid by the CIA."

Those who uphold the existing order can never accept that ordinary citizens might be able or willing to challenge it, and so any manifestation of "people power" is always followed by a search for the hidden hand that has been pulling the strings. I was, therefore, unsurprised by my lunch companion's conspiracy theory; what surprises me is that it isn't more widely believed. How can there be genuine rejoicing in the streets of Belgrade? Haven't countless British politicians and pundits, from both left and right, assured us that President Milosevic enjoys near-universal support in his own country?

In May last year, only a few days before the Serb withdrawal from Kosovo, Martin Bell MP told the House of Commons why the Nato intervention had nevertheless failed: "My feeling is that, as far as his domestic political situation is concerned, Milosevic has been strengthened." In the House of Lords, former defence minister Lord Blaker warned that "the determination of the Serb people to support Mr Milosevic would be increased". The political journalist Paul Routledge wrote in the Mirror that "the tyrant Milosevic is still in power, and more popular with his people than ever", while Times readers learned from Simon Jenkins that "Mr Milosevic may be 'degraded' but he is politically impregnable". The Daily Mail agreed: "There is no doubt the country is now united behind Milosevic."

A Panorama programme on The Mind of Milosevic interviewed Dr Jerrold Post, who was director of the CIA's political psychology centre from 1989 to 1998. "I believe," he intoned gravely, "that the Nato strike designed to weaken him will strengthen him and will very much add not only to his support but to his mystique." Tony Benn, Henry Kissinger and a large battalion of historians and retired ambassadors claimed that Nato's onslaught had scuppered any chance of a more democratic regime emerging in Belgrade for many years to come. In the words of Denis Healey, "All observers agree that the bombing has strengthened Milosevic's political position in Yugoslavia."

Not all observers, actually. On this page last April, I quoted what George Orwell had written in 1940: "Whereas socialism, and even capitalism in a more grudging way, have said to people, 'I offer you a good time,' Hitler has said to them, 'I offer you struggle, danger and death,' and as a result a whole nation flings itself at his feet. Perhaps later on they will get sick of it and change their minds, as at the end of the last war." And so they did; though Hitler's hegemony over his people seemed unchallengeable at the time, as soon as he and his gang were defeated the Germans exorcised the demon and democratised their nation. Was it vain to hope, I wondered, that history might repeat itself?

Even during the Nato campaign, Milosevic was never as "politically impregnable" as the pundits claimed. At the end of April 1999, deputy prime minister Vuk Draskovic appeared on state television to denounce the president for dragging the nation into a war it couldn't win. Other opposition leaders started demanding Milosevic's resignation, and by early May there was evidence of widespread public discontent: our own Maggie O'Kane reported on it at length, which may be why she was promptly expelled from Belgrade.

After the ceasefire of June 1999, it became clearer still that the population which had supposedly flung itself at Milosevic's feet was indeed "sick of it". More than 10,000 Serbs took to the streets of Cacak on June 29 to demand the immediate resignation of the dictator. In the southern city of Prokuplje, which had hitherto been regarded as a Milosevic stronghold, only five people turned up on July 8 for the first pro-government demonstration since the end of the Kosovo war - while 4,000 staged a rival rally in the main square, chanting "Slobo like Saddam" and "Slobo out". A month later, 150,000 anti-Milosevic protesters marched through the centre of Belgrade. The president's downfall had become a question of when, not if.

Why, then, did so many allegedly perceptive observers maintain that he was invincibly popular? The answer, I'd guess, is that they took Milosevic at his own estimation. It's an all too common error: throughout the 1990s, he convinced foreign politicians and diplomats that he was the man who could deliver peace in the Balkans, rather than the father of strife. Hence the willingness of successive British foreign secretaries to peddle the fiction that the Bosnian conflict was a "civil war", even though they knew perfectly well that it had been instigated and directed from Belgrade.

By treating the Butcher of the Balkans as a reasonable statesman who must be accommodated, those grandees who proclaimed their even-handedness - Douglas Hurd, Malcolm Rifkind, David Owen, Sir Michael Rose - proved in effect to be accomplices of Serb aggression, since the beneficiaries of this neutrality were Milosevic and his goon squads. Hurd accidentally gave the game away in April 1993, when explaining why the arms embargo against Bosnia shouldn't be lifted. Although "at first sight it seems an act of justice", he said, in practice it would merely create a "level killing field".

The only possible inference to be drawn was that he preferred an uneven killing field, on which Milo-sevic provided the Bosnian Serbs with troops and weapons while the Bosnian government had to make do with whatever equipment it could buy on the black market or grab from captured enemy soldiers. Confirming this interpretation, Hurd said that allowing the Bosnians to defend themselves would "only prolong the fighting".

Hurd's successor, Rifkind, continued the tradition of appeasement by default. After the 1997 general election, incoming Labour ministers discovered that he had deliberately prevented the war crimes tribunal in the Hague from obtaining evidence that could prove Milosevic's complicity in genocide - while insisting in public that "we want to see cooperation with the war crimes tribunal".

Even Labour took some time to abandon the Tories' spurious moral equivalence. As late as January last year, Robin Cook told the House of Commons that although the massacre of Kosovar civilians in Racak was "a war crime", the blame "lies with both sides".

Despite all the atrocities committed by Serb troops and paramilitaries, from Vukovar in 1991 via Srebrenica in 1995 right up to Racak in 1999, international negotiators insisted that Milosevic was "a man we can do business with", in the words of the US envoy Richard Holbrooke. (Did Holbrooke know that Neville Chamberlain had used the same phrase after his first meeting with Adolf Hitler?) Although his promises were continually shown to be as flimsy and worthless as a devalued dinar, still the old mantra was recited: Slobo's the chap with whom we can make deals.

Literally so, in the case of Hurd and his old Foreign Office colleague, Dame Pauline Neville-Jones, who led the British delegation at the Dayton peace talks. Within months of leaving Whitehall, Hurd and Neville-Jones were breakfasting with Slobo in Belgrade to celebrate a business partnership between his regime and their new employer, NatWest Markets.

Where are they now, all these eminent and culpable oafs who so consistently misjudged Milosevic? Shut away in their kitchens, gorging on humble pie? Of course not: this is a breed that knows no shame. Owen could be heard on the World Service last Thursday night, pontificating grandly about the future of Yugoslavia while modestly omitting to mention his own inglorious role in its past. The following morning, Neville-Jones gave Radio 4's Today programme the benefit of her own expertise.

Since she is a governor of the BBC, it was probably wise of the interviewer not to ask the obvious question: how dare these ministers and mandarins, who helped Milosevic to stay in power for so long, and to wreak such ghastly havoc, now presume to lecture us on the inevitability of his demise?

webTitle: Leader: War in Israel is now possible

fields.headline: A fearful future
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian conflict comes home to Israel

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The inhabitants of Israel and the Arab world caught a glimpse this week of the frightening future that awaits should the seven-year-old peace process be allowed to collapse.
fields.body:
The inhabitants of Israel and the Arab world caught a glimpse this week of the frightening future that awaits should the seven-year-old peace process be allowed to collapse. Within Israel, far from the Occupied Territories flashpoints of Netzarim junction and Hebron, pitched battles erupted between Jewish youths and radicalised members of Israel's 1m-strong Arab community. In Tiberias, Tel Aviv and Nazareth property was smashed, cars burnt, mosques attacked and vigilante mobs chanted "Death to the Arabs!" As Arab citizens fought (and died in disproportionate numbers), newspaper headlines warned of civil war.

Prime minister Ehud Barak's appeal to Israeli Jews to remember the experience of the Diaspora and respect minority rights apparently passed unheeded. In Jerusalem, wallposters went up proclaiming "Kahane was right!" - a reference to the late Rabbi Meir Kahane, who advocated expulsion of all Arabs from a Greater Israel. In vain do Israeli peace groups insist upon the necessity of coexistence. Their voices are lost in the clamour of hate raised by racist bigots on both sides of the growing divide. This week, that fenced-off "war" between the Israeli army and Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza has come home with a vengeance. And its now unconfined evil spreads rapidly, fragmenting Israeli society and polarising its peoples.

This fearsome vision of a future without peace may also be seen unfolding in the disputed lands of Palestine. Evidence grows that the Palestinians may be beginning systematically to target Jewish settlements. It seems certain that some of the 200,000 settlers in the Occupied Territories are already organising their own counter-terror. Fatah commanders and their young generation recruits, ignoring Yasser Arafat's half-hearted appeals for calm, demand an all-out popular war.

Critical questions meanwhile arise about the fate of the Palestinian Authority and the lands previously freed from Israeli control should all consensus break down. With the weekend desecration of Joseph's Tomb in Nablus, another boundary is crossed. For this crisis began with the Likud leader Ariel Sharon's supposed defilement of Haram al-Sharif (Temple Mount) and thus the tit-for-tat confrontation becomes one not only of race but of religion, too.

This prospective descent into chaos, should Kofi Annan and the Americans fail to patch up some sort of deal, has destabilising implications for the whole region. Some are already in train. Is it really in Israel's interest, Mr Barak, that Iraq's Saddam Hussein score a triumph of rehabilitation by attending the Arab summit planned in Cairo later this month to discuss the crisis? Perhaps Mr Sharon might care to explain how the enormous, unifying agitation in the Arab world, reaching from the Gulf to Morocco and the demands for oil embargoes strengthen Israel's position?

Then again, maybe Mr Arafat would like to tell undemocratic, pro-western Arab regimes like Egypt how his loss of influence to the rejectionist militants of Hamas and the Iranian-backed Hizbullah helps them in their struggle against a rising, populist Islamic fundamentalism. And while we are at it, perhaps Lebanon's new leaders might clarify whether they, or Syria, or Palestinian exiles, or Shia hostage gangs, or Bugs Bunny are actually in control of their southern borders.

The peace process is deeply imperfect. Any final agreements will be deeply unsatisfactory for almost all concerned. But the alternatives to rational dialogue are far, far worse. Jews and Arabs alike should urgently wake up to that fact.

webTitle: Branson plans to take on BA's surplus jumbo jets

fields.headline: Branson plans to take on BA's surplus jumbo jets
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic airline is preparing to do a deal with its old enemy British Airways by buying its used planes, only one careful owner.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic airline is preparing to do a deal with its old enemy British Airways by buying its used planes, only one careful owner.

Virgin sources last night confirmed that the company was ready to buy four Boeing 747s surplus to BA requirements.

BA believes that the time has come to phase out some of these world famous jumbos and replace them with the smaller, sleeker Boeing 777s. They carry fewer passengers but can be flown more frequently.

Rod Eddington, BA's chief executive, has confirmed the company's intentions in an interview with the airline pilots' magazine, Log.

Asked whether he was going to get rid of any 747s he replied: "I wouldn't discount that at all as a possibility. For a lot of the shorter routes, you don't need a four-engine, high gross weight aircraft that flies 14 hours. It may be that the 777 is a better aircraft on that type of route."

BA sources said that if the Virgin deal went ahead, it would not be the only one. The airline was also looking to sell off more of its 57 jumbos, although there would always be a need for aircraft like them.

BA would make no official comment last night beyond saying that it was always looking at ways of improving its fleet. A Virgin Atlantic spokesman said the company was in the market for 747s. It said two new jumbos were on order from Boeing and would be delivered next year.

The 747 is an attractive aircraft for Sir Richard on his increasing number of long haul flights. Next year he is expected to target Singapore, followed by Australia, routes for which the 747 would be ideal.

The cost of the Virgin deal depends on the age of the aircraft. But Virgin is looking for recently built aircraft, which would be worth around £90m on the market.

BA will soon be announcing its summer routes for next year. Some destinations, particularly European ones, will be phased out. But BA is expected to step up the frequency of planes on some key routes, where it thinks there is a potential for growth.

webTitle: PO bank to cost £130m a year, say high street groups

fields.headline: PO bank to cost £130m a year, say high street groups
fields.trailText: The financial services sector will be expected to foot an annual bill of at least £130m to run the Post Office-based universal bank, according to details which emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The financial services sector will be expected to foot an annual bill of at least £130m to run the Post Office-based universal bank, according to details which emerged yesterday.

It is understood the big four clearing banks - Lloyds TSB, Barclays, NatWest-Royal Bank of Scotland and HSBC - will be expected to cover 40% of the cost between them.

The rest is to be shared between the other players in the financial services industry, including the so-called new entrants such as internet-based banks.

Details of the cost will add to the fury among some of the banks which are likely to feel they have to bare the cost of automating social security payments by creating accounts for up to 4m benefit recipients. With the universal bank, the government aims to provide the "un-banked" with facilities so it can pay benefits into accounts. It is also regarded as a means to throw a lifeline to the Post Office.

The plan for a universal bank has pitched banks against each other amid fears over costs. It has also led to criticism of a duplication of effort by the government in tackling financial exclusion since the banks were already working on offering basic accounts, without overdraft facilities.

While the first written estimates of the costs are understood to be lower than some had feared, it was suggested last night that the banking sector would continue to regard the move as a "recurring tax".

One source said the cost would be incurred "each and every year" that the universal bank existed.

fields.body:
The world's biggest corporate merger - the tie-up between internet company America Online and media group Time Warner - is today expected to be approved by the European commission after months of wrangling.

Mario Monti, the competition comissioner, is expected to say the £87bn deal can go ahead after extracting concessions designed to ensure that the new company's rivals will not be unfairly disadvantaged.

Last week's collapse of the related £14bn tie-up between EMI Music and Warner Music in the face of stiff regulatory opposition from Brussels removed the commission's fears that AOL-Time Warner will be able to monopolise the market for entertainment delivery over the net.

The deal still faces regulatory hurdles in the US. The federal trade commission has said it may scupper the merger unless it is assured that Time Warner will allow rivals to lease some of its cable lines which run into people's homes. That the companies have been willing to compromise with European regulators suggests that they will also be ready to allay Washington's concerns.

To win Mr Monti's blessing, AOL, already the world's largest internet company, has reportedly agreed to sever links with Bertelsmann, the German media groupwhich owns 50% of AOL Europe.

Such a concession would effectively prevent any potential for collusion between Warner Music and Bertlesmann's BMG, one of the world's top five record labels.

A similar restructuring of AOL's French unit, which it runs with Vivendi, is on the cards and AOL has reportedly agreed not to force content providers in the US to sign exclusive carriage deals with AOL Europe.

Time Warner, for its part, has said it will not discriminate against non-AOL internet service providers who want to distribute its music online for a period of five years.

The commission's decision to clear the deal will go some way to defuse American suspicions that European regulators are deliberately seeking to hold up internet-related mergers to give their own companies time to catch up.

Such a charge was levelled at Brussels when it decided to block the telecoms tie-up between MCI/Worldcom and Sprint earlier this year, stating that it feared the merged entity would dominate the internet's backbone. That ruling is now under appeal.

The EC is expected to clear a similar deal on Friday - Vivendi's £20bn takeover of Canada's Seagram which owns Universal Music and pay-TV station Canal-Plus.

This deal raised similar concerns, but Vivendi has now made a series of significant concessions and the acquisition looks likely to be given a green light.

Do not mention the name of Genghis Lloyd-Harris at the Piccadilly offices of SkyePharma, the FTSE 250 drug delivery firm. Ever since the CSFB analyst issued a "sell" recommendation last Friday SkyePharma has been in free fall. Yesterday they eased a further 0.75p to 63p, taking their decline since the publication of the note to around 15p.

Mr Lloyd-Harris issued his "sell" recommendation and 50p down side target in response to the firm's disclosure that its move to profitability has been delayed by six to 12 months. He also expressed concern about the firm's development pipeline.

However, help is said to be hand. According to the market gossips, analysts at a major investment bank - rumoured to Dresdner Kleinwort Benson - have been working on a research note in which they will argue that SkyePharma shares are a "buy", and set a target price of close to 100p.

webTitle: Steel gloom

fields.headline: Steel gloom
fields.standfirst: Corus cuts more jobs
fields.trailText: Corus, the loss-making Anglo-Dutch steel group, is to axe a further 200 jobs at its Port Talbot plant in south Wales and other UK strip plants and mothball a blast furnace at Llanwern producing 1m tonnes of steel a year, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Corus, the loss-making Anglo-Dutch steel group, is to axe a further 200 jobs at its Port Talbot plant in south Wales and other UK strip plants and mothball a blast furnace at Llanwern producing 1m tonnes of steel a year, industry sources said last night.

The company, in an announcement due today, is expected to blame the downturn in the motor industry and the continued weakness of the euro for its decision. The decision raises questions about the medium-term future of its British operations.

The job cuts will also cast a shadow over Corus's Welsh plants where 1,300 jobs losses, including 400 at Port Talbot (pictured above), were announced in the summer on top of 2,500 elsewhere in Britain. The latest redundancies will take the Port Talbot workforce, which is losing 100 jobs, below 3,000 from 3,500 and hit Shotton, north Wales, and Teesside.

The group, which lost £249m after tax in the first nine months of its formation from the merger of British Steel and Hoogovens, lightened the gloom recently by giving the go-ahead for a £35m relining of a blast furnace at Port Talbot's sister plant, Llanwern, which produces 2m tonnes of steel annually. However, the smaller furnace at Llanwern is to be shut because of problems with oversupply and low prices of carbon steel, the Welsh plants' output, and of the impact of the strong pound.

Union sources said there were now fears that the Llanwern furnace and a strip line to be mothballed at Port Talbot would never reopen and could be the prelude to a wider series of plant closures in the UK, especially in Wales, as Corus struggles to regain profitability.

Corus is understood to be losing hundreds of millions of pounds from its UK carbon steel business.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Prudential expands in Asia
fields.body:
Prudential expands in Asia

Britain's biggest life insurance firm, Prudential, has expanded its presence in Asia by buying a Taiwanese mutual fund for £71m.

Prudential said it had bought 88% of Core Pacific Securities Investment Trust Enterprise, Taiwan's 9th largest unit trust provider with £1.2bn of funds under management.

The move follows Prudential's purchase last year of 74% of Taiwan's Chinfon Life for £21.4m, and gives it fund management capability in addition to the life business.

Prudential's shares rose slightly on the news.

London top business city

London has been voted Europe's best business city by executives for the 11th year running and has scooped the title of internet capital of Europe in the European Cities Monitor 2000 survey.

Despite London business chiefs being divided over monetary union, the city maintains its lead as the future financial capital of Europe. Nearly 40% of Europe's leading executives at 504 European companies rated it the best place to do internet-related business in the survey carried out by international property consultancy Healey & Baker. Frankfurt came second with only 7% and Paris scored 5%.

Lex to stop selling cars

Lex Service, once one of the country's largest franchised car dealers, yesterday announced that it was to quit the retail market altogether.

The group is pulling out of the secondhand car market to concentrate on the RAC motoring services business it bought for £437m in July last year.

Chief executive Andy Harrison said Lex would close or sell its remaining seven used car showrooms by the end of the year. It has already sold its 49 new car outlets to Pendragon group - the first 17 for £44m in 1997 and the remaining 32 for £93m in March.

Sky Global float on track

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp said yesterday the planned multibillion-dollar float of its digital television arm, Sky Global Networks, was still on track for the fourth quarter of 2000.

Despite competition from a number of US and European telecoms offerings and the prospect of bedding down a complex deal with cable TV mogul John Malone, News Corp said the Sky Global offering would not be delayed.

"News Corp always said the float would be by the end of 2000 and that has not changed. Everything remains on schedule," a spokesman said.

Telecom talks up Snook's role

France Telecom said the arrival of Jean-Francois Pontal, one of its executive vice-presidents, on the management of mobile telecom group Orange does not imply the departure of or a reduced role for Orange's chairman, Hans Snook.

"Jean-Francois Pontal will be part of the Orange management alongside Hans Snook," an official said. "Is Hans Snook leaving? The answer is no. Hans Snook is not leaving and he does not have a reduced role."

webTitle: At this price?  St Ives

fields.headline: At this price?  St Ives
fields.trailText: St Ives, the printing group which puts together books including the Harry Potter series and magazines including the Economist, proved yesterday that there is life in the old print world yet.
fields.body:
St Ives, the printing group which puts together books including the Harry Potter series and magazines including the Economist, proved yesterday that there is life in the old print world yet.

Online magazines, marketing and e-books might chew up the headlines but St Ives yesterday managed to report what it termed its best ever year.

Pre-tax profits for the 12 months to August were 14.5% higher at £68.8m and revenues 4.6% better than the previous year.

The markets were understandably spooked by problems in its US business where pre-tax profits halved because of pressure on prices. Growth in the short term, the company warned, is unlikely to be at current levels - though part of the fall was due to investment which will curtail more expensive contracting out. The shares fell 3p to 423.5p.

The improvement last year was largely driven by the healthy level of corporate activity in financial markets - each takeover or issue of new shares needs the publication of extensive documentation.

An increasing amount of the business is also coming from printing junk mail, one of the fastest growing marketing disciplines.

Both of those important areas also face potential difficulties. Uncertainty in the financial markets could unsettle the former while a widely predicted slowdown in the advertising market could hit the junk mail and coupon printing arm.

Both worries though would seem easily rebuttable. The financial markets have gone through a period of volatility for much of this year which has not stemmed the flow of business, while markets historically turn to the cheaper, more targeted below-the-line disciplines in times of hardship.

They also appear to have already been factored into the St Ives share price, which has been batting back and forth between 400p and 500p for much of the year against a peak of 635p. Hold.
