webTitle: Today's TV

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: A Star Is Born/A Summer's Tale/Halloween H20/Orphans
fields.body:
A Star Is Born

(George Cukor, 1954)

11.15am, 5.15pm, Sky Cinema

Lavish musical remake of the tearful 1937 drama about a rising singer's fraught marriage to a free-falling drunken movie star. James Mason seized the latter role after Cary Grant said no, and he's impressive, but it's tragic Judy Garland's show: a heartbreaking performance, even if the songs aren't so hot.

A Summer's Tale

(Eric Rohmer, 1996)

6pm, FilmFour

One of Rohmer's Tales of the Four Seasons, a typically deli cate chamber piece that seems quite frivolous, until you find yourself on the edge of your seat wondering how it will be resolved. This midsummer's comedy has Melvil Poupard as Gaspard, a student holidaying in Brittany, awaiting the arrival of his girlfriend (Aurelia Nolin). There he strikes up a strictly platonic relationship with another student (Amanda Langlet) and a more physical one with her friend (Gwenaëlle Simon). So there's the choice: will he plump for the affair romantic, intellectual, or sexual? A very funny, perceptive little masterpiece.

Halloween H20

(Steve Miner, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

Twenty years on from John Carpenter's original Halloween, Jamie Lee Curtis's Laurie, survivor of the encounter with teeny slasher Michael Myers, is now a twitchy, alcoholic single mum with a teenager (Josh Hartnett) of her own. It's only a matter of time before Myers returns to his dirty work, and Miner has fun giving us sev eral false starts before Laurie realises he's not a figment of her imagination but real.

Orphans

(Peter Mullan, 1997)

12.30am, FilmFour

Mullan's directorial debut is a blend of social drama and gallows humour. It has the Flynn siblings - Michael (Douglas Henshall) Thomas (Gary Lewis) Sheila (Rosemarie Stevenson) and John (Stephen McCole) - gathering in a Glasgow pub the evening before their mother's funeral. There is a stabbing and the four go their separate ways, each dealing with feelings of grief and anger.

webTitle: Letters:  Commonwealth war graves

fields.headline: Let's not wither them
fields.trailText: Anyone who has visited the Commonwealth war graves of northern France cannot fail to have been impressed by the immaculate care and attention with which they are maintained.
fields.body:
 Anyone who has visited the Commonwealth war graves of northern France cannot fail to have been impressed by the immaculate care and attention with which they are maintained. These are among the most moving, least triumphal of all war memorials. The fact they remain so well tended is a tribute to the dedication of their gardeners. Any attempt to reduce their pay and conditions looks mean and ungrateful (War grave gardeners fight pay cuts, Guardian Unlimited, October 10).

Michael Palin
London

 Maybe the FA should invite Debbie Bampton to become England manager (£1m for 16 weeks a year - the job that nobody wants, October 10). She has taken her club to the top of women's football in this country and played over 90 international matches, including seven years as captain. Her understanding of the game is comprehensive.

Oliver Thornton
Crowborough,
E Sussex

 Thanks, Sal at the BBC, for your words of reassurance to us Seinfeld addicts (King of New York, G2, October 10)). So what's the excuse for next week's complete non-appearance? Reruns of Phil Silvers more pressing?

David Ward
Chichester,
W Sussex

 I can't speak for its clarinet-key cleaning propensities (Letters, October 10), but when I lived in Eritrea, the Guardian Weekly served several purposes. Read copies could be passed on to local people, which helped to make friendships. It also served for draining fried food and was perfectly well suited to, ahem, roll-up making.

Tom Locke
Burntisland,
Fife

 If Michael Portillo is on the "socially liberal" wing of the Conservative party (Report, October 9), who's on the other one? Darth Vader?

Glyn Evans
Newbury,
Berks

webTitle: Connex to lose suburban services franchise

fields.headline: Connex to lose suburban services franchise
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Connex, one of the worst peforming rail companies, was yesterday given the broadest hint by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority that it will not have its franchise to run London suburban services renewed for a further 20 years.
fields.body:
Connex, one of the worst peforming rail companies, was yesterday given the broadest hint by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority that it will not have its franchise to run London suburban services renewed for a further 20 years.

The SSRA is to announce a decision on who will operate the south central franchise before the end of the month.

In preparation, it issued a Stock Exchange statement warning Go-Ahead, Connex's main rival for the franchise, to make sure that a potential take over bid for the company did not interfere with the SSRA's plans.

Mike Grant, the SSRA's chief executive, said that Go-Ahead was the subject of a takeover bid from the French financial consortium, C3D, and Rhone Capital. He has made it clear to Go-Ahead that he will need to approve any change of control in the ownership of the two franchises in which Go-Ahead has an interest.

Industry sources suggested last night that the SSRA would not have issued the statement if it was going to renew the Connex franchise. It has been under political pressure to ensure that the French owned company is not awarded the franchise. Its performance has been poorly rated by the SSRA and it would face a damaging backlash from commuters.

Connex, which operates the adjoining south east franchise and has aspirations to run others in Britain, has indicated that it is ready to step down gracefully.

webTitle: Arts: Two responses to John Freeman's article

fields.headline: Bite back
fields.standfirst: Last week John Freeman said mainstream theatre was 'irrelevant' and 'backside-numbing'. Here are two responses
fields.trailText: Last week John Freeman said mainstream theatre was 'irrelevant' and 'backside-numbing'. Here are two responses...
fields.body:
British theatre is a cosy conspiracy between producers, critics and theatregoers alike to keep the medium safe, middle-brow and tedious. The majority of plays performed in any given week are at least 20 years old and in most cases over 100 years old. Is it any wonder, then, that the average age of the theatregoer continues to rise, that young people are staying away and that on any given evening the foyers of most British theatres resemble the assembly point for a Saga holiday? We have to break this conspiracy and the only way to do this is to make a really radical move.

Ban the classics from state-funded theatre for at least five years and dare the audiences to look forward, rather than back. There is an appetite for the new, it's just that young audiences don't believe the theatre is where they will find it. All over Europe the work of radical new British playwrights dominates the theatrical landscape, yet how many of these plays have been seen outside London? How many productions of Blasted have been seen in the regions of Britain? Sure, the average pensioner may not immediately embrace Shopping and Fucking, but tough: we've had to sit through their productions of Sleuth for long enough. The theatre needs to become necessary again. And in the first instance it can only do this by embracing wholeheartedly the new. If it doesn't, then John Freeman's sensationalist article may unfortunately prove prophetic. Chop down the Cherry Orchard and barbeque The Seagull. Embargo the classics in subsidised theatre. Anyone got the nerve?
Mike Bradwell and Tim Fountain
Bush theatre, London

 John Freeman's attack on "mainstream theatre" has the demagogic stridency of Zhdanov, Stalin's lethal arts commissar, and the barricade rhetoric of every modernist art manifesto, a century too late. To ape the venom of Antonin Artaud's onslaught on clapped-out theatre, you also need Artaud's painful genius. To lay about injustice, you need the punch of Emile Zola. And you need to have a case to make.

Freeman's well-worn reflexes paraded as dynamic thinking show none of these signs. His ignorant sneers and slurs come thick and fast. "Theatre dialogue bears no relation to contemporary language". Ask Joe Penhall, whose Blue/Orange was a riveting confrontation between the argot of a spaced-out black kid and the uptight speech of two quarrelling white doctors. "There can be nobody in Britain who wants - really wants - to sit through another play by Wesker"? Well, lots of people did at Bristol Old Vic, when Wesker's Denial was premiered earlier this year.

Does Freeman have the same scorn for the older generation of performance artists? This cultural sans-culotte would rush them all to guillotines erected in the wreckage of disaffected theatres. There's little to be gained from Freeman's Savonarola-like denunciation. It may come out of a genuine indignation, but its crude and tub-thumping formulations betray a mind that has scant regard for language, still one of the essential constituents of true theatre.
Michael Kustow
Author of theatre@risk
fields.bodyText: British theatre is a cosy conspiracy between producers, critics and theatregoers alike to keep the medium safe, middle-brow and tedious. The majority of plays performed in any given week are at least 20 years old and in most cases over 100 years old. Is it any wonder, then, that the average age of the theatregoer continues to rise, that young people are staying away and that on any given evening the foyers of most British theatres resemble the assembly point for a Saga holiday? We have to break this conspiracy and the only way to do this is to make a really radical move. Ban the classics from state-funded theatre for at least five years and dare the audiences to look forward, rather than back. There is an appetite for the new, it's just that young audiences don't believe the theatre is where they will find it. All over Europe the work of radical new British playwrights dominates the theatrical landscape, yet how many of these plays have been seen outside London? How many productions of Blasted have been seen in the regions of Britain? Sure, the average pensioner may not immediately embrace Shopping and Fucking, but tough: we've had to sit through their productions of Sleuth for long enough. The theatre needs to become necessary again. And in the first instance it can only do this by embracing wholeheartedly the new. If it doesn't, then John Freeman's sensationalist article may unfortunately prove prophetic. Chop down the Cherry Orchard and barbeque The Seagull. Embargo the classics in subsidised theatre. Anyone got the nerve? Mike Bradwell and Tim Fountain Bush theatre, London  John Freeman's attack on "mainstream theatre" has the demagogic stridency of Zhdanov, Stalin's lethal arts commissar, and the barricade rhetoric of every modernist art manifesto, a century too late. To ape the venom of Antonin Artaud's onslaught on clapped-out theatre, you also need Artaud's painful genius. To lay about injustice, you need the punch of Emile Zola. And you need to have a case to make. Freeman's well-worn reflexes paraded as dynamic thinking show none of these signs. His ignorant sneers and slurs come thick and fast. "Theatre dialogue bears no relation to contemporary language". Ask Joe Penhall, whose Blue/Orange was a riveting confrontation between the argot of a spaced-out black kid and the uptight speech of two quarrelling white doctors. "There can be nobody in Britain who wants - really wants - to sit through another play by Wesker"? Well, lots of people did at Bristol Old Vic, when Wesker's Denial was premiered earlier this year. Does Freeman have the same scorn for the older generation of performance artists? This cultural sans-culotte would rush them all to guillotines erected in the wreckage of disaffected theatres. There's little to be gained from Freeman's Savonarola-like denunciation. It may come out of a genuine indignation, but its crude and tub-thumping formulations betray a mind that has scant regard for language, still one of the essential constituents of true theatre. Michael Kustow Author of theatre@risk

webTitle: Passnotes: Roger Moore

fields.headline: No: 1738
fields.standfirst: Roger Moore
fields.trailText: Roger Moore
fields.body:
Age: A caddish 72.

Best known for: Owning the most expressive eyebrow in the western hemisphere; starring roles in The Saint (1962-69), The Persuaders (1971-72), and seven James Bond films (1972-85).

And now he's ...? Broken the holy bond of matrimony.

Bet that raised a few eyebrows. Nope. Not really. Roger has been divorced twice before - from the skater Doorn Van Steyn and from the singer Dorothy Squires. And of course these things always come in threes.

Surely it should've been third time lucky? It did look that way. Luisa Mattioli and Roger met in 1961, on the set of the Rape of The Sabine Woman. They have three children - Geoffrey, Deborah and Christian.

But he wasn't for her eyes only? Alas no. They separated six years ago, after Moore was spotted frolicking with Swedish-born socialite Christina "Kiki" Tholstrup (60) - whom Luisa has, some may say bitterly, called "a hanger-on who has had two husbands and three face lifts".

So she's taken it rather badly? Yes, but I'm sure this week's news of a £10m divorce settlement will cushion the blow. And of course it will undoubtedly boost the sales of her new book about their life together. Sadly, recent events have forced her to alter the title from Living With a Saint to the considerably more cynical Nothing Lasts Forever.

But Luisa was determined to keep that Gold on her Finger? Ahem. Yes, she was pretty determined. After Moore broke the news to her over the phone (allegedly with the words, "I am not in love with Kiki, but I am very fond of her. I am sorry"), Luisa took her revenge by refusing to divorce him ... until now.

How did he manage to persuade 'er? I'm not even going to dignify that one with an answer. Anyway, needless to say he is now free to marry Kiki.

Will it be a secret service? Who knows, but Mr Moore has a view to a wedding before Christmas.

Do say: "Saintly behaviour."

Don't say: "A good Rogering."

webTitle: Christopher Hope on South Africa's censors

fields.headline: Just like old times
fields.standfirst: After seeing one of his satirical poems banned by the apartheid regime,  Christopher Hope  looked forward to its revival under the ANC 25 years later. Instead it was banned again - for the same reasons. Here the celebrated South African novelist argues that the new regime is rapidly becoming as thin-skinned as the old one
fields.trailText: After seeing one of his satirical poems banned by the apartheid regime,  Christopher Hope  looked forward to its revival under the ANC 25 years later. Instead it was banned again - for the same reasons. Here the celebrated South African novelist argues that the new regime is rapidly becoming as thin-skinned as the old one.
fields.body:
In the old South Africa, censorship was not just a necessity, it was an industry. Poems were suspect, pictures dangerous. The liberal press was said to be unjust, unfair and unpatriotic and deserved to be closed down. The censors were busy people. They banned everything from lapel badges to T-shirts.

I had my first brush with the censors in 1972, when a satirical ditty of mine called Kobus Le Grange Marais was banned by the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC). It contained "words and phrases likely to cause offence" (in this case to Afrikaners), and it was said to be "racist". The SABC of the time was so slavishly supportive of the ruling party it was known as the government's glove-puppet.

The regime was brutal, but strangely sensitive. If its people called you a liberal subversive in the pay of effete capitalist western powers - and this was a common charge - it was regarded as fair comment. But if you suggested that South Africa was run by a bunch of racist desperadoes whose barbarism was exceeded only by their stupidity, that was unfair, un-South African, and swiftly suppressed.

A few years later, in 1976, my novel, A Separate Development, was banned for "holding up sections of the population to scorn and derision" (this time it was the police). Our censors were grimly amusing in their obsessions. A title was enough to cause trouble. Martin Buber's theological treatise, Between Man and Man, was banned because rumour said it might be a gay treatise. Of course, people laughed and so it became an offence to mock the censors' decisions. In effect they tried to ban laughter.

All that was supposed to end with the new democratic government of 1994. It didn't. A couple of years after the new South Africa was born, Kobus Le Grange Marais was dusted off after 25 years of silence, set to music and sent off to be broadcast. The new "transformed" SABC promptly banned it again, for reasons not far removed from those given the last time around. It contained words and phrases likely to cause offence - this time to blacks. In a word, it was "racist".

How did it feel, someone asked, to have my work banned in the old and the new South Africa? Quite nostalgic, actually.

It goes on - this urge to shut people up. Anyone visiting South Africa and looking at the papers or the TV will catch, before long, a whiff of paranoia in the air. The search is on for enemies of the people, the unpatriotic, the dissident, the disloyal. The fortunes of the country are once again being equated with those of the ruling party. The line between party and state was washed away under the old apartheid regime and has not been redrawn. Increasingly the search is on for dissenters. The charges are the same - unpatriotic, unfair, un-South African.

Only the methods have changed. In the old days, when people like BJ Vorster led the apartheid government, and someone at a political meeting asked a question the prime minister did not like, he would send in the security police the next morning.

In the new South Africa, they send in the committees. Earlier this year I watched a committee sniffing out something called "subliminal" racism in the press. Difficult thing to defend yourself against - the subliminal. You may have it even if you don't know it. "Racism" is a word used to brand your political enemies - as ubiquitous and as empty a label as "communism" once was. It even comes colour-coded. "Racist" may be coupled with or swapped for the word "white", rather as "communist" and "red" used to be.

Here and there the alarm is being raised. In his recent Steve Biko memorial lecture, the writer Njabulo Ndebele quietly and profoundly doubted the wisdom of this new name-calling. By constantly erecting this bogeyman of white racism, black South Africans were embracing again their old dependency, by ascribing to their former masters a power which they no longer possessed. There still existed an alarming "heart of whiteness", that whites themselves needed to confront and explore. But secret cabals of white racists bent on destroying the new democracy did not exist.

Ndebele is chancellor of the University of Cape Town and one of the most original thinkers South Africa has produced. But what he said was heresy. The SABC refused to carry Ndebele's address and said by way of explanation that "it was not in the national interest" - a phrase so full of the perfume of the past that nostalgia again overwhelms me.

Under the old regime at least you knew who the enemy was. Nowadays, you may be silenced by erstwhile allies. Or be expected to censor yourself. This is hotly denied, of course. You are free to say or write what you like in the new South Africa, say the authorities and their lackeys. But it's tosh. The ANC is the Party is the Government is the Country - that is the way it goes. And in its intolerance of criticism and debate the government and its minions do indeed pay unexpected homage to those they have replaced.

This is not to say that racism is not alive and well and living comfortably in white South Africa. It would be amazing if this weren't so. For most of the last century entire rugby fields were packed with large chaps in shorts who not only believed in apartheid; if they had any regrets it was that there wasn't more of it. But these days a kind of general amnesia has set in, and it is almost impossible to meet anyone who believed in apartheid.

Black South Africans who suffered the long lunacy find it infuriating. Of course they do. The same bums in the same pound seats. The odd thing is that it isn't the big chaps in shorts, beer-in-place-of-brains- brigade who are under fire. What is under attack is dissidence and independence. In a word, "liberals" are loathed every bit as much as they were under apartheid.

The trouble with loathing is that once you get a taste for it you can't stop. You start finding enemies on your left and your right. In the woodwork, under the beds. And you have to gag them, too. It was with a pang of recognition that I read the protest of Oupa Moatshe, a trade-union organiser, who told the Sowetan newspaper that the SABC was not a public service - it was, he said sadly, (how the music comes back!) the "state broadcaster".

Of course it is. The only thing that has changed on state-run television and radio under this new government is that this time round the puppet doesn't bother wearing a glove.

Anyone who spends time in South Africa will be surprised by the intensity of the racial debate, and the heat of the political invective. The ANC government, elected with an overwhelming majority, shows itself to be as thin-skinned as the old Afrikaner establishment. Their languages mirror each other. Particularly, the language of threat.

In the old days if you declined to accept that the white regime was fair, upright and democratic, you were a detestable liberal revolutionary and urged to go and live in Ghana. Today, those who doubt that the ANC government is divinely inspired are detestable liberal counter-revolutionaries, who should immediately start packing for Perth.

There is also a deeply unhealthy respect for authority. One hears it in the way people talk about the administration. It proposes and disposes, it does not take the definite article, it is, quite simply "Government" - like "God". In reality, "Government" is simply that bit of the ruling party susceptible to manual stimulation - a kind of political G-spot. To watch ostensibly independent public servants, broadcasters , frightened liberals and pliant functionaries stroking the party's G-spot is to see a form of political pandering so perverse it should be viewed only by consenting bureaucrats.

In South Africa now the need to manipulate information for "patriotic", that is to say, for political ends, is growing. The crime rate frightens many people, but crime may be a coded reference to race, so you stop releasing the figures. Murders get a lot of bad press, so you don't publish the numbers. Rape is widespread. Well then, let us declare it unpatriotic to talk about it. Road fatalities are shockingly high - let us no longer give them out.

This being South Africa, such innovations are followed by a chorus of approval from party supporters. That is another old tradition, known as "thanking the minister". It has little to do with gratitude. It is a veiled warning to those who do not feel the required degree of appreciation.

Nowhere is this better illustrated than in the current debate over Aids. President Thabo Mbeki questions whether Aids is a disease when it is "a syndrome". Confusion reigns. Aids may or may not be not a virus; it may or may not be spread by sexual contact. Party supporters are expected to believe several impossible things before breakfast. For example, that drugs for treating Aids are a conspiracy by US drug companies to increase profits. When the trades unions come out squarely and say that Aids is caused by HIV, the president suggests big American drug companies have infiltrated the unions. The party stalwarts toe the presidential line, thank him for his leadership, and shout down those who disagree. The minister of health refuses to answer questions on the causes of Aids. Only the virus is happy, to paraphrase WH Auden, and impervious to argument, strikes down more South Africans than ever.

South Africa seems a country run on edicts, pronouncements, threats, hot air and the increasing need to find someone to blame. There has never been a tradition of free speech in South Africa. Words are weapons, their meanings found in the government gazette, not in the dictionary. The wrong form of words can seriously damage your health.

Take a word like "tolerance". Tricky stuff, tolerance. Mzwandile Khumalo is the project officer for transformation and employment equity on the campus of the University of the Witwatersrand. This is my old college, where for decades under apartheid a celebrated anti-authoritarian spirit characterised staff and students. Not any more. The new citizens of the new South Africa should be on guard against what Khumalo, writing in the Sowetan, calls "the crass and deceitful politics of tolerance".

And who masterminds these detestable values? Abdul Malik, writing in a newspaper called the Citizen and credited as an editor at GQ in the UK, has them in his sights. Black South Africans , he warns, are victims of a white plot designed to keep them poor. And who is to blame? Step forward the usual suspects. "Jews are wealthy all over the world because their money circulates 10 times in their communities before it gets out."

So does the money of Indians, Malik adds for good measure. I don't know what is oddest about this notion of an Indo-Jewish scheme for the mystical multiplication of money. That it comes from someone who spends his life touting zoot suits? Or that this choice piece of rant appeared in the Citizen, a newspaper founded on stolen money by the old apartheid government because it believed the "liberal" press was disloyal, seditious and stuffed with - oh, dear me - liberal agitators full of the deceitful politics of tolerance? Or that Malik's comments are not very unusual in South Africa, and passed without comment or contest?

What I do know is that what goes round comes round. You bet it does.

Not long ago I drew an affectionate portrait of my home town, Johannesburg, for a magazine called Traveller, published by Condé Nast. I said that Jo'burg was the greatest city in Africa south of Cairo. The city of beautiful walls and big dogs. Not even its friends would call it an easy town. I said you learned more about Jo'burg from the graffiti on the beautiful walls than you do from the papers. "One Settler, One Bullet" was a slogan you saw around town in the old South Africa. But I liked the new variant - "One Settler, One Prozac". On balance, I felt things must be looking up.

A gentle and affectionate portrait, I say again, an accurate portrait. But not affectionate enough for the new censors. After reading my piece, the South African tourist authorities have said they plan to withdraw all their advertising from Condé Nast publications - unpatriotic? Not in the national interest? Too contaminated by the deceitful politics of tolerance?" Subliminal racism? All of these and more? Who can say?

But punitive measures - oh yes. And how that takes me back. It's so like old times I get quite homesick.

webTitle: Memo to the board

fields.headline: Memo to the board
fields.standfirst: If English football were a company it would probably be closed by now. As the FA scrambles to find yet another coach, Merope Mills asks the management experts for some free advice
fields.trailText: Sir John Harvey Jones, corporate troubleshooter
fields.body:
Sir John Harvey Jones, corporate troubleshooter

It's the whole ethos of football that makes working for the FA so repelling. They hire and fire people like mad and the manager always ends up being the scapegoat while the chairman gets away scot-free. I do believe the manager should be seen as a leader, but in this instance they're put in a job where they never get a decent chance to prove themselves. Who would want to follow that career? What would I advise them? I think trying to attract a Frenchman to run the English national side is not the way to go. They've got to look inside the UK. And they've got to give the applicant a reasonable period - a minimum of two years. And if he's a flop after 18 months or so, well, we should sack the chairman instead.

Bill Quirk, managing director, Synopsis

I would have to ask whether, as an association, they have a unified direction and management team, or are they coming up with compromises all the time? They need a common direction, a clear purpose and they need to work together as a team, because only a unified team behind the scenes will produce a successful team on the pitch. Also, in a normal company the chief executive should be given a certain level of autonomy from the board to do what he thinks is best. That is something that should be happening in football, too. The manager should be given a clear mandate from the board and should not be trying to manage upwards as well as downwards, in an effort to compensate for the failings of the people above him.

Kevin Hague, director, OC&C strategy consultants

The entire system needs to be looked at because the way the FA and the FA committee operates does not work. There is a lack of accountability at the top, which is no way to run a business. None of the people are put there by the people that matter: the fans. The FA should treat the fans like shareholders or customers and should consult them on all major decisions. Instead of that it's old, time-served farts that have been around for ever. It's your classic old-fogey organisational set-up. The other thing is, they don't seem to be thinking about the future. There's a lack of policy and leadership in youth football with no sign of creative thinking. They also need to set up a formal manager training scheme like the ones they have in Italy and Holland. At the moment the FA is a company that is managing the status quo in a classic old-boys'-club way. They need to take a proactive role, grasp the game by the scruff of the neck, take ownership, and address the issues from the bottom up.

Victor Kiam, business guru

You have to treat all sports like you treat a company. You have to make sure the money is there and support the organisation and the people you have in place. That's probably not a problem for your national side - it must be a deeper problem than that because it doesn't seem that long ago that England were major players in the soccer world. One of the worst mistakes in business is trying to get a quick fix for a situation. I tell every one of my clients that that doesn't happen unless you get real lucky. There's no point in getting everybody's hopes up and making out everything is going to be fine once they make some cosmetic change. It's got to be a real change to get the company or the organisation back to the pre-eminent position it once was in.

What we're looking at here is a job with massive pressures of accountability which are very unattractive. Unusually, though, the pressures don't come from the upper echelons of the company but rather from the public, who are expecting high results from a very poor product. No manager can come and turn this around like we expect them to. It's a long-term project that would require the FA first of all to change the very core of the product by investing more in school sport and football and, second of all, to change public expectations by letting them know it's going to take a very long time to match expectations with results.

Frank Dick, former British athletics coach and motivational expert

The difficulty with England football is that if you stood back and asked, "What is the ultimate goal of English soccer?" most people would say, "To win the World Cup." The problem is that most Premiership managers wouldn't agree with that. So the key problem is that the structure doesn't support - or, worse still, goes against - the main goal that most of the customers seek. If we are a nation committed to England becoming successful on a world stage, the club-comes-first culture needs to be addressed. So the total structure needs to be reviewed - not just the manager's job. The other thing that needs to be addressed is that it is not possible to sign all the qualities you need in one manager any more. You need to select one person as a leader, yes, but you need people in the background who will compensate for that person's shortcomings as a team leader, because we all have them.

Judith Mills, Judith Mills Management Consultants

As with so many senior managerial positions it is possible to feel very isolated as team manager. I suggest a mentor that is detached from football who can listen to the coach's issues and guide him through the minefield caused by the various stakeholders: the players, the FA, the supporters, the press, the government and the nation. It's a high-pressure job and it's a lot to ask one person to take all that responsibility.

Colin Smith, Colin Smith Consultancy

There are several issues, really. First of all, at the top level there are too many levels of managers. There are chairmen, chief executives, executives - there's too much hierarchy. Secondly, there needs to be a clear split between the technical side and the managerial side of the team. The manager should be respected but there needs to be a competent team behind the manager. Thirdly, the FA need to enforce a long-term strategy for the future. There needs to be clear investment from the juniors to the under-21s all the way through to the senior players if the team is to have any kind of success in future years.

Andrew Campbell, director, Ashridge School of Business

If a job is unattractive, you have to look at why that might be. Is it because the pay is too low? Is it because there is too much interference from higher up? Is it because you can't get your hands on decent staff - or in this instance, players - or that there aren't enough of them? My guess is that in this case there are other jobs available in the industry that are a lot more attractive. All these things need to be addressed and dealt with to get the standard of applicant you are looking for. My advice would be to widen the net for potential applicants and look to the bigger job market including non-UK citizens. A lot of English companies are run by foreigners these days, and football really is no different.

webTitle: Jordanians unite in anger and grief behind new intifada

fields.headline: Jordanians unite in anger and grief behind new intifada
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: On Amman's streets, the troubles in Palestine are on everyone's mind, provoking not only anger and riots but grief.
fields.body:
On Amman's streets, the troubles in Palestine are on everyone's mind, provoking not only anger and riots but grief.

There have been demonstrations on a scale that Jordan has not witnessed for many years, if at all. According to security sources quoted by the Jordan Times, there were 300 marches and protest meetings in the last week. Sixty-two policemen and "tens of civilians" were injured; 52 vehicles - 28 of them police cars - were damaged.

It is scarcely surprising that the protests seen throughout the Arab world have been particularly strong in Jordan, where more than half the population is of Palestinian origin. A western diplomat in Amman said all sections of the com munity - not just Palestinians - had joined the protests.

Arab newspapers now call the uprising in Israel and the occupied territories "the Aqsa intifada". This serves as a reminder that the troubles were sparked by the visit of the Israeli opposition leader, Ariel Sharon, to the contested religious site in Jerusalem which includes the al-Aqsa mosque. Islamic groups, naturally, are also keen to emphasise the religious aspects of the conflict.

But what seems to have touched the masses far more was the televised killing of 12-year-old Mohammed al-Direh. In Jordan, the rear windscreens of cars display pictures of the boy.

It is many years since the Arab world, from the poor states of north Africa to the rich ones of the Gulf, has been so united in its public expressions of emotion.

In Jordan, the authorities have responded by sympathising with the protesters' while urging calm, and suggesting that the money needed to repair the riot damage could have been spent on helping Palestinian victims.

They have also tried to redirect the popular outpouring towards more practical goals. A few days ago, King Abdullah donated blood in front of the television cameras, and Jordanian hospitals are treating many Palestinian casualties.

Among others who need help are some 500 passengers on the Palestinian airline who were stranded in Jordan when the Israelis closed Gaza airport. Many of them are without money and there is no sign of Gaza airport reopening.

In Jordan and elsewhere, the anger is coupled with frustration. Many feel the time has come to confront Israel - without a clear idea of how. The only specific demand by the Jordanian protesters so far is the closure of the Israeli embassy. If so, one of the long-term casualties could be Jordanian efforts, heavily backed by the US, to normalise relations with Israel.

Shortly before the troubles started, the Jordanian prime minister lectured the country's trade unions and professional organisations on the need to keep out of politics - meaning that they should not try to block economic cooperation projects with their Jewish neighbour.

That is a message he will probably not dare to repeat for a long time.

webTitle: Britain in dock over airports golden share

fields.headline: Britain in dock over airports golden share
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The European commission is today expected to take Britain to court for failing to relinquish its controversial "golden share" in BAA, the airports operator privatised in 1987.
fields.body:
The European commission is today expected to take Britain to court for failing to relinquish its controversial "golden share" in BAA, the airports operator privatised in 1987.

The move will anger the government since it has already indicated that it is willing to surrender the £1 special rights preference share it retains in around a dozen formerly state-owned companies.

Its failure to specify a timeframe for when it might shed these symbolic shares has forced the EC's hand, however, and Brussels now believes legal action will oblige the government to fulfill its promise in the case of BAA.

The EC thinks the shares - which allow the government to protect companies from hostile takeovers and to veto key decisions in the name of the national interest - fly in the face of EU rules on the free movement of capital.

The government's stake in BAA - which runs London's three main airports - prevents anyone from holding more than 15% of the company's equity.

The idea is to ensure that Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted airports cannot be sold off without specific government approval.

But if the European court of justice finds in the EC's favour the government could be fined, and would be forced to scrap its "golden share" in the airports authority, paving the way for a potential takeover.

It has been argued that its stake in BAA does not impede the free movement of capital, since many non-British investors own stocks in the company, which is listed on the London Stock Exchange.

However, in July, senior government sources admitted there was no real reason for the government to hang on to its golden shares. But nothing has happened since then.

The EC has taken a hard line on "golden shares" in other European countries, and has already sued Belgium, France, Spain and Portugal over the issue. It is also considering legal action against Denmark, the Netherlands and Germany.

The other companies in which the British government still holds a "golden share" include Cable & Wireless, P&O Stena Line, BAE, Rolls-Royce, National Grid, National Power, PowerGen and several other power generators.

webTitle: Incepta buys its way to double profit buoyant market

fields.headline: Incepta buys its way to double profit buoyant market
fields.trailText: Incepta, the marketing services group which owns financial public relations business Citigate Dewe Rogerson, yesterday announced a doubling in profits after a string of acquisitions in the first half of the year.
fields.body:
Incepta, the marketing services group which owns financial public relations business Citigate Dewe Rogerson, yesterday announced a doubling in profits after a string of acquisitions in the first half of the year.

It reported a 103% increase in pre-tax profits to £14.2m for the six months to September while revenues were 48% higher at £113.4m.

Chief executive David Wright said he saw no reason for the 15% rate of organic growth to slow despite the widely held belief that corporate activity, particularly flotations, might ease next year. Financial PR accounts for more than half group profits.

"I don't think we will see the same peaks and troughs in the market that happened years ago," he said. "The markets are awash with cash. We have become a nation of indirect savers, and that money has to find a home somewhere."

Incepta shares, which peaked at 184p in March, yesterday succumbed to profit taking after being tipped in the weekend press. The stock fell 7% by 10.5p, to 136p.

Group chairman Bob Morton announced yesterday he was to stand down by the end of the financial year after eight years.

webTitle: Value of OM's exchange bid falls by £100m

fields.headline: Value of OM's exchange bid falls by £100m
fields.standfirst: Swedish predator's share value tumbles
fields.trailText: OM of Sweden came under further pressure to increase its bid for the London Stock Exchange yesterday as a further fall in its shares reduced the value of its bid for the exchange by more than £100m.
fields.body:
OM of Sweden came under further pressure to increase its bid for the London Stock Exchange yesterday as a further fall in its shares reduced the value of its bid for the exchange by more than £100m.

The fall in the Swedish group's shares came after the release of its profits figures for the first nine months of the year which were lower than many analysts had been forecast.

Because the hostile bid by OM comprises largely of its own shares, the fall in its shares had the effect of cutting the value of its bid for the LSE to below £700m, compared with £808m on the day it made its surprise bid last month.

This is less than the £840m at which the LSE's own shareholders value their business.

OM has hinted that it is prepared to raise its offer but yesterday refused to say when or by how much the bid could be increased. Some industry sources are sceptical that the Swedish company will be able to raise its bid by much because of its offer is so dependent on its own share price being strong.

An OM spokesman insisted yesterday that its share price fall was not connected to its profits figures but was part of the wider malaise hitting demand of hi-tech stocks listed on New York's Nasdaq market.

"Our shares have been tracking Nasdaq. We are seeing a bear market in hi-tech stocks," the spokesman said.

One of the lines of defence mounted by the London Stock Exchange is that its shareholders should consider the risks involved in swapping their shares for one in a hi-tech company.

The LSE's shares, which are not traded on the stock exchange but via the broking firm Cazenove, closed yesterday at £28.20, lower than the levels above £30 to which they jumped when OM made its offer but still higher than the current OM bid of £25 per LSE share.

The audacious bid by OM, which has forced the exchange to call off its planned merger with its German rival, has prompted reports in the Swedish media of allegations against Olof Stenhammar, the founder of OM, about irregularies in the campaign he led for Sweden to host the Olympic games in 2004.

A spokeswoman for OM last night said that Mr Stenhammar "denies any wrongdoing".

Per Larsson, the chief executive of OM, which owns the Swedish stock exchange, said the group was reporting "another set of record results with increased income, profits and earnings per share".

Its profits for the nine months were 154m Swedish kronor (£10m), below the market's expectations, hurt in part by its investment in Jiway, an online broking service in which it owns a 60% stake. Jiway, of which investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter owns 40%, is due to go live later next month and break even two years later.

Shareholders in the LSE will vote next week on whether to lift the 4.9% single ownership limit on their shares which appears to prevent a takeover.

OM said: "We will continue talking to the owners of the LSE. It is a process of talking to them and then being able to acquire their shares."

So far, just 1% of the LSE's shareholders have supported the OM bid. But, the takeover battle is only half way through and speculation continues to swirl that other exchange may yet put in rival bids for the LSE.

webTitle: Judge rules out Hyder contract

fields.headline: Judge rules out Hyder contract
fields.trailText: Severn Trent could gain the lucrative contract to run Hyder's Welsh water services after the high court ruled yesterday that an exclusive deal between Hyder's new US owners and United Utilities breached British and EU regulations.
fields.body:
Severn Trent could gain the lucrative contract to run Hyder's Welsh water services after the high court ruled yesterday that an exclusive deal between Hyder's new US owners and United Utilities breached British and EU regulations.

Western Power Distribution, which bought Hyder this summer, had planned to outsource the daily management and operation of Welsh Water to Warrington-based UU while retaining the business's assets.

Yesterday Mr Justice Langley ruled in principle that the outsourcing, seen by British water companies as the key to earnings growth, should be awarded after an open tender.

Brian Duckworth, Severn Trent's managing director, said the group had cleared a significant hurdle and had asked the judge to expedite a second hearing into which services are covered by the regulations.

A WPD spokesman, which won a bidding war with Japanese bank Nomura to take over Hyder, said the outsourcing might be delayed but the ruling was "no big calamity". The ruling is a blow to UU which, like other British water groups, has suffered a loss of confidence among shareholders because of tight regulatory controls.

Separately UU denied reports that it faced an imminent court case over the role played by its Vertex customer service and billing business in the recent collapse of Independent Energy, the elecrtricity and gas supplier.

Independent went into receivership when debts, caused by billing problems, reached more than £150m. Vertex said it had not been responsible for cash collection.

webTitle: No minor feat

fields.headline: No minor feat
fields.standfirst:
The Morris that keeps going... and going
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: In the 42 years since Bert Taberner bought his Morris Minor he has clocked up 500,000 miles - further than a return trip to the moon - and the car engine has only been replaced once.
fields.body:
In the 42 years since Bert Taberner bought his Morris Minor he has clocked up 500,000 miles - further than a return trip to the moon - and the car engine has only been replaced once.

Mr Taberner, a retired building inspector from Greasby, on the Wirral, bought the car second-hand for £480 in 1958. It had been built in 1955 at Cowley in Oxfordshire.

After 250,000 miles, he replaced the 803cc engine with a 948cc version. It gave the car, often nicknamed the Moggy Minor, a new lease of life.

Mr Taberner, who wrote a book about the maintenance of Morris Minors called Moggy Matters - which sold 1.6m copies between 1948 and 1971 - is now the president of the Merseyside branch of a Morris Minor owners' club.

"It's been a great little car, simple made and dependable," he said. "There's no reason why she shouldn't keep going for a long time yet."

An RAC spokesman said: "It's fantastic, incredible. Bert ought to be congratulated. It shows the service you can get from a vehicle if you look after it."

webTitle: Obituary: Sirima Bandaranaike

fields.headline: Sirima Bandaranaike
fields.standfirst: The world's first woman prime minister, she brought reforms - and bureaucracy - to Sri Lanka, but alienated the island's Tamil minority
fields.trailText: The world's first woman prime minister, she brought reforms - and bureaucracy - to Sri Lanka, but alienated the island's Tamil minority.
fields.body:
"What does she know of politics?" scornfully asked a cousin of the assassinated prime minister of Ceylon, Solomon "Solla" Bandaranaike, when his widow Sirima announced that she was taking over his party's leadership in 1960.

"In Solla's time, Sirima presided over nothing fiercer than the kitchen fire," continued Paul Pieris Deriyanagala, who had been best man at the Bandaranaikes' wedding. "She'll end by spoiling her personal reputation and ruining the family name."

Few forecasts have proved so mistaken. Thanks to Sirima Bandaranaike, who has died of a heart attack aged 84, even more than to her husband, the name of Bandaranaike became a legend. She not only became the world's first woman prime minister, but went on to head her country's government three times. She altered the face of Ceylon, in many ways controversially, made it a republic, and changed its name to Sri Lanka.

More than that, Mrs Bandaranaike became one of the third world's best-known leaders, rubbing shoulders with Indira Gandhi, Chou en-Lai, Marshal Tito and others in the heyday of the non-aligned movement. A cauldron far, indeed, from the kitchen fire, and, at home at least, much fiercer.

Yasmine Gooneratne, another cousin within the vast Bandaranaike clan, who recounted "Uncle Paulie's" scathing comments in her family memoirs, Relative Merits, describes "Aunt Sirima" as "the most formidable and charismatic leader the country has ever seen". And in the words of Maureen Seneviratne, her biographer: "If Mr Bandaranaike's stature as a politician and leader was built up over decades of campaigning, Sirimavo (the suffix "vo" denotes respect) donned hers like a cloak that had been lying in her wardrobe for years, unworn, but which had been pressed and kept ready for wearing at any given moment."

Sirima Bandaranaike was born Sirima Ratwatte, the daughter of a prominent Sinhalese family in the Kandyan hill country of Ceylon - a perfect match for the wealthy, low-country family of her future husband, with his driving political ambition. Like many similar families, the Bandaranaikes were thoroughly anglicised, and held prominent positions in the British colonial regime then in charge of the country.

Although many leading Kandyan families also served the government and adopted English first names, most remained staunchly Buddhist, and preserved Sinhalese traditions. Sirima's was just such a clan. Her father, Barnes Ratwatte (named, like her husband-to-be, after a British governor-general), was seen as an excellent match for her mother, herself the daughter of one of the best-known Kandyan chieftain families.

Wanting the best education - which had to be English - for Sirima, the eldest of six children, her parents sent her, at the age of eight, to a convent boarding school in the capital, Colombo. But they ensured that she remained a devout Buddhist, speaking Sinhala as fluently as English. After leaving school, she threw herself into social welfare work, walking miles through jungles and over mountains to distribute food and medicines, organise clinics and develop village industries. She became a great favourite of the Sinhalese peasantry, acquiring a reputation that was to prove invaluable to both her husband and herself.

Her marriage, in 1940, to Solomon West Ridgeway Dias Bandaranaike, then a brilliant, young, Oxford- educated colonial government minister, was dubbed "the wedding of the century". Both were from the top goyigama caste of landowners, and their horoscopes were found to match perfectly. And if he did not know the rural Sinhalese as she did, Bandaranaike instinctively sensed their needs and aspirations.

Unfortunately, neither knew anything about the country's Tamil minority, its language and culture or needs and aspirations. It was an omission that often led the couple to ignore the Tamils, or make fatal blunders in dealing with them.

At first, Sirima's public role was that of a dutiful wife. Her eldest child, Sunethra, was born in 1943, followed by Chandrika, and finally a boy, Anura. But in 1948, as the island of Ceylon edged towards independence, the shy, methodical wife and mother found her home invaded at all hours by her mercurial husband's friends, forever discussing politics and demanding refreshment.

Throughout their married life, according to James Manor's biography of Bandaranaike, The Expedient Utopian, her main difficulty was her husband's male chauvinism. Manor cites a possibly apocryphal, but indicative, story about a delay in tea being served at a political gathering in their Colombo house, to the host's irritation. When it appeared at last, and his wife retired to the kitchen, he shouted: "Sirima! These gentlemen drink tea with sugar. For the sugar to get into the cup, there must be some instrument. You have not put a spoon in the sugar bowl."

Manor's account continues: "The dutiful wife went to fetch a spoon, and Mr Bandaranaike quipped: 'We have to think for them too.'" She made no complaint. No wonder the men failed to foresee what a forceful leader she would be - "perhaps too forceful", Manor adds drily.

Nonetheless, Sirima soon became Bandaranaike's valued confidante. It was she who persuaded him to resign from the government and the ruling United National Party (UNP) in 1951. She had long been aware of his exasperation at the social and political immobility since independence. Two months later, he formed the Sri Lankan Freedom Party (SLFP), with democratic socialism and Sinhalese resurgence at its heart, setting the party political battle lines in the country for the rest of the century.

General elections the following year brought Sirima her first baptism of political fire, as she campaigned on her husband's behalf in his constituency, while he carried his new party's message to the rest of what was still Ceylon. Her reward was the biggest majority for him of any candidate, though the SLFP won only nine seats.

At the next elections, in 1956, Bandaranaike won by a landslide and formed a leftwing coalition. The key factor in his victory was the "Sinhala only" policy - the promise to replace English with Sinhala as the island's sole official language, and a watershed policy in Ceylonese history. It was aimed at the dominance of the English-speaking elite, but, in fact, sowed the seeds of bitter conflicts with the Tamils. Bandaranaike used Sinhalese chauvinism to gain power, but found he could not control it. And though the influential Buddhist monk who planned his murder in 1959 was motivated primarily by personal grievances, this chauvinism played a part in it.

For Mrs Bandaranaike, her husband's death was a traumatic tragedy. One morning, she was in the garden of their house, always open to visitors, when she heard a commotion inside. She rushed indoors to find him collapsing, gravely wounded, with a Buddhist monk pointing a gun at him. She courageously flung herself at the gunman, who was then felled by police fire, but Bandaranaike died in hospital the next day.

Sirima was given little time to grieve in peace. The following year, she succumbed to the SLFP's desperate pleas to assume the party leadership, and led it to victory on a wave of public sympathy. The world's first woman prime minister took office in triumph.

In the next four years, she forged ahead with the socialist reform programme her husband had initiated - and, indeed, went further. The island was thrust full-tilt into the emerging non-aligned movement; foreign oil companies were nationalised, and all government business was transferred to the state-owned Bank of Ceylon and the new People's Bank, bringing an end to American aid; Soviet aid was sought for industrialisation projects; and education was reformed in favour of the Buddhist Sinhalese.

But Mrs Bandaranaike paid a high price. At the end of 1964, under pressure from right-wing Buddhist leaders, some SLFP MPs crossed the floor, and the government collapsed. Sirima lost the next year's elections, but was herself elected to parliament for the first time.

Five years on came sweet revenge. In 1970, the United Left Front, led by the SLFP, won a two-thirds majority in parliament, and the socialist bandwagon set off again at full speed - although not fast enough for the militant and disaffected youths of the extreme leftwing People's Liberation Front, the JVP.

Having benefited from Mrs Bandaranaike's educational reforms, they found there were still no jobs for them, so, in 1971, they launched an insurrection. It was swiftly crushed, though at the cost of an estimated 1,000 young lives. More than 10,000 were jailed, although most were later released.

Deeply shaken, the government pressed on hurriedly with land reform, nationalisation of the tea estates and a new republican constitution, which changed Ceylon's name to Sri Lanka and made Buddhism the state religion - to the dismay of the mainly Hindu Tamils.

Mrs Bandaranaike also imposed rigid state control over the economy, which had the now familiar consequences. Under the impact of soaring oil prices, living standards collapsed in a welter of rationing, bureaucracy and corruption. As a result, her SLFP was routed in the 1977 elections, winning a derisory eight seats. The UNP, led by Julius Jayawardene, secured a 75% majority, which he used ruthlessly to tighten the authoritarian regime his predecessor had imposed in her second term. Jayawardene revised the 1972 constitution and had himself elected executive president, setting up an oppressive state with the mere trappings of democracy. In 1980, he vindictively had Sirima's civic rights suspended for seven years for abuse of power - a crime of which he himself soon became much more guilty.

With Mrs Bandaranaike unable to play any public role, the SLFP was riven by discord. In the difficult years ahead, her main task was to hold the party together and, with very few cards to play, to counter Jayawardene's devious but masterly manoeuvres.

Succession to the party leadership became a bone of contention between her son Anura, who was moving to the right, and her daughter Chandrika, who eventually broke away and, with her popular film-star husband Vijaya Kumaranatunga, formed their own leftwing party - one of whose main aims was to seek a rapprochement with the Tamils. But with her civic rights restored in 1985, Mrs Bandaranaike recovered her place as unchallenged leader and the SLFP's fortunes rose again.

After Kumaranatunga's assassination in 1988, Chandrika eventually rejoined the SLFP and, proving herself a consummate politician, secured the party leadership in 1994 at the expense of Anura, who had angrily crossed over to the UNP. But, said Mrs Bandaranaike consolingly: "He's my son and I love him."

These were years of mounting violence in Sri Lanka, more often than not initiated by the government or the ruling UNP. After a nationwide pogrom against Tamils in 1983, they took to armed resistance with such effect that, in 1987, India sent in troops to impose a peace settlement. It failed, but Mrs Bandaranaike, once India's greatest ally on the island, hotly opposed the intervention, in the name of the Sinhalese nationalism she had long since embraced.

Without influence either in Delhi or among the Tamils, she was powerless to sway events. Nor could she prevent rising violence in the south. In 1989, the JVP, by now more chauvinist than Marxist, was crushed by the UNP government - with vastly greater brutality than in 1971. Estimates of the number slaughtered vary from 30,000 to 70,000; no prisoners were taken and no trials held - a sharp contrast with Mrs Bandaranaike's treatment of the JVP.

Her last bid for power came in the presidential elections of 1988, and the parliamentary polls of the following year. With the cards stacked so heavily against her by Jayawardene and his successor, Ranasinghe Premadasa, she could hardly win, though despite all the violence and electoral manipulation he used, Premadasa secured only 50.1% of the votes. However, the UNP lost its two-thirds majority in parliament, its chief weapon in manipulating the constitution. What finally broke the government was Premadasa's assassination in 1993.

Reluctant though she was to hand over the reins, age was telling on Mrs Bandaranaike. Impressed by Chandrika's brilliant campaigning, she stepped down just before the parliamentary elections in August 1994. It may have been part of the deal that when Chandrika also won the presidential elections three months later, she appointed her mother prime minister - a symbolic act intended to extirpate Jayawardene's injustice over her civic rights.

Real power, however, remained in her daughter's hands. Sirima retired as prime minister last August to allow her daughter to appoint a hardliner, in an attempt to boost the government's fight against Tamil separatists ahead of this week's elections.

With a more cosmopolitan outlook than her mother, and influenced by her late husband's ideals, Chandrika made a genuine effort to come to terms with the Tamils. But her father's miscalculations, her mother's ignorance and neglect of the Tamils, and what can only be described as Jayawardene's cynical viciousness towards them, created a legacy of Sinhalese intransigence and Tamil fanaticism that may have made the task impossible.

The Bandaranaikes - husband and widow - unquestionably broke the stifling colonial ethos of the English-speaking elite, and restored dignity and a rightful place to the Sinhalese majority. But it was done largely by exploiting their chauvinism, and at the expense of the Tamils, not least because Mrs Bandaranaike, like most Sinhalese, had little concept of her island as a multi-ethnic whole. If a country may be judged by how it treats its minorities, the failure to treat them properly in Sri Lanka has carried a fearsome price, which even yet has not been fully paid.

Bandaranaike is survived by her three children.

 Sirima Ratwatte Dias Bandaranaike, politician, born April 17 1916; died October 10 2000.

webTitle: Flood alerts issued for 17 rivers

fields.headline: Flood alerts issued for 17 rivers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: A large band of wet weather expected to bring up to an inch of rain was heading towards the Channel yesterday, prompting warnings to homeowners to brace themselves for a second night of flooding.
fields.body:
A large band of wet weather expected to bring up to an inch of rain was heading towards the Channel yesterday, prompting warnings to homeowners to brace themselves for a second night of flooding.

The environment agency issued flood warnings covering 17 rivers in the south-west, the south-east, the Midlands and Yorkshire.

Flood watches, which warn of possible flooding, are in place across Wales and in most counties south of Yorkshire.

Jo Warburton, a spokeswoman for the environment agency, said: "With the ground saturated and many rivers and streams already full, flooding could occur almost anywhere."

On Monday night 80 homes in Ryde on the Isle of Wight were flooded. Firefighters worked through the night to pump water out before the rain returned.

Other areas badly hit were Bognor Regis, West Sussex, were homes were evacuated, and Midhurst, where roads were swamped.

webTitle: Minister gets out of his depth with garden pond

fields.headline: Minister gets out of his depth with garden pond
fields.trailText: There is, they are fond of saying here, no problem so abstruse that it cannot be solved by rational consideration and the marvels of French administration. But what with his ducks, his herons, his foxes and his fishes, the foreign minister has learned otherwise.
fields.body:
There is, they are fond of saying here, no problem so abstruse that it cannot be solved by rational consideration and the marvels of French administration. But what with his ducks, his herons, his foxes and his fishes, the foreign minister has learned otherwise.

The telling tale of Hubert Védrine's pond began last year, when the doyen of French diplomats decided it would be a nice idea to refill the dried-out lake at the bottom of the landscaped gardens adjoining his official residence, La Celle-St-Cloud, outside Paris.

Several months later, the lake was restored to its former glory. First problem: the crystal-clear waters were invaded by a particularly potent algae.

webTitle: Sex appeal of Scottish redheads

fields.headline: Sex appeal of Scottish redheads
fields.trailText: Playground banter, media portrayal, cutting jokes and even popular perception would not seem to offer much empirical evidence to back up the theory.
fields.body:
Playground banter, media portrayal, cutting jokes and even popular perception would not seem to offer much empirical evidence to back up the theory. But the reason redheads number so highly among the Scottish population may stem from their sexual allure, according to a skin specialist.

In a theory which may rely more on the public perception of redheads such as Geri Halliwell rather than Chris Evans, Edinburgh university professor Jonathan Rees said the large number of redheads north of the border may be due to sexual selection.

Prof Rees, in his inaugural lecture at the institution's medical school, said that ginger hair was the result of a single gene carried by up to 40% of the Scottish population. He made the suggestion about redheads as part of research examining the link between skin colour and sensitivity to the sun.

He said: "Our work suggests that the first human redheads walked this earth 50,000 years ago and then spread throughout Europe.

"Why are there so many redheads in Scotland? We cannot be certain that chance did not play a role, but we also suggest that the very obvious selection people make for their sexual partners based on physical characteristics may be relevant."

But there is a downside for redheads, since the gene which causes red hair also causes greater sun sensitivity.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: ANC condemns attack on youth
fields.body:
ANC condemns attack on youth

A group of white men attacked a black teenager they accused of breaking into homes, beat him and then forced him to eat his own faeces, South African police said yesterday.

The 17-year-old was hitchhiking near Potgietersrus on Saturday when the group abducted him. The ANC condemned the attack as barbaric and racist.
AP, Johannesburg

Police question Mugabe foe

Police have questioned then released the leader of the Zimbabwean opposition, Morgan Tsvangirai, over a speech he made in which he allegedly threatened Robert Mugabe.

The government may be hesitating to lay charges because a case against three opposition MPs for inciting violence collapsed in a Harare court yesterday.
Andrew Meldrum, Harare

MP's £18,000 phone card bill

An Australian government minister has admitted giving his son access to a government-funded telephone service which racked up a bill of more than £18,000.

Peter Reith said police were investigating the misuse of his card since 1994, but that his son had made only £350 of calls.
AP, Canberra

Pakistani ruler's election pledge

General Pervez Musharraf said yesterday that his government had halted Pakistan's economic decline in the year since he ousted the country's civilian rulers and that he would restore democracy by 2002.
Reuters, Lahore

webTitle: Soldiers' plight shocks Colombia

fields.headline: Soldiers' plight shocks Colombia
fields.standfirst: Film of servicemen languishing in rebel 'concentration camps' increases calls for prisoner swap
fields.trailText: Grainy shots of Colombian soldiers and policemen behind barbed wire in rebel "concentration camps" have increased pressure on President Andres Pastrana to allow a prisoner exchange with guerrillas.
fields.body:
Grainy shots of Colombian soldiers and policemen behind barbed wire in rebel "concentration camps" have increased pressure on President Andres Pastrana to allow a prisoner exchange with guerrillas.

The film, which has been broadcast on television news programmes, shows five compounds deep in rebel-held jungle, where guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) are holding some 450 servicemen.

The pictures were obtained when rebel leaders allowed two women to visit their imprisoned relatives. In one scene, soldiers ignore heavy rain as they crowd against a barbed-wire fence to greet the visitors. Other images show the men praying, reading the Bible and eating inside rough wooden huts.

Monsignor Pedro Rubiano, the archbishop of Bogota, described the muddy compounds as "worse than a Nazi concentration camp", but an opposition senator, Juan Manuel Ospina, who represented the government in peace talks with the rebels last year, said the film underlined the need for a prisoner exchange. "We have to make some decisions. The government can't continue ignoring this situation," he said.

Over the last two years, Farc has captured 468 servicemen in combat. It hopes to swap them for imprisoned guerrillas, but the government has refused to free around 500 rebels convicted of crimes ranging from rebellion to kidnapping and murder.

The camps are believed to be somewhere within a huge rebel safe haven abandoned by government forces in 1998 as a precondition for peace talks aimed at ending nearly 40 years of fighting.

Government and guerrilla negotiators have been involved in the talks since January 1999, but the two sides have been unable to agree on terms for a ceasefire.

One of the visitors, Marlene Orjuela, told the Bogota daily newspaper El Tiempo that the captives were tied together with nylon nooses around their necks, to stop them escaping if the army arrived.

Ms Orjuela, whose cousin is among the captives, spent 12 days escorted by Farc guerrillas as she hiked through dense jungle to visit the camps and record video messages from each of the 129 servicemen she talked to.

"They weren't expecting our visit. They thought it was a dream," she said.

Her journey came after two years of meetings with Farc leaders. "I'm very demanding, but above all, I'm discreet and respectful. This is not about attacking people, but looking for solutions," she said.

Last year, Mr Pastrana rejected legislation which would have allowed judges to free condemned rebels, arguing that the captured servicemen were kidnap victims, not prisoners of war. Human rights observers warn that an unconditional release of rebel prisoners could open the doors to a blanket amnesty for human rights violators.

But legal arguments hold little sway with the prisoners' families, who think the president has ignored their plight.

"We begged and implored for an audience or some help, but he never wanted to see us," said Esperanza Lopez, a waitress whose son Gesid was taken captive in August 1998.

Ms Lopez saw the new film last week at a meeting with other relatives. "It was like a wake. We were all crying like we never had, the men were all shouting. It was terrible to see the boys in a cage, as if they were wild animals," she said.

webTitle: England stutter to finish a distant second

fields.headline: England stutter to finish a distant second
fields.standfirst:
Beaten Hussain calls for control, discipline and hard work from the bowlers
England 182
South Africa 184-2
S Africa won by eight wickets
Wisden Verdict

Match scorecard
fields.trailText: England's first objective of the winter, to win the ICC Knockout Trophy, ended in emphatic failure here yesterday. They were overwhelmed by eight wickets in the quarter-final of a tournament billed as a mini World Cup, and South Africa were not flattered by the margin of victory. They beat England as easily as England themselves had beaten Bangladesh last Thursday.
fields.body:
England's first objective of the winter, to win the ICC Knockout Trophy, ended in emphatic failure here yesterday. They were overwhelmed by eight wickets in the quarter-final of a tournament billed as a mini World Cup, and South Africa were not flattered by the margin of victory. They beat England as easily as England themselves had beaten Bangladesh last Thursday.

From the eighth over, when the England openers Marcus Trescothick and Alec Stewart had totalled only five runs, only one result looked likely. England batted thoughtlessly and bowled without penetration.

"We were outplayed from the first ball to the last ball of the match, which went for six," said the captain Nasser Hussain. "We'll always be beaten by sides such as South Africa if we don't do the basics right.

"We came up against a team on top of their form; they bowled, fielded and batted exceptionally well and we weren't up to it. We didn't even come second.

"Boys from South Africa and Asia were brought up on pitches like this. They know you need control and discipline because the ball doesn't seam or swing as much as in England. We must get used to the conditions and learn to work bloody hard for everything."

Certainly there must be significant improvements if England are to compete with Pakistan in the one-day series there this month. Not to mention the Test matches in Pakistan and, early next year, Sri Lanka.

Five of England's top six were caught in the deep and to make matters worse Craig White and Andrew Caddick were run out. But in truth England never escaped the suffocating stranglehold imposed by the opening bowlers. Shaun Pollock and Roger Telemachus were naggingly accurate and Trescothick and Stewart simply could not get the ball away.

Trescothick later managed a few meaty blows before chipping Pollock's slower ball to mid-on, and Hussain was soon caught behind. Then Stewart, who had scored 459 in his previous five one-day international innings for twice out, lofted Donald to deep square-leg. When Graham Thorpe did something similar against the left-arm spin of Nicky Boje, England were 88 for four in the 27th over and in considerable distress.

Graeme Hick, who had looked in fine form in his brief innings against Bangladesh and also in the nets, effected a recovery with Andrew Flintoff. They had put on 66 in fewer than 11 overs when Flintoff, in the first over of Pollock's second spell, produced a virtual carbon copy of Stewart's dismissal. He had needed to stay for at least another seven overs so his departure was as grievous as it was unnecessary.

White perished to a direct hit by the brilliant Jonty Rhodes. Then Hick, whose 65 came from only 68 balls, pulled to deep square-leg. England were seven down and their mission now was to bat out the full 50 overs.

They failed by some distance. Paul Grayson, only five days after being called into the party, was caught at slip from what was his first ball in international cricket. Caddick was beaten by Boje's shy at the stumps and Mark Ealham fished and gave Pollock his third victim. England's final six wickets had fallen for 28 runs from 46 deliveries, and their total never looked enough.

Hick then held a fine catch above his head at slip and an even better one low to his left in the gully, but South Africa always seemed certain to qualify for the semi-final against India on Friday.

Hussain posted four close catchers at times, but it was a fruitless policy. Boeta Dippenaar finished it with a straight six off White and his partnership of 132 with Jacques Kallis took South Africa to victory with 10.5 overs in hand.

 Zimbabwe's Alistair Campbell has been found guilty of dissent when adjudged leg-before by Steve Bucknor in his side's quarter-final defeat by New Zealand and has been suspended for the first game of their next one-day international series. The Kiwis face Pakistan in today's semi-final.

webTitle: Unease among local authority bosses over elected mayors

fields.headline: Unease among local authority bosses over elected mayors
fields.trailText: They are not quite ready to press the panic button. But if the looming departure of the chief executive of England's second city is anything to go by, there is growing unease among the most senior local authority bosses over their role under a system of elected mayors and new town hall management structures.
fields.body:
They are not quite ready to press the panic button. But if the looming departure of the chief executive of England's second city is anything to go by, there is growing unease among the most senior local authority bosses over their role under a system of elected mayors and new town hall management structures.

Sir Michael Lyons, Birmingham's chief executive since 1994, is citing political modernisation for his reason to give a year's notice to quit his £150,000-a-year post. The city council is to hold a referendum in a year's time to test the concept of an elected mayor. If the vote goes in favour, the city could have a US-style elected executive by 2002.

Suggestions within the Society of Local Authority Chief Executives (Solace), which this week holds its annual conference in Liverpool, are that "a good 20" of its number are considering their positions in light of the new Local Government Act, which paves the way for the changes. David Clark, the City of York's chief executive who is shortly to become Solace's first director general, says: "In a lot of places people are very nervous and we've got a heck of a lot of thinking to do about the skills that are [now] needed."

Clark, widely respected for having made York one of the country's more successful councils after it gained unitary status six years ago, argues that changes have been thrown into the local government system "quite recklessly". What he means is that insufficient thought has been given to how a chief executive is expected to work alongside a mayor who will want to grab many of the executive functions. "Potentially, it could unpick quite a lot of the good developments that have happened in the last two or three years," he says.

A recent poll of chief executives in the Local Government Chronicle found that 45% of the 240 English and Welsh council chiefs who responded believe the new structures represent a threat to their policy role. Just 14% thought elected mayors, and cabinets, would enhance their position.

"One of the big issues is that the skills that people had are deemed now to be the ones not required," says Clark. "But no one can really define exactly what it is that is needed."

Clark believes that the problem is highlighted by the difficulty in finding a chief executive for the new Greater London Assembly (GLA) which needs a high-profile bureaucrat who will have to work alongside mayor Ken Livingstone. Elsewhere, though, mayors will have far more power, overseeing GLA-style strategic functions as well as delivering services from schools to social care, libraries to parks. "A local authority like Birmingham, for example, matters a damn site more to its population than the GLA."

Clark would like to see the role of chief executive developing along the lines of a Whitehall permanent secretary - advising a minister and perhaps less in the public eye than now. That's where a higher-profile Solace comes in, advising ministers before big decisions are taken on the practicality of changes.

"At the moment we are consulted on green papers, white papers and other papers, by which time a lot of it's already too late," he says. That creates confusion. And uncertainty about the chief executive's future role? "There has been quite a lot of uncertainty for some time," says Clark. "Chief executives in my region have less longevity than football managers. I have been here five years and I am one of the longest serving."
